IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common primary brain tumor in adults and one of the most deadly cancers, with a median patient survival of 12-15 months. This application aims to unravel the molecular mechanisms activating lipid synthesis in GBM by glutamine metabolism, and further reveal the novel and important role of SREBP-1 in upregulating glutamine uptake that promotes GBM growth. Completion of this study will significantly advance our knowledge of metabolism reprogramming in GBM and malignancies, also provide insights into potential therapeutic approaches for GBM treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative It is estimated that ~1/59 children are affected with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), one of the most serious psychiatric disorders of childhood, defined by deficits in social communication and restricted interests/repetitive behaviors. Recent advances in functional brain imaging show promise that pre-diagnostic neural signatures for ASD may provide useful risk markers and may even be sensitive to responses to interventional therapies that have been shown to improve quality of life. In this R01 proposal, we will extend high density diffuse optical tomography methods, which can silently image brain function in a naturalistic setting and have the potential to be useful for pre-symptomatic risk monitoring, for an innovative and prospective longitudinal study of awake and engaged infants and toddlers at risk for developing ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative. Altered serotonin signaling is linked to brain disorders such as depression and schizophrenia, but the vast complexity of the human brain makes it difficult to study this relationship. This study analyzes an excitatory signal modulated by serotonin within a model neural circuit that regulates a simple behavior in C. elegans. This work will advance our knowledge of serotonin signaling with the goal of better understanding its connection to mental disorders to enable strategies for developing more effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The genetic variation underlying human phenotypic differences including disease is often discovered by mapping associations between sample genotypes and phenotypes. These studies have historically focused on individuals of European ancestries in part to mitigate statistical challenges that arise from inclusion of diverse samples, but the results of these studies are not necessarily applicable to individuals from other global populations. To extend these studies to diverse cohorts, this proposal aims to develop a novel method for controlling for population structure in association studies, and to apply this method to investigate sources of phenotypic variation in a large, globally diverse human gene expression dataset that our group recently generated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Using airway epithelial cells from well characterized and genotyped children with asthma we will determine if dysregulated interferon responses to rhinovirus infection by asthmatic airway epithelial cells are associated with exacerbation frequency, lung function, and/or T2-high vs. T2-low inflammation. We will pair human cell ex vivo approaches to work using a novel mouse model of human rhinovirus infection to provide in vivo mechanistic insights. These studies will allow us to identify potential novel therapeutic pathways to target in asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have identified a robust copy number variant (CNV) signature that distinguishes homologous recombination deficient (HRD) pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas (PDA). Our expertise in DNA content flow cytometry of solid tumors and the genomics of PDA, and Mayo Clinic resources will be leveraged to establish a novel CNV scoring assay (HRD-IA) for predicting treatment responses for patients with PDA. We will validate our assay for use with routinely collected formalin fixed paraffin embedded (FFPE) PDA tissues and will include CLIA approved protocols that will introduce our HRD-IA assay into routine clinical application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Chronic psychosocial stress exposure is a potent but largely under-recognized risk factor for cardiovascular disease (CVD), and research shows that stress reduction techniques may have a benefit in individuals with CVD; however, the underlying mechanism linking stress to CVD remains uncertain. Cutting-edge brain imaging techniques have demonstrated changes in brain center activity in the setting of chronic stress. This multi- parametric hybrid PET/MRI study tests the hypothesis that stress reduction reduces stress-associated neurobiological activity as well as systemic and arterial inflammation and seeks to yield insights into mechanisms that translate stress into physical disease with the goal of improving our ability to prevent and treat CVD.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urinary incontinence (leaking) affects more than 18 million U.S. women and is associated with high costs and significant negative impact on quality of life. Effective non-surgical treatments are available but often do not reach patients. Urinary incontinence may be reduced by helping primary care practices to screen for incontinence and connect patients to resources that are already available within the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. There are near 290,000 people in the United States of America that have a spinal cord injury (SCI) (with at least 18,000 new cases each year) many with functional impairment. The main objective of this grant proposal is to investigate a novel therapeutic strategy which modifies the inflammatory response and can potentially lead to protection of the spinal cord after injury, as well as functional recovery. This dose-response experimental approach will be studied in multiple injury levels and functional outcomes, as well as tracked over time and collectively, these studies will lead to better understanding of the impact of inflammatory modification after injury and can potentially lead to improvement in human care and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major challenge facing contemporary genomic medicine is the clinical community’s desire for yes/no answers to the nuanced issue of whether a specific genetic variant will produce a meaningful phenotype. The current framework used to assess the significance of these variants classifies them from likely pathogenic/ pathogenic to likely benign/benign, with most stuck as variant of uncertain significance. We intend to prove that clinically meaningful knowledge is lost in this compression of variant information into a classification and that a data-driven estimate of disease penetrance is a higher resolution alternative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) is an arterial disease that can cause stenosis (inward growth), aneurysm (outward growth), dissection (tearing), or tortuosity (abnormal bending) of blood vessels, leading to manifestations such as high blood pressure, stroke, heart attacks, and death. These dysplasia-associated arterial diseases are estimated to occur in 1-4% of the U.S. population and most often afflicts women. This study will use genetic and laboratory approaches to discover and characterize the involved genes and understand their functions in causing pathologic changes in the arterial wall, leading to the cardiovascular manifestations; the biologic insights from this study will be important for developing novel diagnostic and therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite its low prevalence, schizophrenia is one of the leading causes of disability worldwide. Immune processes are implicated in the etiology of schizophrenia but remain poorly understood, which is further complicated by the highly clinically heterogenous nature of the disorder. The proposed research will investigate the role of genetically regulated immune marker trajectories in clinical dimensions of schizophrenia to advance the field’s biological and clinical understanding of this devastating neuropsychiatric disorder.

PHR: The first malaria vaccine is being rolled out even though it has suboptimal efficacy for children living in malaria endemic areas. The focus of this proposal is to determine which combination of vaccine-elicited immune responses protect these children against malaria, in contrast to factors that result in malaria vaccine failures. This knowledge will help improve the next generation of malaria vaccines intended for children who bear the burden of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The recent push for early clinical diagnosis of ADRD at the time of symptom onset would be bolstered by evidence of better long-term health for diagnosed patients, more appropriate healthcare utilization, or decreased medical costs. The goal of this project is to develop the evidence base describing the predictors and consequences of underdiagnosis (i.e., late or missed diagnosis) vs early clinical diagnosis of dementia in healthcare settings. Based on our findings, healthcare consumers and medical providers will be able to make better informed choices about when to seek or offer cognitive evaluation, and public health agencies, health systems, and health insurers will be able to use our findings when deciding whether and how to promote ea rly evaluation and diagnosis of dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor heterogeneity is a well-known property of treatment resistant, recurrent, and metastatic breast cancer. The proposed research project is relevant to public health because it will provide a genetically tractable Cancer rainbow mouse model for inducing and visualizing tumor heterogeneity in an immune intact system. The proposed studies will credential the use of a novel Crainbow mouse model that more accurately recapitulates the heterogeneity found in treatment resistant HER2+ breast cancer patients. Our proposal will significantly improve upon the translational utility of mouse models for preclinical trials and at the same time provide a reliable tool for reconstructing the molecular and cellular interactome controlling tumor heterogeneity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed experiments utilize critical biomechanical information and approaches to understanding the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) and associated disc, which were determined by our previous study of pig TMJ. It extends that approach into human patients, and combines it with state of the art patient-specific craniofacial morphology combined with oral function biomechanics. This approach will test healthy males and females, in comparison with those who have TMJ dysfunction, to determine why females get TMJ dysfunction and disease 3-8 times more frequently than males.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The minimum protective tenofovir diphosphate (TFV-DP) concentrations, the active form of tenofovir-based PrEP, in the blood and the level of adherence required to achieve those concentrations may differ depending on the route and frequency of exposure to HIV. Using our combined complementary expertise in HIV prevention research in women and antiretroviral pharmacology, we will define cisgender women-specific adherence- concentration-efficacy benchmarks for TFV moieties in a novel directly observe study of TDF/FTC PrEP in African women, a priority population for HIV prevention. We will then link the newly defined thresholds to the Partners PrEP Study clinical cohort to estimate TFV-DP concentrations associated with HIV protection for women and the minimum adherence level (doses per week) required to achieve these levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Although early-stage and low grade endometrial cancer generally exhibits a favorable prognosis, metastatic and recurrent endometrial cancer is incurable with currently available standard therapies for most women. Therefore, there is an urgent obligation to explore the mechanism of tumor metastasis and recurrence to further elucidate the progression of endometrial cancer. The experiments proposed in this application will employ the first preclinical animal model that closely resembles human endometrial cancer with distant metastasis and recurrence to identify new mechanistic targets that could dramatically improve therapeutic options for endometrial cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Recent discoveries indicate that subsets of human NK cells mediate adaptive immunity to HIV-encoded antigens; however, NK cell receptor repertoires diversify throughout life, and high NK cell receptor repertoire diversity is associated with increased risk of HIV acquisition. These data present a challenge for vaccine design, as both protective NK cell-mediated memory responses and potentially harmful NK cell receptor repertoire diversifications are consequences of antigen exposures. To solve this problem, this study will identify the NK functional subsets that are most responsive to HIV, and their mechanisms of host protection from HIV disease, providing the rationale to develop novel vaccines that exploit the antiviral effector functions of NK cells to protect humans from HIV infection while avoiding harmful activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will elucidate molecular mechanisms through which WT RAS signaling drives transformation of cancers harboring specific mutant RAS isoforms, including the relative contribution of SOS1 and SOS2. Defining the mutant RAS-isoform specific requirements of WT RAS signaling will help us better understand the landscape of RAS mutated tumors and allow us to identify specific vulnerabilities for therapeutic intervention in an isoform-specific manner. Hence, this research will inform novel therapeutic approaches for eradicating subsets of RAS mutated tumors with genotype-dependent precision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Success of the proposed research will unveil in-depth mechanisms of ferroptosis, as well as its functional communication with various cancer-relevant intercellular and intracellular molecular events. The proposed research will also lead to the identification of biomarkers that predict cancer responsiveness to future ferroptosis- inducing cancer therapy.

PHR: Project Narrative The Advanced Technologies-National Center for Image guided Therapy (AT-NCIGT) is a research and technology center with the mission of advancing patient care, by developing novel innovative tools for image guided Therapy (IGT). IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and other progressive fibrosing interstitial lung diseases (PF-ILDs) are incurable, scarring lung disorders that lead to respiratory failure and early death despite current therapies. This proposal will evaluate a novel pathway in the development and progression of IPF and other PF-ILDs in order to determine its prognostic and therapeutic potential. Knowledge gained from this study is likely to provide new insights into potential biomarkers of PF-ILD progression and acute exacerbations that will ultimately support generation of more effective therapies leading to improved outcomes in PF-ILD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The commercial availability of cannabidiol, or CBD oil, has increased in the United Stated and this supplement has the potential to cause a variety of drug-drug interactions, including in solid organ transplant recipients who receive tacrolimus to prevent rejection. Through a series of pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamics assays, this proposal will identify gene-drug and drug-drug interactions (DDI), including those that place transplant recipients at risk for increased toxicity related to their immunosuppression. The information learned in these studies will help to inform practitioners as to whether cannabidiol needs to be avoided in transplant recipients and how to appropriately adjust doses of CBD and immunosuppression in order to improve health outcomes and long-term treatment success in this high-risk population.

PHR: Project Narrative Cost-related medication restrictions may reduce the effectiveness of glucose-lowering medications among real- world patients with diabetes. The proposed research will generate new scientific knowledge the feasibility of an educational outreach intervention to reduce cost-related restrictions and improve evidence-based medication use. This research can help patients with type 2 diabetes and their healthcare providers make better treatment decisions to improve health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Currently, more than 250 million humans worldwide are infected with schistosomes, flatworms in the genus Schistosoma, and approximately 20 million humans suffer from severe morbidity due to schistosomiasis. Humans become infected after exposure to larval parasites (cercariae) that are produced by infected snails in freshwater habitats. This project proposes and evaluates novel ecological hypotheses that could improve the prediction and control of a parasite causing major global health burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents with severe obesity experience significant physical and mental health morbidity, stigma, and premature death. Metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) is the most potent treatment available; however, a significant proportion of youth experience ongoing persistent obesity or weight regain after MBS without clear physiologic predictors, which may lead to residual cardiometabolic, mechanical, and psychological risks that must be effectively managed long-term. In the proposed study, we will collect rigorous longitudinal physiologic measures of gut peptides, insulin sensitivity, and cardiovascular structure/function not previously reported in youth after MBS, and will perform the first randomized, controlled trial of semaglutide post-MBS among youth with suboptimal BMI reduction, which in aggregate will refine the definition of MBS success and establish the feasibility and initial efficacy of semaglutide as a potential postoperative treatment adjunct.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The risks of severe disease or death from bacterial pneumonia are far worse in individuals with pre-existing lung disease, and it has been long established that alcohol use disorders (common in the Veterans’ population) lead to increased lung infections due to compromised innate lung defense. While reactive aldehydes are a source of this lung injury, their source and mechanism of action remains unknown. This study will define which at-risk conditions particularly impact those with AUD and their unique needs in order to empower clinical preventive care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly one-third of deceased donor livers ultimately go unused due to the inability to preserve them long enough. We aim to develop a novel technology for indefinitely preserving whole livers in an extremely low-temperature vitrified (glass-like) state and subsequently using nanotechnology to rewarm them on demand. If successful, this novel technology will enable the banking, or “off-the-shelf” availability, of livers for transplantation and other vital biomedical applications such as cell therapy, biomedical research, and drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders are a set of major morphological, neurobiological, and cognitive abnormalities in offspring exposed to alcohol in utero. A common cognitive manifestation of alcohol exposure during neural development in humans, and in animal models of prenatal alcohol exposure, are deficits in spatial learning and memory. The primary objective of the present proposal is to identify the systems and neural circuit-level mechanisms involved in spatial learning and memory deficits after prenatal alcohol exposure by monitoring large ensembles of hippocampal neurons during active behavior and rest. Further investigation of the neurobiological mechanisms underlying spatial learning and memory impairments is critically important for the development of precise diagnostic tools and therapeutic interventions to help manage or reverse disordered brain states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol activates microglia within the central nervous system via the critical innate immune protein MyD88 , although it remains unclear if this activation is helpful or harmful for dependence and abuse. This project will determine the specific impact of chronic alcohol exposure in mice on microglial-MyD88 function and their impact on precise neuronal function and excess drinking behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An aberrant expansion stem-like cells is observed in a number of lung diseases, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), Cystic Fibrosis, and cancer. In this study we propose to use molecular and genetic approaches to define signals resulting from defects in airway epithelial architecture, which our observations suggest contribute to aberrant stem cell expansion and other disease phenotypes associated with lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have recently discovered that a subpopulation of Trypanosoma cruzi parasites (the cause of Chagas disease) is able to enter a metabolically inactive state that makes them resistant to anti-parasitic drugs. The goal of this project is to understand how this state of dormancy is generated and how existing drugs can be delivered, and new drugs discovered, so as to eventually clear these otherwise drug resistant forms from hosts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence of type 2 diabetes continues to escalate worldwide, but fortunately, it is well established that regular physical activity can prevent or delay the onset of this disease. The long-term goal of this project is to understand the molecular mechanisms through which exercise improves glucose homeostasis and metabolic health, and in the last several years we have determined that when mothers exercise, their offspring have improved metabolic health. The specific focus of this research project for the next five years is to determine how maternal exercise has these remarkable beneficial effects on the health of offspring, which could provide a new paradigm for diabetes prevention and have a tremendous impact on health care worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Lay Summary Knee osteoarthritis (OA) is a common, disabling problem in the United States. Walking can help treat and control pain from OA and walking in your neighborhood is a great way to exercise. This study will look at what characteristics of a neighborhood contribute to walking and how doctors should talk to their patients about it to help them accomplish their walking goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Recurrent, truncating driver mutations of PPM1D, the gene encoding the WIP1 protein phosphatase, occur across a range of human cancers, including Diffuse Midline Gliomas (DMG), a devastating brain tumor of childhood. We will evaluate the mechanisms through which PPM1D mutations drive tumor formation and will determine strategies to therapeutically target them. The results generated in this proposal will inform the development of precision medicine approaches for children with DMG, and will be relevant to thousands of other patients diagnosed with PPM1D-mutant tumors including leukemia and endometrial cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV/AIDS is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, the overarching goal of this project is to explore the safety and therapeutic potential of a novel, combined cytokine treatment (IL-12 plus IL-15/IL-15ra) as a curative strategy for HIV/SIV in SIV-infected ART-treated, therapeutically vaccinated rhesus macaques. Specifically, we propose that the sequential administration of IL-12 and IL-15/IL-15ra will have a strong synergistic effect on antiviral responses leading to the reduction of SIV replication. If successful, this strategy will then be translated to the human clinic to achieve a cure for HIV infection without lifelong ART.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is an aggressive cancer subtype with limited treatment options. We have made the surprising discovery that the antioxidant glutathione (GSH) functions extracellularly, not intracellularly, to support TNBC growth. Our research will challenge the paradigm of antioxidant function in cancer by describing a novel mechanism of GSH function as a circulating source of amino acids and has the potential to reveal a completely new set of therapeutic targets for TNBC intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Polyphosphates are an understudied class of inorganic polymers, which are accumulated by bacteria as long linear chains of orthophosphate residues. Here, we hypothesize that bacterial polyphosphates interfere with a protective host immune response and mediate harmful outcomes of septic peritonitis after cecum ligation and puncture. The proposed studies aim for new insights into the pathogenesis of polyphosphate-dependent host-microbe interactions in the peritoneal/mucosal microenvironment and will help to better understand the systemic injury response to bacterial sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The osteocyte is the most abundant cell in mature bone and functions to sense mechanical stress and regulate bone homeostasis. We have found that the Fibroblast Growth Factor signaling pathway is required for osteocyte viability in adult bone. Understanding the underlying biological mechanisms connecting Fibroblast Growth Factor signaling to osteocyte viability and skeletal homeostasis will lead to the identification of new genes and pathways that could be targeted to promote osteocyte viability and maintain healthy bone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The oncogene MYC is one of the most commonly altered genes in human cancer, yet there are no FDA-approved MYC-targeting therapies due to a lack of a binding site for standard chemical inhibitors; therefore, it is imperative to develop alternative methods to treat MYC-driven tumors. Recent evidence indicates that the tumor-promoting activity of MYC requires RNA splicing, a process that determines which version of a gene is expressed within cells. In this research, we will identify which proteins controlling RNA splicing and gene versions are impacted by MYC to promote cancer, and we will thereby discover targets for the development of novel therapeutic strategies targeting RNA splicing in tumors and new markers that could be used for clinical diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current therapy for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which is the fourth leading cause of death in the United States, focuses on inhaled medications without targeting systemic processes although COPD is now recognized as a disease with systemic manifestations. Understanding whether platelet activation, which perpetuates inflammation, regulates immune cell function, and has long been implicated in the development and rupture of atherosclerotic plaques, is associated with respiratory morbidity may uncover a target for systemic therapy in COPD. A potential antiplatelet therapy, aspirin, is no longer recommended as primary prevention for cardiovascular disease, thus a clinical trial to determine an effective aspirin dose that suppresses platelet activation in COPD is timely and provides preliminary data for a larger trial investigating whether aspirin improves respiratory morbidity in COPD that may identify an alternative indication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension prevalence increases with aging and is an important modifiable risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias and cardiovascular disease. The overall goals of this K24 program are to investigate the mechanisms (including social determinants of health) of the use, underuse, and unsafe use of antihypertensive medications to prevent aging-related multimorbidity, including Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias and cardiovascular disease, as well as to train the next generation of diverse, patient-oriented, aging-related research scientists in hypertension pharmacoepidemiology. This proposal will have a significant public health impact because it will (1) increase the number of new patient- oriented researchers from diverse backgrounds dedicated to optimizing medication use to prevent aging- related multimorbidity and (2) generate new knowledge on the mechanisms leading to the underuse, misuse, and unsafe use of antihypertensive medications to reduce aging-related multimorbidity across the US population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: Many glaucoma patients experience continued vision loss despite maximally reduced intraocular pressure, indicating that additional factors contribute to the pathology of the disease. Our preliminary studies have indicated that the T-cell population of some patients exhibits a markedly pro-inflammatory skew and that the removal of T-cells protects vision in animal models of the disease. The goal of this project is to identify which T-cell population is active in this process and to elucidate the mechanisms of T-cell mediated damage to the retina in glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Relevance Antibiotic resistant Campylobacter is a serious antibiotic resistance threat to public health. This project will elucidate a new mechanism used by Campylobacter for multidrug resistance and for coping with selection pressure from use of various antibiotics. The findings will facilitate the development of intervention strategies to control the emergence and spread of antibiotic resistance in this significant human pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excessive alcohol consumption is a major public health hazard. This component of the Integrative Neuroscience Initiative on Alcoholism-Neuroimmune consortium is a research project that will examine neuroimmune activity in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region that mediates the reinforcing effects of alcohol. The results of this project will shed new light on how interactions between neurons and non-neuronal brain cells promote excessive alcohol consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Over 600,000 people die from cancer each year in the United States and many more suffer from other serious illnesses that may benefit from specialist palliative care. By identifying modifiable factors that influence effectiveness of specialist palliative care delivery, this project will directly inform policies for palliative care programs, cancer centers and hospitals to enable and ensure the delivery of effective palliative care for all patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: US veterans develop diabetes and chronic kidney disease (CKD) at an alarming rate, and comorbidity is twice as common in veterans compared with the general population. Both diseases put patients at increased risk of fracture and when fractures occur, patients are at a greater risk of death compared to other populations. Treatments for skeletal disease typically address deficits in either bone mass or tissue quality, which may be insufficient in cases of combined CKD and diabetes where there are known deficits in both. Unfortunately, models needed to study treatment of these comorbid conditions are lacking. The goal of this project is to study skeletal interactions between diabetes and CKD and to identify effective combination skeletal treatments. Specifically, we propose experiments to study combined treatments for bone mass and tissue quality deficiencies, in the context of disease onset age and duration. The results of this work will provide alternative ways to prevent or treat skeletal deficits associated with diabetes and CKD in our veteran population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This proposal addresses how the lungs of older people change with age. In particular, we will study how mucin 5AC increases in the airway epithelium with age, how that relates to increased susceptibility to lung cancer and how we can diminish mucin 5AC levels in the lung. This is of importance to Veterans as lung cancer is one of the three most diagnosed cancers in the VA system, while 48% of the Veterans enrolled in the VA are over the age of 65.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research training plan will address the knowledge gaps in the development and progression of the most common inherited cardiac disease, Hypertrophy Cardiomyopathy (HCM). Several single point mutations in b- myosin heavy chain (MYH7), myosin-binding protein C (MYBPC3) and cardiac troponin (cTn) have been associated with HCM and increased contractility at the organ level; however, the kinetics at the molecular level remain unclear, as different mutations can result in increased, decreased, or unchanged myosin force production. This research will focus on changes in biochemical signaling of HCM mutant cardiomyocytes, specifically through the Hippo pathway, which is known to be a homeostatic regulator of cellular size, a hallmark of HCM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE American Indians suffer from the highest rate of cardiovascular disease in the nation and efforts to address cardiovascular disease prevention amongst American Indians are few and less effective compared to the general population. The goal of this project is to partner with the Cherokee Nation to co-create an intervention to prevent cardiovascular disease based on over 30 years of successful interventions that facilitate Cherokee-specific cultural learning. Results from this project will lead to potentially new methods to reduce the morbidity and mortality of cardiovascular disease using an indigenous and community informed perspective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and emphysema are, jointly, the fourth leading cause of death in the United States and third leading cause globally. The Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA) Lung Study found that emphysema measured quantitatively on computed tomography (CT) is common and morbid among older adults in the general population; however, standard measures underestimate the complexity of the disease. In this renewal, we hypothesize that machine-learned CT emphysema subtypes are distinct, have different causes and prognoses, and that distinguishing pathological emphysema from that resulting from normal aging with help the prevention and treatment of COPD and emphysema.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Addressing the significant mental health burden of our modern society cannot be accomplished in the absence of meaningful scientific discovery by physician-scientists. The Emory Clinical Scientist Training Program (CSTP) addresses the critical shortage of well-trained physician-scientists in psychiatry by utilizing an innovative research training platform, grounded in state-of the-art clinical neuroscience research and addressing the primary need for intensive mentorship throughout psychiatry residency. In addition, the Emory CSTP provides research training and experiences to all psychiatry residents to nurture their interests in research and prepare them for a life-long practice of evidence-based medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Linking Science, Mathematics and Literacy for All Learners (LSM&L4AL) PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is focused on developing educational resources—multimodal STEM text sets—designed for middle school students to engage in and understand complex text. We will test the hypothesis that these resources, situated in life sciences topics, will result in improved diverse learners’ reading, mathematics, and scientific argumentation skills. These resources along with findings from the project will be disseminated widely and contribute to NIH’s and the nation’s overarching goal to “enhance the training of a workforce to meet the nation’s biomedical, behavioral and clinical research needs and especially of students from underserved communities.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although widely used and accepted in oncology practice to determine patient eligibility and physical tolerance for clinical trial participation, performance status—the single most powerful prognostic and key clinical decision-making tool across all solid tumor types—has one very significant limitation: its subjectivity. We propose to examine the association between continuously and objectively measured PA and clinician- assessed performance status scores, overall patient survival, and clinical outcomes of significance (i.e., symptom burden, quality of life measures, death, disease progression, treatment termination due to toxicity, hospitalizations and emergency room visits, and referral for supportive/hospice care). Our long-term goal is to increase objectivity in performance status assessments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The experiments in this project will use an animal model of alcohol self-administration to study maladaptive changes in synaptic plasticity in specific prefrontal cortical networks that occur in the transition from goal-directed to compulsive alcohol drinking. Understanding the development of these changes is important as they are likely to contribute to cognitive deficits and impact the ability of the prefrontal cortex to regulate drug-seeking behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal will investigate the mechanisms that underpin effective vaccination against the systemic fungal infection Coccidioidomycosis. A live attenuated vaccine strain of the fungus has been developed and is known to protect against lethal infection, following vaccine delivery intranasally. It is widely believed that local immunity is mobilized by the vaccine and this proposal will clarify the necessary elements required for establishing this vaccine immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) is a severe congenital heart defect that can lead to death of newborns within a week in the absence of surgical treatment. This R01 project aims to address how the aberrant intercellular communication between myocardium (cardiac muscle fibers) and endocardium (endothelial cells lining the interior of the heart) leads to HLHS using patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cells and CRISPR genome editing. Understanding how HLHS is developed would be pivotal to discover novel therapeutic treatment for this lethal disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The most common cause of renal failure in the United States (US) is diabetic kidney disease (DKD), which costs the US ~$20 billion annually. DKD is, therefore, a substantial medical and economic burden to the healthcare system. The goal of the proposed studies is to determine if potentiating the effects of a hormonal system that protects the cells forming the kidney’s filter prevents or slows progression of DKD. If successful, the treatment approach might be used to treat DKD in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasmodium parasites, which cause the disease malaria, still sicken and debilitate over 200 million people per year at great cost to health. In this proposal, we will specifically address the biology behind the elusive Plasmodium vivax hypnozoite, a dormant liver stage, that can reactivate days, months or even years after its initial infection of a host hepatocyte, leading to a relapse of blood stage disease. Understanding how to combat the clinically silent hypnozoite is vital in an arena of malaria elimination and eradication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Approximately half the patients treated with BCG, the only approved immunotherapy for non-muscle invasive bladder cancer, experience a recurrence or progression of the disease. Our goal is two-fold: First, to better understand the longitudinal local and peripheral immune response to repeated intravesical BCG exposures and second, to identify specific genetic and immunological factors that impact patients’ sensitivity or resistance to treatment with BCG. When successful this information will help identify potential new strategies for improving treatment with BCG as a single therapy or in combination with other immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypothalamic neuropeptides AgRP, NPY, and αMSH are powerful regulators of food intake, energy expenditure, and body weight; however, exactly how they impact downstream circuits to modify behavior and physiology has remained a knowledge gap in the understanding and treatment of the obesity epidemic. Biochemically, receptors to these peptides signal through the secondary messenger cAMP, but technological barriers have prevented real-time monitoring and manipulation of cAMP in behaving animals. This grant uses new tools to track, make, and degrade cAMP to understand: (i) how cAMP levels change over time following direct cAMP stimulation of feeding, (ii) how changing cAMP influences neuronal activity, and (iii) how natural, compartmentalized changes in cAMP affects local neuronal functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our work suggests that activation of STING in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) cells is disadvantageous for their growth and survival. Further understanding the mechanisms of STING in regulating BCR degradation, apoptosis and chemoresistance in CLL will inform us of how STING agonists can be deployed as anti-CLL agents alone or in combination with inhibitors of the BCR signaling such as BTKi to treat CLL in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early detection of subtle cognitive decline associated with developing Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathology is crucial for identifying individuals who are most likely to benefit from early interventions. In this innovative proposal, we leverage existing data from three cohort studies to examine novel measures from the widely-used story recall task, including lexical retrieval, serial position, and computational linguistic measures, and their associations with amyloid, tau, neurodegeneration, and progression to clinical impairment. By using existing data from multiple AD cohort studies, we can develop novel methodology for early detection without adding participant burden, and can contribute an improved understanding of the underlying mechanisms of memory and communication breakdowns in preclinical AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of DT-LVAD implants is rapidly growing, and linkages between change in sleep and changes in cognitive function, symptoms of anxiety and depression, and health-related quality of life following LVAD implant remain largely unknown. The proposed research will detail changes and uncover new connections between sleep quality, cognitive function, psychological symptoms and health-related quality of life, which have not been studied simultaneously in the LVAD population. Findings generated from this investigation will provide foundational knowledge for building a new program of research in symptom and symptom management science in advanced heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: We aim to test and understand the mechanism of a FDA-approved anti-inflammatory drug called Singulair for blocking initiation and malignant transition of a human disease named polycythemia vera (PV). We have identified a key gene known as Alox5 in PV-initiating cells from which PV is derived. We found that the Alox5 pathway is critically required for PV-initiating cell survival and disease initiation, and Singulair blocks this pathway effectively, providing a novel strategy for treating PV patients, and also for preventing PV and disease relapse in some healthy individuals who have acquired PV-causing gene but have not developed clinical symptoms, in patients who are in remission but in danger of transitioning to acute leukemia, and in patients who received bone marrow transplantation but still have detectable leukemia cells.

PHR: Project Narrative Our mitochondrial genome (mtDNA) holds instructions that make mitochondria the “powerhouses of the cell”, but there is growing awareness that mtDNA can also trigger autoimmune response and collateral damage. I will examine the molecular machines that control this yin and yang of mtDNA. Through the K99/R00 award, I will train towards becoming an independent academic investigator and discover basic mechanisms relevant for treating both mitochondrial and inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research by Dr. Zhiyu Dai is aimed at understanding why some patients develop high blood pressure in the lungs (pulmonary hypertension). Pulmonary hypertension is a serious and progressive disease without a cure and with 5-year mortality as great as 50%. In particular, we are trying to understand a pulmonary hypertension causing gene called SOX17 and develop a new effective therapeutic strategy for the treatment of this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Virtually every mammalian tissue exhibits overt 24-hour rhythms in gene expression that are critical for coordinating the daily activity of nearly every biological function and maintaining cellular homeostasis. The proposed study will determine the role of feeding rhythms and of the mTOR signaling pathway in the regulation of rhythmic gene expression in mouse liver. Our results are expected to uncover exciting findings on how rhythmic food intake regulates the activity of the mTOR pathway to set along with the molecular circadian clock a harmonized rhythmic gene expression network and prevents the development of pathological disorders.

PHR: The next generation of viral vaccines and biologics alike will be designed rationally, based on a structural understanding of how protective antibodies engage the epitope of the target. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Consumption of ultra-processed foods is linked with obesity, type 2 diabetes, multiple forms of cancer, increased incidence of cardiovascular disease, and overall increased all-cause mortality. Uncovering the basic mechanisms of why these foods are so rewarding and overconsumed is essential to develop strategies to improve health and reduce the disease burden driven by consumption of these foods. To this end, we will combine metabolic, neural, and behavioral measures with advanced predictive modeling to uncover key factors that drive ultra-processed food reward in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The experiments in this proposal explore ways in which microorganisms adapt to the infected host to favor their own survival. The investigators have identified microbe-specific features that mediate these adaptations, suggesting new targets for antimicrobial therapy. Additionally, these experiments will explore how understanding and intervening with the host response to infection might also contribute to the optimal treatment of infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer metastasis to the brain is rising in prevalence and is an increasingly lethal threat to the patients. Our research objective is to determine the mechanism by which microRNA secreted by breast cancer cells alters normal cells in the brain to promote metastasis. This understanding could help researchers develop novel predictive biomarkers and therapeutic treatments to prevent cancer cells from metastasizing to the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE There is a complex interaction between stressful life experiences, alcohol drinking, and the risk for developing an alcohol use disorder (AUD). The work conducted in this Core will combine the INIAstress model of stress- induced escalation of alcohol drinking in dependent mice with cutting-edge whole-brain imaging technology, advanced network analysis of activated cells, and pharmacological targeting of key systems important for stress- alcohol interactions. The overall goal is to identify novel brain regions and networks and evaluate how these networks are altered by pharmacological manipulation of critical target systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Nearly 20% of women in the U.S. (1 million women per year) experience clinically significant depressive symptoms during the perinatal period (pregnancy and postpartum), and social connectedness may be a modifiable factor involved in symptom persistence. A promising self-management approach called Mindful Moms has been developed and tested in our team’s pilot studies; we propose to build upon this work by evaluating Mindful Moms through a randomized controlled trial with marginalized women (minority, low socioeconomic status) who often suffer “in silence” due to various barriers in care. The successful completion of this study will provide important insights into social connectedness as a mechanism to decrease depressive symptoms in a largely understudied population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relapse to alcohol use in dependent individuals is exacerbated by stress and the experiments outlined in this proposal will help inform our understanding of the neurobiological mechanisms that underly the complex relationship between alcohol use disorder (AUD) and exposure to stress. Ultimately, the data collected from these studies will provide valuable information about mechanisms that contribute to uncontrolled alcohol use, cognitive dysfunction and anxiety-like behaviors characteristic of AUD, and will help to identify new pharmacotherapeutic targets for the treatment of AUD, especially in the context of chronic stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Concurrent alcohol drinking and stress is a risk factor for excessive drinking and deficits in cognitive function in favor of performing habitual actions. The proposed research will use sophisticated in vivo neuroimaging methods to measure dynamic changes in brain circuitry and brain metabolism across the history of exposure to alcohol, stress, or in combination of the two. This will open a new pathway for diagnosing the severity of brain impairments and developing treatments for chronic ethanol.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exercise and physical loading support bone health, and better understanding the cellular mechanisms involved will help to treat an aging population facing degenerative bone diseases. This project studies the signaling pathways by which irisin, a signaling factor released from muscle during exercise, affects key cells within bone to guide adaptation of the tissue. By delineating these mechanisms, our work will contribute to the understanding of skeletal adaption and inform future efforts at developing therapeutics to protect bone health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver transplantation, the only lifesaving treatment for end-stage liver disease, is increasingly performed for older adults with multiple comorbidities and physical and cognitive impairments. Navigating post-transplant medical care is complex and requires formidable cognitive and self-management skills. This project will study how cognitive impairment and self-management skills among liver transplant recipients and their caregivers influence health status, health behaviors, and outcomes to inform future health-system interventions to reduce complexity and optimize long-term health after liver transplantation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is focused on elucidating the regulation and structure/function relationships of a single enzyme, OGT, involved in post-translational modification of thousands of protein substrates. This work builds on our recent discovery that mutations in the OGT gene are causal for X-linked intellectual disability. The proposed efforts will uncover a mechanistic understanding of the impact of the disease variants and lay the groundwork for being able to ameliorate consequences of the disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol abuse is a major public health concern, resulting in close to 100,000 deaths per year in the United States alone. Cognitive deficits and maladaptive responses to stress are known to be cooccurring factors associated with alcohol use disorder and determining how these factors contribute to susceptibility and resilience would help to improve prevention and treatment strategies. This proposal focuses on precisely defining how the function of specific circuits in prefrontal cortex mediate interactions between cognition, stress, and the development of harmful alcohol drinking patterns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A high density of tobacco retailers in communities is strongly linked to tobacco use behaviors and contributes to tobacco-related health disparities. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sickle cell disease (SCD) disproportionally impacts underrepresented minority populations and remains grossly understudied . The proposed research will help us understand how variations in environmental exposures and immune responses predicated upon health disparities predispose children with SCD to poor clinical outcomes. The proposal is relevant to public health and the NIH’s mission as the findings will help improve the prediction, prevention, and treatment of acute complications in children with SCD with strategies that move beyond the current paradigm of supportive and/or reactive care.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Healthy People 2030 stresses the importance of the social determinants of health, including the family and the COVID-19 Pandemic has brought emphasis to the effects of structural determinants of health. Our goals fit squarely within the vision of the NICHD and specifically the Population Dynamics Branch (PDB) to help understand changes—including new challenges—shaping families and provide data useful for timely assessments of community health. These data will provide researchers and practitioners monthly point-in-time estimates of social and community context—an effective tool for understanding the changing landscape of marriage and families in the United States and its effect on health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Urinary tract infections (UTIs), a frequent problem in children with spina bifida, are notoriously difficult to diagnose in this population. The goal of this research is to first develop a method to identify which children with spina bifida are at high risk for a UTI, and then develop a more accurate way to diagnose UTIs in this population. The results of this research will lead to more appropriate antibiotic use, thus tempering the rising rate of UTIs with antibiotic-resistant organisms seen in children with spina bifida.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The sex differences related to the physiological mechanisms that cause fluid retention associated with cirrhosis are unknown. Animal models of cirrhosis will be used to determine the physiological and cellular mechanisms that produce sex differences in vasopressin release and fluid retention associated and differences in gene expression in vasopressin neurons among males and females using spatial transcriptomics to bridge this gap in our understanding and eventually to identify new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is an effective tool to reduce new HIV infections, however, it is underutilized, especially in the South and among heavily impacted groups, such as racial and ethnic minorities. This application focuses on the development and evaluation of a multifaceted strategy to improve PrEP implementation among individuals incarcerated at the Dallas County Jail. By using data from electronic health records and patients’ health histories to identify candidates for PrEP, engaging them in informed decision- making about PrEP, and providing navigation to PrEP care upon community re-entry, this project has potential to improve PrEP use and reduce HIV infections in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goals of our research are to 1) elucidate the mechanistic link between skin microbiota and local immune dysregulation in rosacea skin and 2) elucidate potential systemic immune dysregulation in rosacea patients. Unlike prior studies, we aim to employ multi-omics data integration to 1) explain the complex relationship of the microbial environment and the host immune response in the skin, and 2) characterize the systemic immune dysregulation that can explain the systemic disease burden in rosacea patients. We anticipate that our findings will lead to the development of novel preventative and therapeutic targets and shift the way we study and manage rosacea toward early detection and prevention of systemic co-morbidities.

PHR: Narrative The National Institute of Mental Health has described a critical shortage of child and adolescent psychiatrists who pursue research as a major part of their career. We are determined to improve the yield of researchers for our field by developing the Research Education in Child and Adolescent Psychiatry (RE-CAP) research track within the largest child and adolescent psychiatry residency program in the United States, while also enriching neuroscience and research education for the full training program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Neonates with congenital cardiac diseases undergoing surgery requiring cardiopulmonary bypass using deep hypothermic circulatory arrest (DHCA) are at high risk for impaired neurodevelopmental progression due to time-related ischemia and exposure to toxic levels of brain metabolites. We will use 1H magnetic resonance spectroscopy to determine the real time metabolic changes occurring in the brain during DHCA and, importantly, during the alternative clinical strategy of antegrade cerebral perfusion (ACP) that provides oxygenated blood to the brain. The proposed studies will document continuous time-related changes in brain metabolites and correlate altered levels of these metabolites with alterations in cognitive development following DHCA and ACP bypass procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will examine how asthma and its treatment with steroids affects the antibody response to COVID-19 infection and vaccination. We will measure antibody levels in the blood as well as from the surface of the nose and lungs. The information obtained by this study will be helpful in developing better vaccines to prevent COVID-19 infection and whether children with asthma are at higher risk for reduced antibody responses and highlight the importance of treatment with anti-COVID medicines when they are exposed to the virus at home or school.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The most common and most aggressive adult primary brain tumor is glioblastoma (GBM). In this study, we seek to develop tumor-derived cell-free DNA present in the circulation as a non-invasive biomarker to diagnose GBM and detect recurrent disease. The non-invasive assessment of GBM has the potential to directly affect patient care by enabling the optimization of clinical management prior to or instead of risk-associated invasive diagnostic procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) disease causes chronic inflammation and requires at least 6-months of treatment. In this proposal, we will characterize the impact of TB on stress hyperglycemia and risk of diabetes mellitus after TB treatment ends. Our results will improve understanding of how inflammation and diabetes interact to impact both TB treatment and metabolic health outcomes for patients with TB disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Changes in neurotransmitter identity represent a novel and potent form of homeostatic plasticity that exists in parallel to the multitude of synaptic strength-based plasticity mechanisms used to maintain the balance of activity within circuits. We have found that the set-point of adult sleep in Drosophila is determined by cells that exhibit transmitter plasticity. In this proposal we will uncover the basic mechanisms of this understudied form of plasticity and determine its role in setting the sleep homeostat.

PHR: RELEVANCE The proposed study seeks to quantify the early age-related changes on brain MRI after unilateral ischemic stroke and how they relate to post-stroke cognition. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hyaluronan is a key component of organs and may play a role in wound healing; however, the role of hyaluronan in the failing heart is not known. By understanding the role hyaluronan plays in cardiac scar formation and chronic fibrosis, we can expose novel therapeutic approaches to optimize these adaptations and minimize disease risk. This project will employ several innovative ideas and techniques to study impact of hyaluronan on fibroblast function and ventricular remodeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The central goal of this proposal is to understand the neural systems subserving the decision to use the left or right hand – a simple choice that is central to our daily functions. Here we focus on parietal mechanisms of limb selection. The work may inform rehabilitation approaches for patients with neurological disorders including stroke and traumatic brain injuries in whom limb use is affected.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Axons (the long cellular connections among nerve cells) typically fail to regrow when severed, leading to paralysis after spinal cord injury. We have discovered a series of compounds that promote the growth of axons in the brain and spinal cord. The goal of this proposal is to improve the properties of these compounds to generate candidate drugs that can be tested in clinical trials of injured patients.

PHR: Project Narrative The COVID-19 public health emergency exposed societal vulnerabilities and racial/ethnic health disparities in access and quality of healthcare for patients with a substance use disorder (SUD). This study will examine the effects of changes to addiction treatment practices on outcomes at the patient, organizational, and community levels, with a focus on Black/African American and Latinx clients. The findings from this study will inform public health responses to reduce health disparities in vulnerable communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: A major function of the circadian system is to align feeding and metabolic cycles to optimize nutrient storage and utilization across the light/dark cycle, though how the clock senses changes in nutrient availability to maintain metabolic homeostasis throughout the day is not well-understood. The major goals of our proposed studies are (i) to dissect the mechanisms underlying the role of the clock at the level of liver and brain in maintaining energy constancy during fasting/sleep, and (ii) to dissect the molecular basis for nutrient sensing by the clock that underlies the physiologic adaptation to healthful calorie restriction. Results from the proposed studies will elucidate how the clock sustains the vital provision of energy to brain during sleep and how calorie restriction acts through the clock to improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative for R01 application by Hayakawa  Extracellular mitochondria transfer in gray and white matter for ameliorating sensorimotor and  cognitive deficits after stroke  Mitochondria are important for maintaining energy homeostasis in mammalian cells, but it is now increasingly recognized that mitochondria may be surprisingly release and transfer from cell to cell. Is it possible that this mitochondrial transfer may represent a novel non-autonomous mechanism to supply energy and promote neuron-oligodendrocyte-vascular recovery after stroke? Here, we propose that post-translational modification by O-GlcNAc amplifies extracellular mitochondrial functionality and efficient mitochondrial transfer that can accelerate the blood-brain barrier repair, remyelination and improve neuroplasticity. Therefore, these mechanisms should boost sensorimotor recovery and ameliorate post-stroke dementia after focal ischemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research seeks to understand the molecular mechanisms of caspase-4/-5/-11 noncanonical inflammasomes activation. Non-canonical inflammasomes are large multiprotein complexes that play key roles in the innate immune surveillance of infections and danger, and have been shown to play pivotal roles in various inflammatory and infectious diseases, including sepsis. Completion of the research will produce critical insights into the non-canonical inflammasome signaling, and open a new avenue for developing therapeutic strategies against sepsis and other noncanonical inflammasome-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a serious public health problem, and current treatments do not address alcohol withdrawal symptoms (AW) and related stress pathophysiology that are associated with high relapse risk and treatment failure in AUD. The proposed research will enroll the more severe subgroup of AUD+AW and test the efficacy of Prazosin in a 12-week randomized controlled trial for improving alcohol use outcomes, other psychological and physical health functioning and patient related outcomes. Positive findings will support the use of Prazosin to reduce heavy drinking outcomes and improve functioning among individuals with AUD and alcohol withdrawal and related stress pathophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This study will address major gaps in knowledge regarding the respiratory health risks of e- cigarette use, which is increasingly common in young adults. It will test robust biological hypotheses regarding e-cigarettes and subclinical lung disease using innovative imaging measures developed and applied by the investigative team; moreover, it will examine the role of metal exposure, an established pulmonary toxin, in e-cigarette-related lung injury. The results will be suitable to help inform public health campaigns and regulatory decisions regarding e- cigarettes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Visual impairment is a terrifying prospect. PHR: RELEVANCE Survival rates for many childhood and adolescent cancers have improved at a remarkable pace over the past five decades. The CCSS cohort has been the source of some of the most significant publications to date addressing the long-term mortality, morbidity and quality of life of survivors of childhood cancer. Understanding the risk for late effects of childhood cancer and its therapy provides the basis for health screening recommendations and interventions that can mitigate long-term health problems in this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite RAS proteins being frequently mutated in human cancers (~25%), efforts to develop targeted therapies against RAS proteins have been largely unsuccessful until recently (06/21) when FDA approved the first drug to shut down the activity of a cysteine-containing oncogenic mutant of RAS that is prevalent in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer. This is the first in a rapidly expanding set of related inhibitors under development, which take advantage of the reactivity of cysteine (C12 in the case of KRAS G12C) to permanently attach drugs to target proteins. We propose studies to investigate the underlying mechanism of RAS inactivation by these inhibitors and how oxidation modulated by the tumor environment may impact the response to treatment by taking a comprehensive bench-to-bedside approach based on novel approaches and high-end technologies.

PHR: Narrative Because its volume is reduced in most psychiatric disorders (Goodkind et al. 2015; Downar et al. 2016), the insula has emerged as a promising target for therapeutic interventions, particularly those involving transcranial or deep brain stimulation. However, progress in this field has been hindered by the lack of high- resolution physiological data about insula signaling. The experiments we propose will shed light on the coding properties and role of insula neurons, thereby facilitating the development of novel therapies.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: The overarching objective of this project is to establish in the US, for the first time, the technologies required to genetically engineer laboratory opossums (which are born at the developmental stage of a 6-week human embryo) for the purpose of answering critical biomedical questions that cannot be answered by research with other laboratory animals. One of the first genetically engineered opossums will be deficient in a gene (Pten) believed, when deficient, to predispose to Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). Key outcomes of the project will be to enable establishment of a new animal model for research on ASD, and to make gene editing technology accessible to investigators from other US institutions for novel research with genetically engineered laboratory opossums.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/ PROJECT NARRATIVE The next and exciting phase of HIV prevention worldwide will involve the use of long‐acting injectable agents: cabotegravir has been approved as a shot every 8 weeks for PrEP (with the WHO expanding its use in July 2022 worldwide) and lenacapavir is being evaluated as an injection every 6 months to prevent HIV in order to make pre‐exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) easier and more widely available. Our laboratory has been studying the use of small hair samples and urine metrics to monitor for PrEP exposure for many years and this application will monitor cabotegravir and lenacapavir exposure in hair samples in important long‐acting PrEP demonstration projects in East Africa, Botswana with breastfeeding mothers, and with lenacapavir in two major trials. Our goal with this application is to minimize failures or “breakthroughs” on these new PrEP agents and find easy‐to‐ collect‐and‐store methods of evaluating exposure and optimizing the success of long‐acting PrEP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Eosinophilic gastrointestinal diseases (EGIDs) of the upper GI tract are predominantly food-triggered chronic eosinophilic disorders with significant impact on quality of life and predictive, non-invasive diagnostic testing and treatments are sorely lacking. This proposal aims to expand and deepen our knowledge of two types of immune cells, namely eosinophils and specialized T cells, in EGID pathogenesis in a cohort of well- characterized EGID patients. The knowledge gained will ultimately impact patient care by improving diagnostics, providing biomarkers for monitoring disease activity and identifying potential targets for novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This K01 Mentored Research Scientist Career Development Award aims to understand how young adults’ (age 18-25) social media use affects their nicotine vaping and to identify intervention targets that mitigate social media’s impact on vaping. A two-arm randomized controlled trial (incentivized reduction in social media use vs. social media use as usual) will examine potential mechanisms of relationships between social media use and vaping behavior; focus groups will explore intervention strategies for reducing young adults’ social media use and vaping and improving their mental health. Results will inform a future digital intervention targeting social media use and vaping, and may have regulatory implications for controlling the spread of vaping-related content on social media.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Projective Narrative Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related forms of dementia are a major public health concern. The goal of the proposed studies is to examine the mechanism and consequences of AD pathology in chimpanzees, the only other living species that naturally develops this disease. Identifying similarities and differences between human and chimpanzee AD may provide important information on the factors that contribute to the profound loss in cognitive functions in human AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Mosquitoes infected with the natural bacterium Wolbachia are currently released worldwide to curb the transmission of Zika and dengue viruses. Wolbachia rapidly spread through host populations by manipulating sexual reproduction to enhance their own maternal transmission. This research will evaluate the initial modifications to sexual reproduction that ultimately enable Wolbachia to spread, self-sustain at high frequencies, and protect local communities from mosquito-borne diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Dominance plays a vital role in human evolutionary genetics both in terms of its fitness effect on functional genomic variants and how it shapes complex trait phenotypes, while its distribution on the human genome and biological effects on complex traits are poorly characterized. This work will fill a critical knowledge gap by producing a complete picture of dominance distribution in humans, which will shed a light into many unsolved questions in genetics, including the evolution of dominance. This work will further provide comprehensive statistical frameworks to model the relationship between dominance and complex trait phenotypes, which will substantially improve the transferability of biomedical applications in historically understudied populations, including disease risk prediction and the development of precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physical activity reduces the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD), the leading cause of death in the US and globally. However, while we know a great deal about how much aerobic exercise (e.g., walking, jogging) to prescribe in order to reduce CVD risk, we know far less about how much resistance exercise (e.g., weight lifting) to prescribe. This proposed project will add important knowledge by (i) testing the effects of different doses of resistance exercise on CVD risk factors in a clinical trial among adults with overweight or obesity, (ii) exploring possible biologic mechanisms linking resistance exercise to CVD risk, and (iii) identifying which dose(s) of resistance exercise is (are) associated with best compliance, after trial intervention, in a free-living environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative and Relevance to Public Health Insecticides are ubiquitous in our environment and the general population is exposed through commercial use and the consumption of fruits and vegetables. Adolescent brain development is a sensitive process influenced by pubertal hormones during which exposures impact neurobehavioral functioning, including exposures to insecticides in occupational and other settings. The research proposed here will advance our understanding of the mechanisms and moderators of these effects by studying both adolescents occupationally exposed to insecticides through working in agriculture and a translational mouse model of this exposure to examine brain mechanisms, which are the first steps to accelerate translation of scientific research into meaningful improvements in human health, optimizing insecticide exposure policies, and developing interventions to protect the brain health of youth.
