IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diseases that affect lipid metabolism cause growth inhibition; however, the mechanism remains unknown due to the lack of knowledge about lipid metabolism in the growth plate. In this proposal, we will use unique transgenic mouse models that can inhibit the use of lipids in the growth plate to comprehensively determine whether the growth plate uses lipids for energy production. The outcome of this proposal will advance our understanding of growth plate metabolism, which will lead to the elucidation of mechanisms underlying growth failure in lipid metabolism disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Special gut proteins called proteases can harm intestinal function in patients with post-infection irritable bowel syndrome (PI-IBS). We have discovered that specific healthy microbes in the gut suppress proteases. We will conduct a randomized, controlled trial of fecal microbiota transplantation to determine efficacy in improving PI- IBS symptoms as well as integrity of gut lining and metabolites produced in the gastrointestinal tract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Non-polio enteroviruses (NPEVs) including enterovirus A71, D68, and CV-B3 have caused 10 to 15 million infections and tens of thousands of hospitalizations in the U.S. However, there is a lack of antiviral for the prevention and treatment of these viral infections. In this proposal, we aim to develop orally bioavailable broad- spectrum NPEV antivirals by targeting the viral 2C protein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Anticancer drug resistance often results from cancer cells bypassing the targeted pathway by adopting alternative mechanisms to maintain their growth. We have identified hnRNP A18 as a key regulator of several cellular pathways controlling cancer growth and immune protection. Using structural biology, Computer Aided Drug Design, medicinal chemistry and cellular biology we are developing small molecules that can selectively inhibit hnRNP A18 to prevent cancer cells growth and immune evasion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The intestinal epithelium, constantly exposed to environmental toxins, chemicals, or pathogens, is continually being regenerated and replaced through the proliferation and differentiation of intestinal stem cells and impaired regenerative process, particularly in response to injury, may result in chronic inflammation and disease states such as inflammatory bowel disease. Recent studies have identified a matricellular protein CCN1 as a powerful endogenous regulator that coordinately regulates complex cellular processes in various cell types for intestinal injury repair and regeneration, and this proposal seeks to elucidate its molecular mechanism of action. We anticipate that results from these studies will yield new insights into epithelial cell dedifferentiation into stem cells and stromal cell senescence during repair, and prompt new therapeutic strategies for promoting intestinal injury repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-associated degradation (ERAD) is the principal ER quality control machinery responsible for the clearance of misfolded ER proteins for cytosolic proteasomal degradation. Our recent studies have revealed a key role of the most conserved SEL1L-HRD1 complex of ERAD in coordinating the activity of another quality control machinery known as ER-phagy to control the maturation and fate of nascent lipoprotein lipase (LPL) in adipocytes; however, the underlying molecular mechanism remains vague. This study will test an exciting hypothesis that SEL1L-HRD1 ERAD regulates ER-phagy activity via ER-phagy receptor CCPG1 to maintain ER homeostasis and ensure the maturation of secreted proteins such as LPL in adipocytes.

PHR: This application aims to create robust computational tools for analyzing messy observational data on postoperative pain (POP). These methods will enhance the precision of POP phenotype predictions to achieve timely POP control and reduce the risk of opioid overuse. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative Every year, over half a million Americans suffer from large-gap peripheral nerve injuries that require surgical treatments with neural grafts or engineered graft substitutes, but these treatments suffer from limited availability and efficacy. Our objective is to address these issues by developing novel ionically conductive biodegradable scaffolds for reliable electrical and chemical stimulation to enhance the regeneration of large-gap nerve injuries. By bridging the knowledge gap between how chemical and electrical stimulation influence cell-material interactions and poorly studied nerve regeneration pathways, this project has the potential to significantly enhance large-gap nerve regeneration and functional recovery, ultimately benefitting patients suffering from peripheral nerve injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This NIH Commercial Readiness Pilot (CRP) project seeks to commercialize a novel product for mosquito control, the first and most critical step in controlling outbreaks of malaria and other mosquito-borne diseases such as West Nile virus, dengue and Zika: SPLAT BAC Plus, a safe, long-lasting larvicide that combines three reduced-risk larval killing agents with attractants for both adult female mosquitoes (inducing preferential egg laying at treated sites) and larval mosquitoes (encouraging feeding on the formulation). Larval control is an effective long-term solution to control mosquito populations, a critical component of vectorial capacity, but use of this tactic is currently hampered by shortcomings in available larvicide products, such as a problematically short field-life and the need to apply quickly after flooding, and by a critical shortage in larvicide active ingredients, particularly after the phase-out of the organophosphate temephos left only four biological modes of action available. By adding an attract-and-kill capacity and incorporating multiple larvicidal AIs into a controlled-release matrix to enable preemptive application, extend their field life, and ensure continued buoyancy and prevent sedimentation, SPLAT BAC Plus will address these limitations in previous larvicides and help to diversify mosquito control programs around the world, which currently rely predominantly on very few chemicals and interventions, leaving them vulnerable to the development of resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: We are optimizing to 1st Preclinical Candidate a class of catechol conjugated β -lactamase inhibitors (CC-BLI) that protect and potentiate β-lactams against Multidrug-Resistant (MDR) Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The compounds will be paired ultimately with ceftolozane, which best supports the potent antibacterial activity, and advanced through Non-GLP toxicology and eventually through IND-enabling activities. The intravenously administered combination would represent a powerful new treatment option against the most problematic, MDR pathogens in the hospital setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A new method of editing the human genome called CRISPR has the potential to treat the hundreds of millions of people with a genetic health condition by allowing defective sequences in their DNA to be overwritten with DNA having corrected sequence. New evidence indicates this editing process is more efficient and less toxic if the corrected DNA is first stitched into a compact package using smaller DNA fragments. In this project, we will develop software that automatically determines the set of DNA fragments, which are unique to each editing situation, that are needed to create such compact packages for the purpose of devising improved genome editing therapies.

Our platform can provide a platform for cell therapy manufactures to isolate highly specific cell populations to develop more potent therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The goal of this project is to scale analytics for large image volumes and thereby accelerate discovery of new biological principles, and remove barriers to communicate and receive this information. We propose to leverage virtual reality to change the way users interact with their data, by providing cutting-edge machine learning methods interpolated with rapid error correction. We propose also that virtual reality can underlie a new mode of interaction among scientific colleagues around 3D/4D data sets, and permit them to make the full extent of their discoveries accessible to experts and non- experts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Disorders of gastric function impact >10% of the US population, but remain poorly understood, with a pressing need for new diagnostic tests to better define these diseases. We will translate a new clinical tool for non-invasively assessing gastric dysfunction called “Body Surface Gastric Mapping”, which applies flexible skin electrodes to spatially map underlying patterns of gastric electrical activity. We will apply this promising new diagnostic tool in large clinical studies to define how gastric electrical abnormalities impact disease, and to validate this new diagnostic approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Reading the sequence and detecting the diversity of chemical modifications in RNA molecules would be a huge step forward for understanding the biology and disease-causing events in human cells. However, methods that can directly read single molecules are lacking, prompting us to develop an ultra-sensitive technology that directly reads RNA molecules, one at a time, at low-cost and with high throughput. Our method will an array of nanometer scale devices in which individual enzymes replicate RNA and report on the RNA sequence and presence of modifications, all from minute amounts that are equivalent to the number of RNA molecules in a single human cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite clinical evidence of craniofacial suture defects resulting in craniosynostosis during prenatal ZIKV infection, yet the etiology remains an enigma and is currently unexplored. Herein, the goal of this proposal is to investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying ZIKV-induced cranial suture fusion that results in craniofacial anomalies. The insights gained will serve as a preclinical platform for development of therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Glaucoma is a common group of age-related neurodegenerative diseases characterized by loss of retinal ganglion cells and their axons that carry information from the eye to the brain. Over 127 genetic risk factors for glaucoma have been mapped to specific places in the genome, however, basic features of these loci (i.e., the causative genes/mutations in each locus and how they affect gene activity) have not been defined, which is an obstacle to targeting them for therapies. Our proposed studies will use a complementary set of human, mouse, and molecular approaches to characterize the important features of three glaucoma risk factor loci by 1) determining the glaucoma-causing gene in each locus, 2) determining the specific DNA variants in the glaucoma-causing genes that confer risk for disease, and 3) determining how these variants alter gene expression and biological pathways that contribute to glaucoma pathogenesis to facilitate development of new sight-saving glaucoma therapies.
PI_NAMEs: ANDERSON, MICHAEL G (contact);FINGERT, JOHN H;SCHEETZ, TODD E

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: The number of NAFLD patients is projected to increase from 83.1 million (2015) to 100.9 million (2030), of whom ~27% will have NASH, however, there are no approved drugs for treating NASH. IP6K1 belongs to inositol phosphate kinase family and its expression directly correlates with NASH and cirrhosis in humans. Our preliminary data suggest that agents targeting IP6K1 may provide a novel treatment for NAFLD/NASH, therefore, the studies described here aim to develop potent and selective IP6K1 inhibitors suitable for clinical application and as such, may have a direct impact on outcomes and/or quality of life for patients with NAFLD/NASH.

In this project, we propose to develop imaging biomarkers to predict treatment response and prognosis of patients with rectal cancer. Success of our research may help guide surgery and identify the most effective treatment for an individual patient, which will improve quality of life and patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite great efforts to target mTORC1 in cancer, adverse effects related to the multiplicity of mTORC1- regulated substrates limit the use of mTORC1 inhibitors in the clinic. Recent cryo-EM work from our lab revealed the structural basis of substrate-specific regulatory pathways that could be targeted with greater precision than heretofore. We will determine how regulation of canonical and non-canonical mTORC1 substrates differs, and reveal the structural basis of mTORC1 regulation by the still largely mysterious mechanisms of the GATOR and KICSTOR complexes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Increased urinary excretion of oxalate is linked with calcium oxalate kidney stones and may originate from the diet or endogenous metabolism. The goal of this project is to determine if, and how, endogenous oxalate synthesis and gut absorption of dietary oxalate are increased in idiopathic calcium oxalate kidney stone formers and if colonization with the gut bacteria Oxalobacter formigenes can reduce urinary oxalate excretion in this population. The results of the study will guide further investigations on the causes of calcium oxalate kidney stones and lead to the development of targeted therapeutic approaches for reducing calcium oxalate kidney stone risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Asian Americans comprise 6% of the U.S. population and represent the fastest growing population group in U.S. The incidence of mild cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s Disease is higher among racial/ethnic minorities, especially in first generation immigrants. Yet, there are few epidemiological and biological studies of Alzheimer’s disease and dementia in immigrant populations such as Indian Americans. In this first of its kind study, we propose to clinically and biologically phenotype 400 older first-generation immigrants from the southern Indian state of Kerala residing in the tri-state area (New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut) to better understand risk and protection against cognitive decline and dementia in this fast-growing U.S. population segment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We live in a rapidly aging society and in the United States, the population of individuals over the age of 65 is expected to reach 90 million people by 2050. Approximately 40% of elderly people consume alcohol which is associated with accelerated cognitive decline. To goal of this project is to identify specific perturbations in host innate immunity, including regulatory microRNAs, caused by alcohol misuse during aging, to provide a foundation for future clinical interventions to prevent neuroinflammation and early onset dementia in patients of all ages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative A critical need is to understand the mechanisms by which alcohol regulates sleep behavior. We uncovered a novel pathway by which norepinephrine engages wake-active dopamine neurons in the ventral periaqueductal gray (vPAG) to produce arousal. In this project we will explore the mechanisms through which ethanol regulates this vPAG signaling pathway, and its role in alcohol-dependent alterations in sleep.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The human brain is comprised of heterogenous cell types, and understanding the gene expression patterns and chromatin states within each of these cell types will provide important insights into many cognitive disorders. The proposed studies will profile cell types in understudied regions of human and non-human primate brain. The resultant data will contribute to human and non-human primate cell type atlases, as well as identify molecular signatures that distinguish humans from closely related species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early life exposures to endocrine disrupting chemicals, such as bisphenols and phthalates, can increase the lifetime risk of developing non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) – a disease that is being increasingly diagnosed in children. Bisphenols and phthalates have been shown to trigger release of Damage Associated Molecular Pattern (DAMP) proteins that promote oxidative, inflammatory, and metabolic stress through activation of receptor for advanced glycation end products (RAGE) signaling and epigenomic reprogramming. Our proposed studies will test the hypothesis that exposure to a bisphenol/phthalate mixture activates DAMP/RAGE signaling, alters the epigenomic/transcriptomic landscape in liver and peripheral monocytes, and promotes metabolic dysfunction upon later life challenge (e.g., Western diet).

PHR: Project Narrative Genetic variants in TREM2, an immune receptor on microglial cells, are associated with a spectrum of neurodegenerative conditions, including Alzheimer’s disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Intestinal disorders such as inflammatory bowel disease, celiac disease and infectious colitis represent a serious health problem in the US with their incidence and complications accelerating over the past decades. This project will improve upon the understanding of normal gut physiology and the pathogenesis of gastrointestinal disorders by exploring novel mechanisms that regulate integrity of the gut barrier, development of intestinal inflammation and post-inflammatory mucosal restitution. Furthermore, it will identify a novel target for pharmacological prevention of the intestinal barrier breakdown and accelerated healing of the injured gut mucosa, which would result in decreased morbidity and mortality of a large cohort of patients with inflammatory disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative During embryonic development of the pulmonary alveolus, a common progenitor pool gives rise to two distinct epithelial cell types in a process requiring both molecular signaling and cell stretch. As both cues exist several days before the epithelial cells are specified, another mechanism is required to time differentiation. We propose a hypothesis ––and our data strongly support–– that timing is controlled by a novel mechanical property named cell membrane tension; if true, this hypothesis will update the model of differentiation of the alveolar epithelium and have fundamental implications for understanding its regulation in lung disease and regeneration, both which we begin to investigate in this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Coronaviruses such as SARS-CoV-2 originate in animals and transmit to humans. New coronaviruses are discovered and sequenced from wildlife frequently, but, without effective laboratory tools to study these viruses, little is known about the zoonotic risk they pose to humans. We have developed several laboratory-based platforms to characterize the cell entry for hundreds of betacoronaviruses and propose to use these tools to annotate the ever-growing virome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  The application proposes a series of hands-on workshops focused on cognitive hearing (a.k.a. CogHear) that will advance the state-of-the-art readouts of mental states of listeners and their impact in advancing technologies and controlling hearing prosthetics as well as shaping the listening experience in everyday complex soundscapes. The workshops are organized around multidisciplinary groups of researchers spanning hearing, brain and cognitive scientists alongside data scientists and engineers. Groups will work in collaborative teams to explore scientific questions, pilot ideas, compare methodologies and brainstorm on new directions of research in the field in close partnership with industry stakeholders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative A major diagnostic feature of alcohol use disorder is compulsive alcohol use despite negative consequences. Our goal is to determine the brain mechanisms that drive compulsive drinking after long-term exposure to alcohol. Here we examine how alcohol exposure alters recruitment of a brain pathway that is normally involved in constraining reward-seeking behavior in the face of negative consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The efficacy of cancer immunotherapy is dependent upon the generation of robust anti-tumor T effector cells. Novel strategies are needed to enhance the metabolic fitness of T cells at the level of precise biochemical reaction, molecular interactions, amenable to pharmacologic manipulation. We postulate that the bioavailability and the biosynthetic process of asparagine determines T cell robustness and anti-tumor function. This proposal will enable us to develop novel metabolic modulations on anti-tumor T effector cells to improve the efficacy and broaden the therapeutic horizons of immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The term “Satisfaction of Search” (SOS) refers to the phenomenon that one or more lesions are missed after a first lesion has been reported in an image, and SOS is responsible for up to 30% of all misses in the domains where it has been studied, such as chest radiology. However, SOS has never been studied in breast imaging, despite breast cancer being the most common type of cancer among women worldwide. In this project we will study SOS in full-field digital mammography (FFDM, a 2d image) and in Digital Breast Tomosynthesis (DBT, a pseudo-3d image), and determine the rate of these errors and their underlying causes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID) is a serious mental and physical health condition which poses major public health problems due to severe impacts on growth, nutritional status, and psychosocial functioning. Although mechanisms that maintain problematic eating behaviors in ARFID are largely unknown, emotion dysregulation is common in eating disorders and our team’s newly developed cognitive-behavioral model of ARFID suggests that avoidant/restrictive eating is negatively reinforced via reductions in negative affect. The proposed multi-disciplinary study aims to determine the role of negative emotions in the maintenance of ARFID symptoms by first comparing activation in brain regions involved in emotion processing and key hormones related to emotional functioning between adults with ARFID and healthy adults, and second integrating real- time reports of negative emotions and avoidant/restrictive eating behaviors with neural circuitry and affect- related hormones to empirically evaluate the cognitive-behavioral model of ARFID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary care physicians are the gateway to reaching adult smokers but need resources to deliver evidence- based cessation treatment uniformly to all. The widespread adoption of Electronic Health Record (EHR) systems with coded smoking status data offers a ripe opportunity to proactively provide treatment. The present research project will test the clinical effectiveness and evaluate implementation of an asynchronous smoking cessation electronic visit that will be delivered proactively via the EHR to all adult smokers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) exhibit altered lipid metabolism to support rapid tumor growth and proliferation; thus, targeting lipid metabolism is a promising therapeutic strategy for GBM patients. Herein we propose to investigate how specific genetic alterations in GBM rewire lipid metabolism to expose new therapeutic vulnerabilities for ferroptosis- a lipid peroxidation-dependent form of cell death. The results obtained from this proposal could pave the way for novel therapeutic approaches to target lipid metabolism and promote ferroptosis within genetically-defined subsets of GBM tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Black women living with HIV (BWLWH; 40% unsuppressed) are marginalized and understudied, in the U.S. in general and in Miami, FL, a southern HIV epicenter. Our 1-year R56, occurring during the time of heighten visibility on racism in the U.S. and COVID-19, has further demonstrated the importance of longitudinally studying the unique role of microaggressions and frequent adversities (e.g. violence/trauma) in relation to HIV viral suppression among BWLWH. Our proposed study will allow for continued longitudinal data collection, and directly generate community-informed interventions to improve viral suppression among BWLWH; thereby helping us to move closer to Zero Infections, Zero Discrimination, and Zero AIDS-Related Deaths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A rotator cuff tendon tear affects up to 64% of adults, resulting in muscular changes that drive functional disability and poor clinical outcomes, but little is known about the mechanisms driving poor function. The purpose of this study is to identify the structure-function associations of muscle and how they change over time after rotator cuff tear and surgical repair using an established rabbit model, and to develop a predictive model to further probe the mechanisms driving biomechanical function. Outcomes of this work will establish the structure-function associations of muscle after rotator cuff tear and expose the mechanisms and time points after injury that should be targeted by treatments to improve function for patients with a rotator cuff tear.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Overall Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are environmental contaminants of emerging concern because they are detected ubiquitously in our environment, yet there is little known about their toxicity, bioaccumulation, or effective remediation strategies. This proposed Center for Environmental and Health Effects of PFAS will integrate a cross-institutional team of leaders in the fields of environmental epidemiology, environmental science and engineering, toxicology, analytical chemistry, data science, and community engagement to address outstanding questions about PFAS exposure and human health in North Carolina and throughout the US. This Center is strongly aligned with the mandates of the Superfund Research Program and aims to couple integrative discovery-based research with community-driven needs to protect the public against unnecessary environmental health risks associated with PFAS exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women show a heightened risk for psychosis in midlife that is not observed in men. The menopausal transition, and its corresponding changes in estrogen and progesterone, may drive these differences in risk, yet data exploring these effects are wholly lacking. Isolating perimenopause as a critical risk period for psychosis and elucidating ovarian hormone mechanisms will substanatially increase understanding of disease susceptiblity and help identify novel targets for prevention and intervention efforts aimed at improving women's health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  (Biomedical Research) Research Project 1  Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are common drinking water contaminants in North Carolina, but  little is known about how long these chemicals stay in the body or what the human health impacts are. We  will study how PFAS levels change over time and how they are associated with thyroid disease. These  results will be useful for other communities and Superfund sites impacted by PFAS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is a highly prevalent syndrome and a major source of morbidity, mortality, and health care expenditures around the world. This proposal aims to elucidate mechanisms underlying HFpEF, focusing on mitochondrial function and metabolic changes. Studies proposed here will provide important insights into the pathogenesis of HFpEF and reveal potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Currently, there is no licensed vaccine in the US to prevent disease caused by Neisseria meningitidis serogroup B strains in less than 10 year olds, the age group at greatest risk of disease, and no licensed vaccine to prevent disease caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Ng), which causes tens of millions of sexually transmitted infections annually. In addition, multiple antibiotic resistance has made Ng an urgent public health threat. We propose to develop a native outer membrane vesicle vaccine from Nm with over-produced Nm and Ng antigens that provides protection against disease caused by both pathogens in all age groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE (Biomedical Research) Research Project 2 Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are environmental contaminants of emerging concern resulting from point source (e.g., industrial and wastewater effluent) and non-point source (e.g., run-off and atmospheric deposition) inputs. Health effects observed in humans exposed to PFAS include cancer, liver toxicity, reproductive and developmental toxicity, and immunotoxicity; this project will explore molecular mechanisms underlying PFAS-induced immunotoxicity in animal models as well as human cell lines. Our goal is to identify impacted signaling pathways and networks that will accelerate development of immune therapies for affected individuals, inform appropriate regulatory measures, and facilitate novel, immune mechanism-based prioritization strategies for PFAS recently detected in North Carolina and elsewhere.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 77,200 Americans will be diagnosed with non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma in 2020 and fewer than half will be cured with conventional treatments. Lymphomas are exquisitely sensitive to radiation and radiolabeled monoclonal antibodies can be very effective at inducing remission in most lymphoma patients, but the disease frequently recurs. This grant proposal describes the development of several innovations that combine radiolabeled antibodies with each other, or with other drugs, to prevent relapse by comprehensively eliminating every lymphoma cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) is progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the extracellular accumulation of amyloid β (Aβ) deposits and the formation of intracellular tau-containing neurofibrillary tangles in the brain. This proposal aims to develop the near-infrared optical probes and instrumentation that will enable, for the first time the non-invasive monitoring of the dynamics of these pathological protein aggregates in AD mouse models with cellular resolution. The developed tools and techniques will represent a significant advance in our ability to assess therapeutic strategies when conducting preclinical mouse studies in AD.

PHR: Project Narrative This is a new application for a training program supporting predoctoral trainees in biomedical research at the University of New Mexico Health Sciences Center. Program strengths include a recruitment strategy targeted at multiple underrepresented minority (URM) serving institutions in New Mexico and the Southwest region, the formation of Learning Communities to support special needs of URM trainees and career training in non-academic research areas. These strengths will enhance retention and increase potential careers paths open to IMSD trainees, preparing highly skilled biomedical scientists from backgrounds underrepresented in biomedical research to increase workforce diversity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  (Environmental Science and Engineering) Research Project 4  Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are environmental contaminants of emerging concern, and  effective PFAS remediation technologies are needed for a wide range of applications. This project will describe  mechanisms of PFAS sorption to granular activated carbon (GAC). Results of this project will contribute to  lower remediation costs, safer management of spent GAC, and cleaner drinking water, which will ultimately  reduce human exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chlamydia is a major cause of sexually transmitted infections in the U.S., and more chlamydial infections are reported to the CDC each year than all other infectious diseases combined. This project will study how conversion between the dividing and infectious forms of chlamydiae is controlled by chlamydial size as an intrinsic signal for conversion, or by alternative mechanisms that utilize extrinsic signals provided by the inclusion membrane or the chlamydial population within an infected cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injury (TBI) remains a public health concern, the consequences of which can lead to long-lasting disability and cognitive dysfunction. Inflammation after TBI can serve both beneficial and detrimental roles, with uncontrolled inflammation profoundly influencing neuronal survival and outcome. The present proposal will investigate the role of the neuropeptide CART (cocaine and amphetamine regulated transcript) in the regulation of inflammation after TBI, and if this neuropeptide can be used to reduce TBI pathophysiology and improve cognitive outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Effectively tackling the many complex factors that influence human health and disease requires the mobilization of the broadest talent base, comprised of individuals with different backgrounds, perspectives and talents. Yet, despite advances over the last few decades, the diversity of biomedical workforce does not reflect the broader population and therefore fails to tap into vast resources of available talent. The proposed training program seeks, in its small measure, to alleviate that lack of diversity by providing academic, research, professional development and networking activities that spur the recruitment, retention and excellence of individuals from backgrounds traditionally underrepresented in the biomedical sciences, and by so doing, improve the health of the population of the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Cancers use two different types of transporters to take up the glucose they need to grow: SGLT2 and GLUT1; we found that early-stage lung cancers use SGLT2, while more advanced lesions switch to GLUT1. We are going to investigate the metabolic function of the switch between SGLT2 and GLUT1, and the mechanisms by which the cells can induce this switch. This is relevant because metabolic inhibition is at the basis of novel targeted therapies for lung cancer, but the switch from one transporter to the other represents a strategy of cancer cells to develop resistance to therapy, which needs to be addressed in order to improve patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol misuse and related risky sexual behavior are significant public health concerns among college students. This project involves (1) adapting and evaluating a technology-delivered behavioral intervention that is designed to reduce alcohol misuse and related risky sexual behavior among first-year college students while also (2) examining factors important to intervention implementation in college settings. If effective, the intervention may be widely disseminated and has the potential to make a positive impact on college student health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative With nearly 40,000 children suffering from Dravet Syndrome in desperate need of more effective therapies, and families moving to Colorado based almost on a blind hope for a new treatment, our proposal is squarely focused on a timely and significant unmet need in the pediatric epilepsy community. Combining multiple levels of analysis across several zebrafish models of DS, this proposal aims to provide new insights and treatment for this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Over the last decade the incidence of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) and recurrent CDI have increased, thought in part to be due to a loss of key commensal species that provide key bile transforming activities. Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) are at particularly high risk for recurrent CDI, though the mechanism remains unclear given that CDI studies notably lack IBD patients, a challenging population due to baseline diarrhea. Given the deleterious effect of CDI on patients with IBD, there is an urgent need to understand mechanisms of recurrent CDI in patients with IBD to better risk stratify them utilizing mechanistic data to promptly identify high risk patients and offer appropriate treatments earlier, thus preventing severe complications, improving symptom burden and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer arises by escaping multiple checkpoint controls. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The only curative therapies for either MDS or AML is allogeneic stem cell transplantation, however few patients are eligible, which underpins the need to resolve the cellular and molecular basis of genetically-defined subtypes of MDS and AML with the goal of developing novel therapies. We identified that TIFAB, a commonly deleted gene in del(5q) MDS/AML and modifier of innate immune signaling, affects the function of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells in response to selective pressures and stressors converging on p53, by regulating the deubiquitinase function of USP15. The overarching significance of this proposal is two-fold: (1) we will uncover the mechanism of transformation from MDS to AML and provide the basis for development of therapies to prevent disease progression; and (2) we will characterize USP15 as a novel regulator and potential therapeutic target in the pathogenesis of AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a common cause of mortality during critical illness. There are no pharmacological therapies for ARDS that address the underlying mechanism of the disease. The purpose of this research is to investigate the role of the receptor for advanced glycation endproducts (RAGE) axis in conferring risk for ARDS and to operationalize the RAGE axis to enrich clinical trials of RAGE-based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section Genetically-encoded, fluorescent sensors for reactive oxygen species (ROS) provide tremendous potential for studying oxidative stress in real-time, but their low fidelity does currently not allow for prolonged large scale studies in relevant disease models. We aim to significantly accelerate the engineering of ROS sensor proteins by combining structure-guided design with a novel high-throughput platform enabling the functional testing of large variant libraries at high-speed. The fast engineering of fully applicable ROS sensors will allow biomedical researchers to precisely detect the timing and location of oxidative stress caused by environmental stress and genetic disposition, and hence, could guide future research on disease mechanisms, facilitate drug screening, and help to identify novel therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Schafer, Dorothy P. Project Narrative While multiple sclerosis (MS) is an inflammatory demyelinating disease, it is now becoming increasingly appreciated that there is extensive neurodegeneration, which is currently an unmet clinical need. One common feature of neurodegeneration in MS, as well as many other neurodegenerative diseases (Alzheimer’s disease, frontotemporal dementia, etc.), is early loss of synaptic connections. We will now shed new mechanistic light on how synapses are lost in the MS brain and, in the process, identify new strategies for neuroprotection in MS and other neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a chronic form of interstitial lung disease in adults with few therapies that leads to chronic respiratory failure with a high mortality rate. I propose to determine lower plasma phospholipid levels of omega-3 fatty acids and their metabolites as a modifiable risk factor in adults with IPF. By achieving the aims of my proposal, this may lead to clinical trials of therapies that raise omega-3 fatty acid levels for the treatment of IPF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in CSF3R are associated with poor prognosis in Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML), a lethal blood cancer. In AML, CSF3R mutations are accompanied by mutations in transcription factors that block CSF3R-driven differentiation to cause an aggressive malignancy. The goal of this proposal is to uncover how these partner mutations inhibit CSF3R-driven differentiation, with the long-term goal of harnessing this molecular understanding to enable new therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Despite the important role of the tumor stroma in cancer progression, the majority of anticancer therapies target cancer cells and not the tumor microenvironment. Here we propose to develop a targeted, protein-based therapeutic platform designed to convert tumor-promoting macrophages to suppress tumorigenesis. This new delivery platform could improve therapeutic outcomes in cancer patients, particularly where tumor-associated macrophages are linked with poor clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative Ovarian cancer is a common and lethal malignancy that metastasizes early and is diagnosed late. Our preliminary observations suggest that a mitochondrial protein, sideroflexin 4, affects both the extent of DNA damage and the degree of DNA repair in ovarian cancer cells. Since both DNA damage and DNA repair affect the response of ovarian cancer to current anticancer chemotherapy, we will test the hypothesis that targeting sideroflexin 4 will enhance the effectiveness of platinum-based drugs and PARP inhibitors used in ovarian cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because young adult sexual minority women are disproportionately impacted by smoking-related health disparities, and research to identify effective and scalable counter-marketing approaches to reduce smoking among this priority population is limited. This research will be the first to determine the effects of inoculation with culturally-tailored counter-marketing messages to increase resistance to tobacco industry marketing, explore the impact of counter-marketing messages in relation to minority stress, resilience and social/environmental factors, and explore the mechanisms via emotions, beliefs and attitudes. This proposal directly addresses key scientific priorities in PAR-18-037 for research that leads to the development of acceptable and appropriate health interventions to ameliorate health disparities in SGM populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in the ABCA3 gene are the most common genetic cause of severe breathing problems among infants and children. As medical treatment options remain limited, affected patients may require lung transplantation for survival. We will use human lung cell lines to determine how specific ABCA3 mutations cause breathing problems and to discover FDA-approved medications to treat breathing problems in infants and children with ABCA3 mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Schistosomiasis is a tropical parasitic disease afflicting ~200 million people worldwide with therapy reliant on a single drug (praziquantel, PZQ) that displays several non-optimal features, including a lack of knowledge about how this drug works. We have recently identified the flatworm target of PZQ, a breakthrough that now permits a screening campaign for novel ligands and regulators of this target. Identification of novel small molecules that show both efficacy at this target and activity against parasitic flatworms ex vivo and in vivo provides a rigorous pipeline for the discovery of next generation anthelmintics, which are urgently needed in the clinic and field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Large scale proteomic analysis of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) patients has identified a connected network of proteins associated with AD. To determine whether the M4 protein network and its key hub proteins, including Plectin (Plec) modulates AD risk, this project will dissect Plec’s function in the nervous system and validate the protein network structure using cross-species analysis. My results will determine the function of a predicted AD target in the adult brain, its role in the protein network, and validate protein network structure with the goal of elucidating novel AD pathophysiological mechanisms and develop novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE STING agonists are a promising anticancer treatment currently being explored in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), a disease which is notoriously resistant to current therapies. A systematic metabolomic and proteomic proﬁling identiﬁed previously unappreciated consequences of STING activation in PDAC malignant cells, speciﬁcally the depletion of nucleotide pools and activation of the replication stress response pathway. This proposal will examine mechanistic underpinnings of these observations and will test rationally designed therapies with the goal of deﬁning new therapeutic options for PDAC for future clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite long-standing racial disparities in breast cancer outcomes, the underlying molecular mechanisms are poorly understood. In this study, we will investigate the causal link between race-dependent differences in DNA repair capacity and the outcome disparities of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), as well as test the chemo- sensitizing effect of VCP inhibition. Thus, the proposed project will help improve personalized treatment decisions for African American TNBC patients to improve their survival outcomes and reduce breast cancer disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Glioblastoma is a uniformly fatal brain cancer with poor response to treatment and high rates of recurrence. This proposal describes application of a tissue-engineered model of the interface between glioblastoma and its associated blood vessels for systematic characterization of the mechanisms by which blood vessels promote GBM cells to migrate away from primary tumors, eventually leading to tumor recurrence.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Heart failure as a result of congenital heart defects is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide and effective treatment options are greatly needed. Cell therapy has provided new avenues of treatment but much work still needs to be done, especially in the pediatric population. We propose that delivery of pre-conditioned human cardiac-derived c-kit+ progenitor cells will improve cardiac function in heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Phosphodiesterase (PDE6)- related retinopathies blind nearly 72,000 individuals worldwide, and there is currently no treatment available to stop disease progression. CRISPR-mediated gene editing, is a challenging clinical treatment option due to its gene- and mutation-specific guide RNA (gRNA) targeting requirements and delivery. We propose to address this problem by developing an efficacious strategy to treat cone degenerations, identify and optimize the CRISPR delivery method best suited for these conditions, and finally, enable treatment in a manner that is not mutation specific.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Developmental language impairments are pervasive in the general population, posing a substantial public health burden that could be mitigated by earlier identification and intervention. The proposed studies will longitudinally examine the development of the neural networks subserving native language processing throughout the first year of life to delineate patterns associated with both typical and delayed language acquisition. These findings will inform the identification of early biomarkers for language impairments – including those associated with Autism Spectrum Disorder – and pave the way for earlier diagnosis and interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative COVID-19 may have significant neurotropic impacts on multiple sensory functions, spanning smell, taste, chemesthesis, hearing, and balance. This research will extensively investigate and capture short-term and long-term COVID-associated multisensory dysfunctions, their recovery, and their relationship with patients’ disease profiles, which will enable more comprehensive understanding to better support future patient care and recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will be the first to apply a multi-dimensional framework of reward processing to determine how `liking', `wanting' or incentive salience, and instrumental learning is altered in anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa, is influenced by outcome valence (reward, punishment) and stimulus modality (taste, money), and corresponds to overlapping and divergent clinical symptoms at study entry and after one year. Advancing our understanding of dimensional constructs underlying symptom heterogeneity in eating disorders, and that predict symptom change over time, will improve diagnostic classification, identify novel therapeutic targets, and drive innovative treatment development for these often chronic and sometimes deadly disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative There is inconsistent evidence indicating that Bilingualism might increase Cognitive Reserve and or resilience (CR/R). We propose a multidisciplinary longitudinal study to compare Bilinguals and Monolinguals with amnestic Mild Cognitive Impairment from an equivalent cultural background in neuropsychological and neuroimaging data. Our findings will advance understanding of the complex interactions between neural, environmental, and sociocultural factors and the role of Bilingualism in CR/R in MCI, paving the way for new targets for interventions and providing fundamental insight into the role of language(s) in the aging brain.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: HARRY S. TRUMAN MEMORIAL VA HOSPITAL
PHR: Project Narrative: Coronary atherosclerosis, one of five top causes for cardiovascular hospitalization in U.S. Veterans, is a chronic progressive disease characterized by the thickening and hardening of arteries as a result of buildup of atherosclerotic plaques. In this application, a combination of molecular, cellular, and genetic approaches with gain-of- and loss-of- function studies will be utilized to establish novel mechanisms by which Olfactomedin 2 promotes the development and progression of atherosclerosis through mediating vascular smooth muscle foam cell formation and later apoptosis. The outcome of the project may lead to identification of new molecular targets for the prevention and therapy of atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Breast cancer (BC) is a leading cause of cancer related death in American women with higher rates of this disease observed in Veteran populations compared to nonveterans. With the rapid expansion in the number of women Veterans, more women from this group are expected to be diagnosed with BC with heightened needs for women’s health care anticipated. While BC death rates have declined with advances in detection and treatment, a large number of US women are still expected to die of BC. The RON receptor and its ligand, HGFL, are coordinately upregulated in human BCs and recent studies show that RON levels are predictive of metastasis and reduced overall survival. However, the mechanisms by which RON and HGFL contribute to more aggressive BC remain incompletely understood. This study will examine a newly discovered function of these proteins in disrupting innate signaling cascades and will evaluate the efficacy of blocking RON in combination with selective immunomodulatory approaches to combat BC mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic kidney diseases (CKD) are common, costly and a significant burden on patients and their families. While structural racism clearly contributes to the 4-fold excess prevalence of CKD in Black compared to white Americans, genetic variants in the APOL1 gene that are unique to some African ancestral populations explain part of the excess CKD risk. This project will define the pathways that translate the genetic association into disease and could identify novel targets for effective CKD treatments in this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The aim of the proposed research is to investigate the correlation between in vivo magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) measures of cellularity, blood flow and fat accumulation with the recently discovered molecular alterations in the angiogenic and lipogenic pathways that are associated to aggressive behavior in clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Quantitative measures of cellularity, blood flow and fat fraction will be obtained with diffusion weighted imaging (DWI), arterial spin labeling (ASL) and Dixon-based MRI techniques, respectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed project is to understand the visual functions of four poorly understood cell types in the primate retina and the mechanisms that underlie their contribution to human vision. We utilize a combination of techniques to accomplish this goal: multi-electrode recordings to study interactions between populations of cells, patch-clamp recordings to study neural circuit mechanisms, and confocal microscopy to study the anatomical structure of the cells; these techniques allow us to study retinal circuits from population coding to cellular and circuit structure. This research will advance our understanding of the functional properties of the primate retina in health and disease, and will contribute to the design of improved techniques for diagnosing and ameliorating visual dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diagnosis rates of familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) are low in the United States, despite multiple guidelines and recommendations for screening and treatment of high cholesterol, to prevent heart attacks in those affected. Using a stepped-wedge design, we plan to utilize tools from implementation science to improve uptake, acceptability, and sustainability of FH diagnostic programs in primary care settings. If successful, this study will provide tools generalizable to other health care systems to improve FH diagnosis rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With endovascular stroke therapy, we now have the ability to dramatically improve patient outcomes after stroke. To date, however, screening for patients that may benefit from this procedure has been relegated to larger academic centers, as the advanced imaging modalities required for this evaluation are not widely available. The goal of our proposal is to develop and validate machine learning-based software tools to identify patients eligible for endovascular stroke therapy using CT angiography, an imaging modality readily available in the vast majority of community hospitals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: At the core of heart failure is the inability of the adult human heart to regenerate after injury. In contrast to the adult human heart, lower vertebrates and neonatal mammals can regenerate their hearts efficiently. The currently proposal addresses the fundamentals of how oxygenation and mechanical load cooperatively regulate endogenous regeneration in mammalian hearts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need to both improve the quality of harmonized data for cross-national research on Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD), and better characterize the key drivers of cognitive health within and between populations. We will estimate the contributions of socioeconomic and cardiovascular ADRD risk factors to older adults’ cognitive health across countries, using statistically harmonized data from the Harmonized Cognitive Assessment Protocols (HCAP) in the US Health and Retirement Study (HRS) and its International Partner Studies (IPS) in South Africa, Mexico, India, and England. Our results will set the stage to identify intervention targets for high-risk individuals as well as whole populations, with the ultimate goal of preventing and/or delaying the onset of ADRD from a global perspective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The first few months of HIV infection are characterized by elevated infectiousness, resulting in a disproportionate contribution to population-level HIV spread. This project aims to increase understanding of epidemiological, spatial, and phylogenetic aspects of HIV transmission during early HIV infection, and to estimate the population-level impact of tailored interventions against transmission during this period. Findings will inform future HIV prevention strategies that recognize the importance of addressing early HIV infection in efforts to end the HIV epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Congenital heart disease affects 1% of all liveborn infants, and is the most common major birth defect. Cilia are antenna-like structures that extend from almost all cells to obtain and interpret information from the extracellular environment, and abnormal cilia are known to cause congenital heart disease. This proposal investigates how cilia instruct normal heart development, and how abnormal cilia can impact patients with CHD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Multiple myeloma (MM) is the second most common hematological cancer in the U.S and is increasing in frequency, especially among veterans. Although new treatments are available, MM remains incurable. We generated a human natural killer (NK) cell line NK3.3, that releases small membrane-bound extracellular vesicles (EVs) with strong tumor killing activity, without harming normal cells. They also kill drug-resistant and cancer stem cells which are responsible for disease recurrence. Our goal is to develop NK3.3 EVs as a new treatment for MM. We generated a murine xenograft model of minimal residual disease in MM to approximate a human clinical situation. This will be used to test the ability of NK3.3 EVs to prevent MM recurrence after chemotherapy. NK3.3-derived EVs may provide all the advantages of NK cell therapy without the challenges of expanding cells and side effects associated with cellular infusions. These studies are the first step towards providing another treatment option for MM patients to prolong their survival and improve their quality of life.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because there are no strategies to ameliorate the sensory ataxia associated with Angelman syndrome. The PIEZO2 mechanosensitive ion channel is a promising target for decreasing sensory ataxia since it mediates proprioception and balance. The proposed study is relevant to the NIH’s mission because it will provide the molecular basis for understanding the mechanism by which the lack of a ubiquitin-protein ligase modulates sensory neuron mechano-responses in the context of Angelman syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Given the lack of effective disease-modifying therapies for Alzheimer’s disease (AD), it is imperative to further explore alternative disease-relevant pathways, including those involving tau and TDP-43. Although more recently recognized as relevant to the pathology of late-onset AD, there is evidence from human cohorts that TDP-43 is highly prevalent in aging populations, significantly increases the risk for cognitive decline, and is associated with pathologic tau, but the underlying mechanism is unknown. I propose to elucidate the mechanisms underlying the synergism between TDP-43 and tau by integrating C. elegans as an experimental model of combined proteotoxicity with human neuropathologic and gene expression data, and in doing so determine whether targeting pathways that underlie this relationship will more effectively rescue the disease phenotype than targeting either alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Helicobacter pylori infect the human stomach of 50% of the world’s population where it can cause mild inflammation, ulcer disease and even gastric cancer, depending in part on the genetic diversity of the infecting strain. In this project we study the genes and mechanisms contributing to chronic colonization to identify the mediators of persistent infection. Our studies of genetic variation during stomach infection will show how these mediators adapt during the chronic inflammation that leads to severe disease (cancer).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Class V restorations, dental restorations on the lower third of the tooth, fail at a higher rate than any other class of dental restoration. Our proposed research will engineer a biofunctional sealant that reduces Class V restoration failure by facilitating attachment of gingival tissue to the restoration surface using peptides. This proposal will illuminate oral keratinocyte integrin activation and contribute to the PI’s training and attainment of career goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative We propose the clinical translation and validation of an innovative “radiofrequency (RF) penetrable” positron emission tomography (PET) insert technology that can be placed within any stand-alone magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) system for acquiring simultaneous PET/MRI data using the MR system’s built-in body coil for RF transmission. If successful, the results of this project will enable more widespread dissemination of and accessibility to simultaneous PET/MR imaging through the availability of this lower cost, novel PET insert technology alternative to the high cost permanently integrated PET/MR systems that are currently deployed in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The current treatment paradigms for minimally invasive ablative breast cancer therapies do not ensure complete tumor ablation or allow for immediate and accurate assessment of tissue viability. Although several MRI contrasts are sensitive to thermal ablation, no individual or combined MR contrasts have been able to accurately predict tissue viability immediately after magnetic resonance guided focused ultrasound ablation. This proposal will develop a non-contrast, deep neural network imaging biomarker that will provide both an accurate assessment of tissue viability and a treatment outcome metric that will allow for iterative MRgFUS ablation assessment, ensuring efficacy of magnetic resonance guided focused ultrasound ablation treatments for breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Osteoarthritis (OA) is a highly prevalent degenerative joint disease that poses a huge economic burden to our society. Currently, there is still a lack of clear understanding on how OA develops and why certain individuals are more prone to OA damage; as a result, there is no optimal treatment to stop its progression. Our proposal investigates the novel role of a protein (Wnt7a) in halting the trajectory of OA and predicting the severity of joint destruction, thus providing new insights into treating OA on an individual basis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The synthesis of lipids in our bodies is essential for normal metabolism but is abnormal in diseases like obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, cancer, neurodegeneration and infection. Mitochondria are subcellular organisms known for oxidizing lipids, but they also have a less understood role in synthesizing lipids. This project investigates how mitochondria contribute lipid synthesis, with the goal of better understanding how disease disrupts the normal regulation of lipid metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Over 90% of people with Parkinson’s disease have speech problems that significantly reduce their quality of life. However, the relative contributions of changes in speech physiology to outcomes that matter to patients are unknown. This knowledge is crucial for providing patients with realistic expectations and interventions that pin- point appropriate physiological targets in therapy. The results of this project will allow clinicians to target specific speech subsystems most likely to improve outcomes that matter to patients based on physiological or acoustic evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Following acute infection with SARS-Cov2 persistent symptoms of fatigue and shortness of breath are common, with physiologic, functional and quality of life impairments lasting up to 6 months or more. Little is known about the causes and long-term effects of these post-COVID, or “long COVID” syndromes. Our longitudinal studies will evaluate progressive pulmonary and neurocognitive dysfunction following acute COVID-19 infection, assessing host genetic and etiologic causes that will enable the development of future treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Recurrence is a significant and unsolved clinical problem for patients with estrogen receptor alpha (ER)- positive luminal breast cancers. We propose that, in ER+ breast cancer, phosphorylated progesterone receptors (p-PRs) interact with ER and ER target genes and also have functions distinct from ER that together, drive resistance to endocrine therapy and the development of cancer stem cells that lead to late recurrence. Our studies will elucidate the mechanisms of p-PR actions in ER+ breast cancer and will identify new drug targets and drug combinations for preventing and treating recurrences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The  role  of  vitamin  C  in  calcium  oxalate  stone  disease  is  unclear.  It  is  known  to  be  converted  in  the  body  to  oxalate, an important contributor to this disease, but the factors that influence this process are not known. The  studies  proposed  will  use  diets  of  known  nutrient  composition  and  mass  spectrometric  techniques  to  define  vitamin C contribution to oxalate in human volunteers, experimental animals and cultured cells.

PHR: Project Narrative Osteoarthritis is a common disease and a major source of chronic pain, yet treatment options are limited. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Target-occupancy studies using PET are critical for go/no-go decisions in CNS drug development. We have developed an algorithm that provides superior, high resolution functional images as endpoints that are less susceptible to bias. They can detect drug action in local brain regions of greatest therapeutic importance. Our academic-industrial partnership with Invicro, LLC – a leading provider of target-occupancy studies to pharmaceutical companies –will help us to validate our invention and to assure that it is disseminated to end- users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because glaucoma is the leading causes of irreversible blindness worldwide, but its causes and underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. The results of the proposed studies with new cutting edge imaging technologies will significantly contribute to a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying the formation and function of the trabecular meshwork and Schlemm's canal. Thus, the proposal is relevant to the NEI's mission and is likely to lead to the identification of new targets and therapeutic strategies for improving the drainage of aqueous humor from the anterior segment of the eye in affected patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Mosquitoes infect hundreds of millions of people with deadly pathogens every year. Since mosquitoes rely heavily on their sense of smell to find and bite humans, one promising strategy to control such pathogens is the deployment of repellant and attractive odor blends that push mosquitoes away from humans or pull them into lethal traps. Our research will provide a transformative inroad into the rational design of such blends by uncovering the molecular and functional properties of the sensory neurons mosquitoes use to detect odors and by providing the genetic tools necessary to manipulate them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic alcohol use and chronic stress result in disruptions in multiple aspects of cognition, particularly under demanding conditions necessitating high levels of cognitive effort. This project will identify alcohol- and stress- induced changes in a key neural circuit underlying both the ability to deploy cognitive effort, including the locus coeruleus, anterior cingulate, and dorsal striatum. Results from these studies will provide a new cognitive effort-based perspective on the relationship between cognitive function and alcohol use disorder and will identify new treatment strategies related to enhancing cognitive effort to prevent problematic alcohol use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Cilia are found on most non-dividing cells in the body, perform many functions, and when faulty, cause human diseases called ciliopathies. In nephronophthisis-related ciliopathies (NPHP-RCs), mutations in a single gene can cause different disease spectrums (renal, neurological, skeletal, retinal, cardiac, and other abnormalities), indicating the importance of understanding ciliary specialization. The application uses the C. elegans model system to identify conserved mechanisms regulating ciliary specialization, remodeling, and plasticity, which important therapeutic implications as cilia are found on nearly every non-dividing cell in the human body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative Hazardous drinking among Black individuals in the United States poses a major public health concern. The proposed research aims to better understand antecedents of alcohol use motivation and hazardous drinking among this population by examining racial/ethnic microaggressions (MAs) – brief, subtle forms of everyday discrimination due to racial/ethnic status – that may prompt Black persons to be more motivated to drink to mitigate MA-related negative affect and engage in risky patterns of alcohol use. Through this research, we also will explore mediational processes and moderators in the MA-hazardous drinking relations that will inform future intervention and prevention efforts for this neglected health disparities group.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Bladder cancer (BLCa) is the 4th most common cancer and the 7th most deadly in male veterans. Almost all cancer deaths are caused by advanced bladder cancer (aBC) which is the focus of this collaborative study. Patients with aBC usually receive medical treatment which includes chemotherapy, immunotherapy and targeted therapy, and, in case of locally advanced bladder cancer, radical cystectomy. Medical treatment is at most moderately effective. The goal of this collaborative application is to improve the treatment outcomes of aBC through revamping all four therapies from three complementary research teams with expertise in basic science, translational research, medical oncology and urology. We hypothesize that the prognosis and patient quality of life in aBC can be improved through optimizing all therapeutic modalities from research teams with complementary expertise.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative There is a paucity of support for young people living with HIV (YLWH) who often fail to achieve viral suppression, with catastrophic consequences in particular in resource-constrained countries in which treatment options are limited. This study aims to improve ART adherence among YLWH by providing small incentives based on insights from behavioral economics, combined with text messages sent by mobile phone. The approach is particularly targeted at those with low adherence as it allows to adjust eligibility thresholds for incentives to participants’ initial adherence, thereby reducing health inequality and facilitating high, long-term ART adherence for a particularly vulnerable group of HIV clients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in the mitochondrial genome can cause severe and devastating disorders. The research described here aims to understand the propagation of mutant mitochondrial genomes. Insights gained from this work will allow for better prediction of disease development, and for the eventual discovery of therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose the development of the Surgical Multidisciplinary Access to Research in Residency Training (SMART) program to develop the next generation of surgical oncology physician scientists. SMART is anchored by the Northwestern University Department of Surgery's successful history of two-year dedicated research training for residents, by a highly accomplished team of Northwestern researchers and clinicians to provide tailored-mentoring for the residents, and by the unique >15-year partnership in training surgical research residents in conjunction with the American College of Surgeons' Cancer Programs. SMART will be a national leader in increasing the pipeline of qualified surgical oncology physician scientists who go on to faculty positions, with independently funded research agendas, making seminal contributions to the field, and mentoring their own trainees, while also delivering high-quality, compassionate care to cancer patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a significant risk factor for cardiovascular disease and diabetes. Multiple studies hypothesize that environmental factors in utero program patterns of infant growth that result in increased susceptibility to obesity and insulin resistance later in life. We found that vitamin D deficiency in utero increased obesity and insulin resistance despite postnatal vitamin D supplementation. These metabolic abnormalities can be transplanted by macrophages reprogrammed in utero by vitamin D deficiency. Moreover, we found this risk is reversible in humans by vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy. This application will explore the role of macrophages and their genetic program in developing adipose differentiation and insulin resistance induced by in utero vitamin deficiency and characterize how antenatal vitamin D supplementation in humans reduces obesity and insulin resistance in the offspring. Our results will provide a better understanding of the programming of immune cells in utero contributing to obesity and the need for vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work will investigate the role that repetitive regions in the human genome play in cardiovascular disease risk. New statistical and computational approaches will be developed to estimate the lengths of repeats in the genome in existing genotyped cohorts, lengths which are hard to ascertain directly from the available DNA microarray data. The fraction of heritability of cardiovascular disease which is explained by variance in repeat lengths will be quantified, shedding light on the genetic bases for these diseases.
