IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The results of this proposal are anticipated to produce new tissue repair modalities that will overcome current limitations in urethroplasty by creating novel “off-the-shelf” silk fibroin grafts capable of urethral delivery of stem cell homing factors, stromal cell–derived factor-1 alpha (SDF1α/CXCL12) and monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP1/CCL2) for reconstruction of long urethral strictures. We also seek to uncover what role CXCR4- SDF1α/CXCL12 and CCR2-MCP1/CCL2 dependent, mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) homing plays in scaffold- mediated, constructive remodeling of urethral strictures following urethroplasty. We anticipate the results of this study will provide new information that is wider in scope than our specific goals and which may be applicable for repair of other urinary tract organs (ureter, bladder) in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cadherin clustering is a unique molecular process that mediates and controls cell-cell adhesion. In addition, it also regulates the actin cytoskeleton, polarity, proliferation, and apparently other structures and signaling pathways. Despite such incredibly important functions, which obviously play out in nearly every aspect of tissue morphogenesis, the molecular mechanisms and regulation of cadherin clustering remains to be studied. This proposal will shed light on how different types of cadherin clusters form and how they participate in such diverse array of cellular mechanisms. The study is a critical step toward the development of synthetic modulators cell-cell adhesion and their application in medicine.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: GRADUATE SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND HEALTH POLICY
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, adolescents and young adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD) are less likely to receive comprehensive sex education and to use reproductive health services than their non- disabled peers. We will test the efficacy of the STEPS-2 socialization and sex education program on increased access to reproductive health services for individuals aged 18-27 with mild to moderate I/DD in a randomized intervention trial. As one of the first such randomized trials among this population, the findings will inform best practices in sex education to improve the reproductive health of youth with I/DD as they transition from adolescence to adulthood, as well as best practices for incorporating individuals with I/DD in public health research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We will develop innovative algorithms for detecting emerging respiratory viruses within US cities. To do so, we will model the syndemic dynamics of respiratory viruses and chronic respiratory diseases and apply machine learning to combine geospatial data that track early indicators of emerging threats. Working with local public health and healthcare collaborators, we will translate this research into practical tools for addressing socio- geographic gaps in surveillance and accelerating the detection, prevention and mitigation of severe outbreaks.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative There is a pressing critical national need for veterinarians to be engaged in biomedical research to enhance, promote and sustain public health. Veterinarians are uniquely trained as comparative biologists to assess patient health in the context of multiple and variable environmental situations and are therefore well suited to meet these societal needs. The Veterinary Research Scholars Program provides select talented students with intensive research experience directed towards attracting veterinary students into biomedical research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate how inhibitory and excitatory neural computations influence basic responses in human visual cortex, as well as how these computations work in concert with attention to selectively enhance perception. The results will inform models of the human visual system, which provide a necessary framework for the development of diagnostic tools and treatments for clinical disorders that involve deficits of central visual processing. Moreover, the studies of visual attention will further inform the development of diagnostic tests and interventions for attention-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) is common in cancer survivors with significant burden on individuals (causing diet restrictions, feeding tubes, choking, pneumonia, death), their caregivers (requiring special food preparation, eating alone, isolation, fear), and the healthcare system (increasing length of stay, medical costs, resource utilization). Effective evaluation using evidence-based metrics in real-world clinical care is the first step in high- quality dysphagia management. This project proposes to apply dissemination and implementation science to help speech-language pathologists improve cancer survivors’ outcomes through adoption of DIGEST™ (Dynamic Imaging Grade of Swallowing Toxicity) as an EBP tool for swallowing diagnostics in real-world clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed Stage 3 efficacy study aims to inform health policy by testing a novel intervention that directly reduces the racial income gap by providing a universal basic income (UBI), which is intended to promote and protect Black men's health through the influx of capital and subsequent increases in personal agency and social connections. We hypothesize that (1) providing UBI of $500 per month for six months will result in increased healthcare utilization among chronically-ill, older and aging, low-income Black men; and (2) the effect of UBI will depend on whether an individual has a recent history of incarceration, such that no incarceration history combined with UBI will demonstrate the best study outcomes. Empirical research examining UBI among older Black men and its capacity to overturn structural racism are lacking in the extant literature—much of the health disparities research intended to inform health and economic policy originated from limited perspectives of older and aging Black men—Dr. W.E.B. Du Bois said in The Souls of Black Folk that for Black people, “discouragement is an unwritten word”; this study draws on that inspiration as it ultimately seeks to fundamentally overturn the economic oppression and brutality that has defined the Black experience for generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Deep neural transformer networks have advanced Natural Language Processing (NLP) performance, but are large models with many parameters, and hence vulnerable to bias. The large data sets required to train these models may be drawn from different study sites or clinical units, leading to confounding by provenance where models make predictions using the characteristics of these data sources instead of diagnostically relevant information, with erroneous predictions at the point of deployment. In the proposed research we will develop validated approaches for Deconfounding Deep Transformer Networks (DecondDTN) and disseminate them as open source tools so that these models can be applied more reliably to clinical problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  The ventrolateral preoptic (VLPO) nucleus is a key brain area for the generation and the maintenance of sleep, and the extended VLPO region (eVLPO) contains neurons that are active during REM sleep and are REM sleep-promoting. The purpose of this project is to define the long-range circuit basis by which the eVLPO controls REM sleep. Successful completion of the proposed research will contribute to a better understanding of the role of the preoptic region within the circuits for REM sleep regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: We will combine synthetic biology and advanced computational techniques to accelerate an ongoing revolution — the application of human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) to regenerative and personalized medicine. We will integrate new genetic circuits into hiPSCs that sense changes in endogenous gene expression and activate expression of other genes in order to redirect organoid differentiation to desired outcomes with specific 3D organization and arrangements of cell types and functions. Our design of sophisticated gene regulatory networks will be based on advanced optimization techniques rooted in control theory and machine learning, enabling precise and predictable generation of desired 3D structures and organoid functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson’s disease can cause cognitive impairment, like issues with memory or problem-solving, that is disabling despite adequate treatment of movement symptoms like tremor and slowness. This research project aims to study a potential mechanism of cognitive impairment by imaging the binding of a specific receptor in the brain with a PET scan and studying the role of this receptor in abnormal brain waves or “oscillations” that are found in Parkinson’s disease. Successful completion of this study would help researchers develop new treatments for cognitive impairment in Parkinson’s disease, the second most common cause of dementia in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Contact tracing is a proven intervention for finding undiagnosed cases of tuberculosis (TB) in households of newly diagnosed TB patients, and the proposed study in Cali, Colombia, will evaluate two exciting new strategies to enhance contact tracing. We will first test if TB molecular testing on oral samples is feasible, acceptable, appropriate, and accurate for TB diagnosis in adults and children. We will then determine the feasibility, acceptability, usability, and appropriateness of mobile phone chat apps, including video calls and automated assistants, to arrange and conduct TB contact tracing procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This proposal aims to optimize and characterize a novel vaccine formulation designed to safely improve the immune response to respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), a disease that causes significant morbidity and mortality in young children and for which no preventable vaccine exists. This novel nanoparticle vaccine formulation uses a biodegradable platform with inherent adjuvant properties to deliver a potent RSV antigen that is more readily taken up by dendritic cells, which are responsible for inducing antibody production and antiviral T cell responses. The tunable nature of the system allows one to tailor the antigen dose and adjuvant potency to balance efficacy and safety profiles, and in this proposal, will be optimized in an established mouse model of RSV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: MODIFIED PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Inflammation can result in the irreversible buildup of fibrosis, an extracellular matrix of collagen and fibrinogen that contributes to a wide variety of chronic and lethal diseases in humans. The proposed research will help identify genes and immune pathways that contribute to natural genetic variation in the risk of fibrosis onset, the severity of fibrosis, and vertebrates’ ability to recover from fibrosis. Concurrently, we seek to identify strategies that parasitic tapeworms use to interfere with animals’ fibrosis, which may present opportunities for therapeutic interventions to treat, or promote recovery from, peritoneal fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease (CMTD) is a peripheral neuropathy that afflicts roughly 1 out of every 2500 people and for which there is no cure or therapeutic drug. The most common forms of CMTD are caused by genetic defects affecting intracellular trafficking of the protein peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22). The goals of this project are to determine by exactly what pathways the PMP22 traffics in the cell under both healthy and pathological conditions, as well as to examine how interactions with other proteins impact PMP22 trafficking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tourette syndrome (TS) is a prevalent neurodevelopmental disorder clinically defined by the presence of tics, but the majority of adults and children with TS also experience sensory over-responsivity, defined as heightened awareness of and behavioral reactivity to commonplace environmental stimuli. The overarching goals of this research proposal are to clarify the neurophysiologic mechanisms underlying sensory over- responsivity and to determine whether sensory over-responsivity is a risk marker for more severe clinical course in TS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neural circuits in the brain undergo activity-dependent changes in structure and function, called neural plasticity, which is largely restricted to early developmental windows called critical periods. Inappropriate critical period extension is linked to neurological disorders such as autism and epilepsy, yet the mechanisms terminating critical periods are poorly understood. The experiments outlined in this proposal will define the cellular and molecular mechanisms that trigger critical period closure, as well as the physiological contribution of critical periods to mature circuit function and behavior.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal mental health critically influences the wellness of the mother and the developing child. Some individuals experience traumatic childbirth and subsequently develop posttraumatic stress disorder, which can undermine maternal health and the health of the child from the time of birth and onward, resulting in heavy health costs. Currently, there is no preventive intervention to reduce the occurrence of this illness; and this study could lay the foundation for preventive and holistic care for mothers to foster maternal resilience and optimize child welfare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epidemiologic studies have linked obesity to poor breast cancer outcomes, and it has been suggested that obese women may experience poorer outcomes, in part, due to dose reductions of chemotherapy drugs; this is because most cytotoxic agents are dosed according to body size, and clinicians may scale back the high doses administered to obese women due to concern about inducing toxicity. Given persisting uncertainty about dosing obese women, in a study population of nearly 34,000 women with breast cancer who were diagnosed and treated in two integrated healthcare delivery systems, Kaiser Permanente Northern California and Group Health, we propose to: i) examine the relationship between body size and dose intensity, and will further examine how the factors contributing to dose reductions vary by body size, ii) evaluate whether chemotherapy dose reductions mediate the associations between obesity and adverse breast cancer outcomes, and iii) evaluate the association between body size and toxicity among women identified as receiving the full body-size determined dose of chemotherapy. Addressing these questions will provide the evidence needed to better inform clinicians treating the 102,000 obese women diagnosed with breast cancer each year in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will examine the effects and cost of opioid interventions at the state and local level to assist policy makers and health professionals in North Carolina. Using publicly available data and published literature we will build a geographically explicit agent-based model (ABM) that will simulate individual trajectories to opioid overdose and death under different intervention scenarios. These interventions will reflect North Carolina Opioid Action Plan 2 and focus on “three pillars” prevention, connection to care, and reduction of harm. We will use representative synthetic populations to link individual trajectories with local environment and context.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed work is to understand how the diverse cell types in the human retina process visual information and transmit it to the brain, and how this compares to the large existing body of work from the closest animal model. Using a collection of novel techniques, we are now able to study the functioning of retinas obtained from human donors. This work will make it possible to understand the function of the human retina in ways that were never before possible, with implications ranging from understanding human vision to diagnosing visual disorders and developing retinal implants to treat incurable blindness.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Although ovarian aging is a natural physiological process, cessation of ovarian function at midlife increases susceptibility to the development of co-morbidities, with no intervention to prevent/delay this, highlighting a current unmet need in women’s health. Follicle stimulating hormone is essential for reproduction and undergoes aging-dependent changes in its glycosylation pattern, which alters its bioactivity. This study will determine how FSH glycosylation regulates FSH receptor oligomerisation and trafficking, and downstream consequences in young and aging ovaries, using a novel N-terminally FLAG-tagged FSHR mouse model, coupled with high resolution imaging and integrated transcriptomics and genomics analysis, which will provide key insights to improve ovarian function, with translational potential to improve/extend reproductive longevity and overall health and wellbeing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identifying evolutionary mechanisms that naturally protect species from developing cancer is becoming an increasingly appreciated approach to develop therapeutic strategies that are both efficient and non-toxic. In the proposed studies, we will build further on our recent finding that mammary cells from domesticated mammals with low mammary incidence secrete bioactive factors that kill breast cancer cells in vitro and reduce tumorigenicity in vivo. The knowledge gained from these studies will increase our knowledge of novel cancer- suppressing mechanisms that will accelerate the identification of novel breast cancer therapeutic and/or preventative agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: Spinal cord stimulation (SCS) is becoming increasingly important in treating various neurological disfunctions. Though it is much less invasive than other direct brain stimulation techniques (e.g. deep brain stimulations) which benefit from precise imaging guidance, the current practices of SCS do not yet have the same target accuracy due to current limitations in imaging spine-brain pathways. Here we propose to develop the much-needed hardware and software solutions for high-resolution diffusion MRI to overcome these limitations and map in detail all the relevant spine-brain pathways and their associated brain connectivities, which can then be used to improve the site-planning accuracy of SCS, leading to targeted neural stimulations in patients to increase effectiveness and efficiency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low-income individuals experiencing food insecurity – the economic and social condition of inconsistent access to healthy food – have a disproportionately higher burden of cardiovascular disease. This study aims to understand whether participation in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) – the largest government funded food assistance program in the US – is linked with improvements in cardiovascular health for low-income individuals. The findings of this study will also identify which SNAP-related policies can potentially impact cardiovascular health outcomes, which is particularly relevant in light of the many changes the program has undergone during the COVID-19 pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Patients require robust, reliable, and clinically interpretable quantitative information about the risk and benefit of a new therapy when making treatment decisions; however, the standard statistical approach using Cox’s hazard ratio falls short of this important goal. The proposed study will fill this gap in practice by developing and disseminating a novel statistical method, the general Censoring-Free person-time Incidence Rate (gCFIR), to improve interpretation of the treatment effect magnitude and increase the likelihood that results from clinical research are correctly interpreted by clinicians and translated to patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project focuses on the mechanisms that control actin monomer (G-actin) addition/dissociation at the polymerizing and depolymerizing ends of the actin filament (F-actin), key events that affect all cellular functions of actin in health and disease, including cell motility, muscle contraction, cancer metastasis, and cardiomyopathies. Using a broad spectrum of experimental approaches, ranging from cryo-electron microscopy and mutagenesis to cellular knockouts, the goal is to provide a structural-functional understanding of the mechanisms that control filament end dynamics in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Dr. Ciara O’Sullivan’s professional vision is to improve care for breast cancer patients through the personalization of systemic treatment options, investigation of novel therapeutics and the development of prognostic and predictive biomarkers. As an experienced clinical trialist, she is committed to being of continued service to the NCI clinical trials networks through the development of and execution of NCI funded trials, active participation in NCTN-affiliated scientific reviews and monitoring committees, supporting institutional efforts to enhance accrual of rural patients and underrepresented minorities to research studies and ultimately assuming leadership roles at Mayo Clinic and within the Alliance for Clinical Trials in Oncology. Dr. O’Sullivan’s research projects, advocacy efforts and support of the NCTN will significantly improve treatment options for patients with all BC subtypes in the short and long term, which is aligned with the NCI vision of advancing scientific knowledge to improve quality of life and overall life expectancy for these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE T-Cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (T-ALL) is a disease where relapses occur in 20-50% of cases, and these patients ultimately die from their disease, highlighting the need to discover novel therapeutic targets. Our preliminary results have identified pyruvate kinase (PKM) as a novel therapeutic target in T-ALL, thus, here we will address the role and mechanisms of PKM in T-ALL in vivo taking advantage of our unique genetic and technical tools. Our results will pave the way for improved therapeutic approaches for the treatment of T-ALL patients in the short-term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Biobehavioral Mechanistic Model of Alcohol Use Following Bariatric Surgery: The BREW ME Model Project Narrative The proposed project will test a novel model to explain the observed relationship between metabolic and bariatric surgery and post-operative hazardous alcohol use. Specifically, we use a combined clinical laboratory and ecological momentary assessment approach to explore the mechanistic role of the gut microbiome and the reward value of alcohol on hazardous alcohol use 2 years following surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children under 5 years of age account for ~50% of the 1.2 million new cases of pediatric TB each year, but are least likely to be diagnosed as they often present with disseminated or extrapulmonary TB and paucibacillary disease, and are therefore often missed by respiratory sampling, and are at highest risk of death without prompt treatment. To meet the need of non-sputum diagnostic tools for TB in young children, we developed an assay that detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) cell free DNA (cfDNA) coupled with CRISPR technology (CRISPR-TB) to improve sensitivity using small blood volumes. The proposed study will utilize samples from an ongoing large well-characterized cohort of children with suspected TB as well as additional cohorts of adults with confirmed TB and their asymptomatic household controls, and recently BCG-immunized asymptomatic infants to evaluate CRISPR-TB diagnostic performance (Aim 1) including longitudinal evaluation for treatment response (Aim 2), and extend evaluation to urine samples (Aim 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CD4+ T cells survey the body for evidence of microbial infection or altered self and then orchestrate long-lived protective immune responses when a problem is encountered. How they collect the relevant information from an antigen presenting cell (APC) and relay it across their cell membranes to direct their response is a matter of intense interest as this process is fundamental to their role in the immune system. This proposal will shed important new light on how CD4+ T cells relay information across their cell membrane to initiate intracellular signaling events and, in so doing, will serve as a guide for efforts to engineer synthetic receptors that mimic the form and function of their natural counterparts for therapeutic purposes. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: HLA genes are key mediators of the immune response in humans and have been linked to several hundred autoimmune disorders, inflammatory conditions, infectious diseases, and neurological disorders that can have significant consequences for patients. Despite rapidly amassing sequencing data on millions of people, scientists are limited in their ability to gain clinically meaningful insights about the role of HLA genes in disease due to the lack of appropriate computational tools. We will address this gap by developing a robust and well-supported HLA analysis toolkit that can scale to millions of individuals, thereby enabling researchers to discover novel HLA-disease associations that will drive the development of new preventive and therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rates of severe maternal morbidity are rising in the U.S. and disparities in these outcomes are worsening. Telehealth utilization increased dramatically in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and has great potential to reduce severe maternal morbidity and disparities in severe maternal morbidity through increasing prenatal and postpartum care access and utilization. This community engaged mixed methods project will determine the impact of telehealth on severe maternal morbidity and disparities in severe maternal morbidity, and identify best practices for implementation of telehealth to reduce these outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Men who have sex with men (MSM) are at high risk for gonorrhea and chlamydia in Kenya, where nucleic acid amplification testing is not feasible and most infections therefore go undiagnosed. We propose an open-label randomized clinical trial with 2900 participants assigned to WHO-recommended periodic presumptive treatment (PPT) or doxycycline post-exposure prophylaxis (doxyPEP), compared to standard syndromic treatment, with 18 months of follow-up and rigorous culture-based and molecular analysis of antimicrobial resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This work will provide critical data needed to inform guidelines and improve STI control among MSM in sub-Saharan Africa and other resource-limited settings, including modelled estimates of the health and economic impact of scaling up these two interventions on STI control among MSM and their partners in Kenya.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging adults (age 18-25) who frequently use cannabis are at an increased risk for cannabis-related problems and developing cannabis use disorder (CUD). Brief interventions (BIs) have been the gold-standard for heavy and problematic alcohol use in emerging adults; however, evidence is mixed, and the quality of studies is low for similar brief interventions targeting frequent cannabis use, suggesting additional rigor is needed to develop and test potentially efficacious cannabis brief interventions. The goal of the proposed study is to develop and evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of a novel cannabis brief intervention targeting theory- and empirically-based mechanisms associated with frequent cannabis use in emerging adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE. Inhalation of Francisella tularensis causes significant morbidity and mortality in humans. We have used mouse and rabbit models to identify the single most effective tularemia vaccine (S4ΔaroD). In this application we extend these efforts to a non-human primate model against pneumonic tularemia. We expect the results to support advancement of this vaccine and to set the stage for human clinical trials

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Degenerative cervical myelopathy (DCM) is a widespread and debilitating condition and decompressive surgery, the standard treatment for DCM, fails to provide any meaningful clinical recovery in over 30% of patients while over 40% have a residual disability. This proposal is important and impactful because it uses a unique model of DCM in combination with our team's expertise in dissecting neural networks to delineate for the first time the neural basis of forelimb deficits and recovery in DCM. This proposal will determine if targeted neuromodulation of spinal interneurons will enhance neurological recovery after decompressive surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:  Preclinical models of lung cancer are essential tools for researchers to understand cancer biology and develop therapeutic strategies, but how they compare with each other and align with human tumors remains elusive. This study proposes to collect and harmonize molecular and pathology data from a wide range of lung cancer preclinical models. These data will be used to generate a user-friendly web application with a myriad of informatics tools for the broad lung cancer community to explore and assess whether preclinical models faithfully represent patient tumors in multiple aspects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell-cell communication is one of the most fundamental, yet poorly understood problems in modern biology. The proposed work will combine mathematical modeling and machine learning to develop analysis tools for systematic screening of cell-cell communication using spatial transcriptomic data. The results will be directly relevant to understanding of tissue organization in space, the mechanisms of microenvironment for tumors, developmental processes, and cell fate decision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative This project investigates rapid plasticity of interneuron intrinsic excitability as an important mechanism for experience-dependent plasticity and homeostasis in cerebral cortex. It will identify the molecular mechanisms for plasticity of intrinsic excitability in two interneuron classes, PV and SST cells, and will test whether deficits in this process contribute to inhibitory deficits in autism. This basic research could identify novel therapeutic targets for restoring cortical circuit function in severe genetic forms of autism.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Standard cancer cell lines have had an important impact on cancer research and greatly facilitated development of a variety of cancer treatments. However, new mammalian cancer culture models are difficult to establish. We developed a new cell culture system that allows us to establish cancer cell cultures that retain the accurate molecular features and patient outcome and drug response profile; in this application we propose to implement this technology and compare monolayer and organoid models and PDX from the same patient to establish best practices in the use of these models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to build a structure-function taxonomy of two key groups of neuromodulatory neuron types in the brain: neurons that release serotonin and those that release norepinephrine. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The overarching goal of this application is to develop mRNA-encoded Cas13 based drugs for treating flaviviruses, with a focus on dengue and West Nile virus, but including screens against yellow fever, Powassan and Zika viruses. Multiple Cas13 nucleases will be evaluated, and mechanisms of action investigated; efficacy will be demonstrated with dengue (serotypes 1-4) and West Nile virus in rodent infection models. Overall, we feel this approach and the RNA-based platform have the potential to alter the paradigm for how viral infections are treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Public Health Relevance. While CT remains the most highly utilized diagnostic tool in clinical practice, its technology still calls for research and development along the entire imaging chain to improve diagnostic accuracy and patient outcomes. The clinical translation of such developments must be safe, efficient, and timely; however, it remains a challenge to the community how to precisely predict performance during and after the development phase. Our proposal aims to develop 3D printing hardware and software that will be capable of creating patient-based phantoms with accurate spectral x-ray characteristics and a natural look and feel of anatomical and pathological structures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a life-threatening lung injury that allows fluid to leak into the lungs and makes breathing difficult, killing 74,000 people each year in the United States. In this project, a highly interdisciplinary team of engineers, clinicians, and data scientists is developing a portable, non-invasive breathalyzer-type device and corresponding algorithm to quickly diagnose ARDS, and the device can be attached to ventilators so a patient can be continuously monitored even if they cannot breathe on their own. Because the device will detect ARDS much more accurately than is currently possible and will help determine if patients are getting better or worse, it is expected to improve clinical decision making and enable earlier treatment, thus improving outcomes for those suffering from ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Chronic stress, the consistent sense of feeling pressured and overwhelmed, is pervasive in our society and has been linked to increased risk of cardiovascular diseases, mental health problems, neuropathic pain and shorter life expectancy. Current treatment options include changes in lifestyle, exercise, anxiolytics, improved sleep and more, but these options are clearly not sufficient, since chronic stress contributes to the increasing societal burden of alcohol and drug abuse, unemployment and collapse of family structures. In this application we test the idea that chronic stress impairs several cellular restorative processes that normally allow our brain to be ready for the daily challenges of our waking life. These restorative processes involve the two major types of brain cells, astrocytes and neurons, and together allow to remove metabolic toxic products and to maintain the high energy costs of brain activity under control. In the proposed experiments we will study astrocytes and neurons in parallel to understand how the normal brain recovers from the wear and tear of our waking activities, and how chronic stress impairs this recovery process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The intracellular pathogen Shigella flexneri is the causative agent of Bacillary dysentery, a severe form of diarrheal disease associated with massive destruction of the intestinal mucosa and presence of blood in stool. In this proposal, we present our plans to uncover the role of host factors in the infant rabbit model of shigellosis recently developed by our laboratory. The proposed approach will contribute to our general understanding of the mechanisms underlying microbial pathogenesis and may constitute the foundation for the rational design of preventive and therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The increasingly crucial role played by family and friend caregivers of patients with advanced cancer is complicated by existential distress, but to date, current psychosocial interventions fail to address such distress. This project is relevant to NIH’s mission as it represents a critical step in the refinement of a targeted intervention–Meaning-Centered Psychotherapy for Cancer Caregivers (MCP-C)–that has shown encouraging results in improving caregivers’ sense of meaning in life and spiritual wellbeing and ameliorating anxiety and depression. If successful, MCP-C holds significant promise to not only improve the quality of life for caregivers across the caregiving trajectory from diagnosis through bereavement, but also to yield downstream benefits to the patients for whom they provide care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The kappa opioid receptor (KOR) system is a prominent neuromodulatory system that controls various physiological functions such as antinociception and mood perception. The KOR system represents a potential alternative to current opioid analgesics, but aversive side effects of KOR activation have hindered its drug development. The experiments proposed will help identify intracellular signaling events activated by KOR that modulate aversion, which may reveal strategies to separate therapeutic from aversive effects of KOR agonists, potentially leading to novel treatments for pain and affective disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Neuronal communication is largely mediated through the release of small-molecules called neurotransmitters which bind to and activate receptors on neighboring nerve cells. Neurotransmitter molecules are stored into small vesicles at high concentrations by transport proteins which are also targets of therapeutic drugs for neuropsychiatric disorders including hyperkinetic movement disorders such as tardive dyskinesia, Tourette’s syndrome, and Huntington’s disease. The proposed research focuses on how these neurotransmitter transport proteins work and how therapeutic and addictive drugs bind to and modify their activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Hospitalization and treatment for cardiovascular disease is one of the main contributors to disability in older adults. Moderate intensity continuous aerobic and resistance training have been the cornerstone of cardiac rehabilitation (CR) for decades to remediate hospital-acquired functional deficits, but some groups receive less or minimal functional benefit from this training. The proposed studies seek to optimize recovery of aerobic fitness and physical function among older cardiac patients using a novel high intensity training regimen with the long-term goal of reducing subsequent disability and improving clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The disruption of fetal developmental processes is hypothesized to give rise to asthma; therefore, prenatal interventions may help reduce its burden. While emerging evidence suggests that maternal vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy can help prevent asthma in the offspring, the molecular mechanisms of this potential protective effect are far from well-understood. Our aim is to identify the molecular determinants that modulate the effect of maternal vitamin D supplementation on childhood asthma by using statistical and network-based computational methods and multi-omic data from randomized clinical trials, with the long-term goal of enabling the precision prevention of childhood asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Glutamate excitotoxicity contributes to the pathogenesis of many different psychiatric disorders and is the primary mechanism for neuronal injury in neurological diseases. Currently, there is no medicine that can suppress glutamate excitotoxicity without inhibiting cognitive functions. Success of this application will open up a new avenue for the development of therapeutic long-lasting autoantibodies that specifically suppress glutamate excitotoxicity and enhance cognitive functions in many neurological diseases and psychiatric disorders including TBI, PTSD, and schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuropsychiatric manifestations are common in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (22qDS), affecting brain development and functioning with marked heterogeneity. We propose to examine developmental trajectories in a cohort of adolescents and young adults and their parents, integrating prospective dimensional and categorical phenotyping of psychopathology, neurobehavioral, environmental exposures, and medical burden. This work will identify convergent risk mechanisms for developmental neuropsychiatric disorders that have relevance to the broader population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The ultimate goal is to discover kinase inhibitors that could be developed as an oral multi parasite effective therapeutic against cryptosporidiosis and giardiasis diarrhea with potential usefulness in other intestinal parasitic diseases. We have demonstrated that kinase inhibitors from two chemotypes have selective inhibition of the parasites with one shown to be therapeutically effective in mouse infection models of Giardia lamblia and Cryptosporidium parvum. The common anatomical infection site of these etiological agents and symptomatic presentations should aid in finding a dual use drug because of similar pharmacokinetic (PK) and pharmacodynamic (PD) requirements for a syndromic treatment of the diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer immunotherapy resistance in squamous cell carcinomas is found to be orchestrated by a special group of tumor-initiating cells. This project aims to uncover novel mechanisms activated by Sox2 to reprogram the immune suppressive microenvironment and intrinsic resistance of tumor- initiating cells. The ultimate goal of this project is to leverage the findings from this study for more effective immunotherapies that can overcome cancer recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This study addresses a high-priority public health need by using technology to examine an intervention to help family care partners address behavioral symptoms for individuals with frontotemporal dementia. The proposed study tests the preliminary efficacy and analyzes the mechanism of action of an intervention using the well- known “ABC” problem solving approach to behavior change, with results informing long-term health and burden in care-givers. Upon completion we will have reliable data to sufficiently understand the underlying principles of STELLA-FTD, in order to test them in an NIH Stage 2 study, with the ultimate goal of making STELLA-FTD scalable for implementation in the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Novel adjunctive treatments for fibromyalgia (FM) that have optimal treatment effects, minimal side effects, and are easy to implement and readily accessible for all are needed. Morning bright light treatment is an accessible and scalable non-pharmacological treatment for FM, and can lead to significant improvements in function and pain. This large clinical trial will determine the active elements of morning bright light treatment for FM, the impact of social determinants of health on symptom burden and treatment, and explore mechanisms of action to assist in developing morning bright light treatment as a treatment for chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding how social and environmental factors influence the substance use, mental health, and suicidality of non-prescriber/non-executive healthcare workers can inform more practical and effective prevention and intervention efforts that address drivers of health that exist beyond the individual level for an at-risk and growing population. This proposal aligns with NIDA’s strategic plan for 2022 – 2026, which specifically calls to enhance the knowledge of the contextual landscape of drug use and to determine individual and population-level risk and protective factors for drug use and addiction across the lifespan. Additionally, this proposal is relevant to NIH’s mission to “foster fundamental creative discoveries, innovative research strategies, and their applications as a basis for ultimately protecting and improving health.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The cerebellum, a brain region traditionally associated with sensorimotor control, has been shown to be involved in reward-related satiety in an appetitive state-specific manner in animal models and in observational data in humans. However, validation of this circuit using an integrated neuromodulation and neuroimaging approach has not been examined, and data on causal mechanisms in humans are lacking. This project will provide mechanistic insight into the role of the cerebellar-ventral striatal circuit as a critical regulator of reward-related satiety and food intake in humans, thereby informing the potential neurobiological pathways to target in the development of obesity therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low level lead (Pb) exposure via drinking water is an everyday problem of high prevalence and is unavoidable for many individuals worldwide. Little is known about how Pb alters the composition of gut microbiota and the secondary impacts on brain development in children, which are more vulnerable than adults. Here, we propose to dissect out the causal role of Pb-induced gut dysbiosis on the central and enteric nervous systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Companion animals, such as horses and dogs, display highly variable mammary cancer incidence and are sentinels for human health as they share comparable habitats and are exposed to similar environmental risk factors. We will use our newly established mammary xenograft mouse model to identify responses to 7,12- dimethylbenz[a]-anthracene (DMBA), a synthetic carcinogen belonging to the polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) environmental pollutant family, in these sentinel mammals that are either resistant (horse) or susceptible (dog) to mammary cancer. The knowledge gained from these studies will increase our understanding on the effects of environmental pollutants on mammary gland health and will help define important regulatory mechanisms that can ultimately result in the identification of biomarkers of exposure and breast cancer risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Quantitative PET biomarker imaging promises to play a significant role in delivering precision medicine for cancer patients, since it can provide accurate biomarker uptake measurements that are necessary for tumor characterization as well as measuring changes in response to therapy. While PET images acquired during routine 18F-FDG imaging are highly accurate, it is challenging to maintain the same performance when imaging large patients (increased multiple scatter, low counts, and reduced tail-fitting region), in situations where few coincidence events are collected (e.g. imaging at low injected activity levels for repeat scans or imaging tracers with a low positron yield), or imaging new radiotracers using isotopes emitting prompt gamma. For PET to fulfill its role in this era, quantification accuracy of PET images needs to be maintained over a large range of data acquisition protocols, where the quantification challenge is the accuracy of the scatter and background estimation method that is used to compensate (correct) for the bias present in the data due to scattered coincidences and prompt gamma events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Heavy metal pollution by arsenic (iAs), Cadmium (Cd) and lead (Pb) disproportionally affects low income and historically underappreciated communities nationally and internationally. We found that these metals alone and in combination, at doses much lower than the World Health Organization (WHO) recommended limits, promote an increase in the generation of reactive oxygen species by ER+/PR+ breast cancer cell mitochondria leading to chromatin oxidative remodeling in the nucleus and the progression of the disease to multi-drug resistant metastasis. This project proposes the development of new and FDA-approved pharmacologic nucleus- and mitochondria-targeted antioxidants as chromatin protective agents to spare H3.1 from oxidation and prevent heavy metal-induced worsening of breast cancer for patients impacted by socioeconomic and environmental health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long-term allograft function in kidney transplant recipients (KTRs) remain suboptimal, and graft failure causes significant morbidity and mortality, with cardiovascular disease being the leading cause of death in KTRs and the most common cause of death with a functioning graft. Sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors safely lower cardiovascular and kidney disease risk in the non-transplant population, yet data in KTRs are lacking. This clinical trial seeks to establish the efficacy and safety of dapagliflozin, a SGLT2 inhibitor, for improving cardiovascular and kidney graft function in adult KTRs with type 2 diabetes and post-transplant diabetes, and to leverage innovate translational methods to define the underlying mechanisms of action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The basal-like subtype of PDAC associates with resistance to treatment and poor patient outcome. Our study will provide mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanism by which intratumoral hypoxia promotes the basal-like state through the suppression of the histone demethylase KDM8. Our findings will likely uncover novel approaches to reverse hypoxia-induced basal-like state while promoting the treatment-sensitive classical subtype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative With age, the body’s ability to repair and regenerate tissues gradually decline. Using hair follicle stem cells (HFSCs) as a model for studying stem cell changes during aging, we will identify genes that can functionally rejuvenate old HFSCs or drive HFSC aging. These results are not only important for the mechanistic understanding of HFSC aging, but may also inform innovative therapeutic solutions to halt or revert age-related decline seen with stem cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is rooted in the fundamental cell biology underlying heart muscle cell division and expansion during heart development, as well as its impact on ischemic heart repair. We will investigate the cellular mechanisms and their components that direct the organization of the mitotic apparatus, a requirement for heart muscle cell division, and how they affect remuscularization post ischemic heart injury. The current incomplete understanding of how division is repressed in adult mammalian cardiomyocytes constitutes an enormous obstacle for designing heart regeneration strategies, and this research will help to elucidate the mechanistic basis of mitotic regulation at key developmental stages, and after cardiac injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE How people flexibly control ongoing movements is a critical feature of healthy human behavior. Current approaches for studying these behaviors have used motor tasks with limitations, and neuroscientific approaches that are unable to reveal contributions of cortical and subcortical brain regions with high spatiotemporal resolution. We aim to overcome these limitations by using a novel motor control task in combination with an invasive and non-invasive brain recording techniques, subcortical brain stimulation, and validated rating scales.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This study addresses middle-aged and older adult veterans with slow gait speed. Slow walking speed is a frequent patient complaint and is associated with bad health outcomes including disability and death. Physical therapy (PT) care is the usual treatment for older adults with slow gait speed, but the optimal model of PT care is not known. Outside of the VA, we developed Live Long Walk Strong (LLWS) which is a program of PT care that builds upon our research identifying new treatments with greater benefit than usual care. We must confirm that LLWS can benefit Veterans beginning in midlife. We intend to conduct a study of LLLWS among community dwelling Veterans in comparison to usual care. We will evaluate the benefits that LLWS provides on walking skills and the qualities that lead to walking skill improvements. We will also evaluate if the benefits of LLWS last up to 16 weeks after treatment ends. If successful, this study will establish LLWS as a treatment targeting health and functional independence, which can be provided in a variety of VA care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell migration directed by external gradients of soluble and matrix-associated ligands, and of tissue stiffness, is encountered in various physiological and natural settings and is a primary means by which cells are instructed to move within and between tissues. We propose to study the molecular mechanisms underlying directed migration of mesenchymal cells using a multi-disciplinary approach involving molecular perturbations, microfluidics, cutting-edge microscopy and image analysis. These studies will directly contribute to our understanding the physiological basis of disease states such as tumor metastasis, fibrosis and cardiovascular disease, as well as our understanding of physiological processes such as wound healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Alternative polyadenylation (APA), which expands the complexity of brain transcriptome and proteome, is critical for normal brain function and is dysregulated in many neurological disorders. The proposed study will advance our knowledge in understanding how APA maintains proper neurological functions and how abnormal APA contribute to the pathogenesis of tuberous sclerosis and other “mTORopathies”. Knowledge obtained from the proposed study will facilitate the development of novel diagnostic and therapeutic options for a broad range of neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Magnetic hyperthermia is a highly promising therapy for various cancers based on the nanoparticle’s capacity to generate intratumoral heat in the presence of an external magnetic field. However, it is currently limited to the treatment of relatively accessible tumors because the required therapeutic temperatures can only be achieved by direct intratumoral injection of conventional magnetic nanoparticles. We propose novel magnetic nanoparticles that can efficiently accumulate in deep-seated primary and metastatic tumors following systemic injection and generate desirable intratumoral temperatures upon exposure to a magnetic field.

PHR: Project Narrative: Public Health Relevance Section  A combined chemical and genetics-based approach is being developed for the discovery of highly domain selective bromodomain inhibitor molecules for the epigenetic proteins BRD4 and BPTF. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's Disease (AD) is rapidly becoming an overwhelming economic and social burden. This proposal will study cerebrovascular function, diffusion measures of white matter injury in the early phases of AD, and use these measures to predict cognitive decline in subjects with AD pathology. Successful execution of the study will provide a better understanding of the interaction between cerebrovascular and AD pathology in the early phases of AD that could eventually lead to the development of effective multi-component therapeutic interventions of AD that target both AD and vascular pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic variants in NMDA receptor subunits, including variants within the intracellular tail of the GluN2B subunit greatly increase risk for schizophrenia, autism, and related neurodevelopmental disorders, but how they impact NMDAR function is unclear. My proposed studies will elucidate a novel mechanism by which GluN2B intracellular tails regulate NMDAR function. These studies could reveal whether distinct functions of NMDAR subunits could serve as a potential target for therapeutic interventions to treat NMDAR-associated disorders.

PHR: Project Narrative  Schizophrenia poses a great social and economic burden in a significant percentage of patients, including increased risk for unemployment, homelessness, incarceration, chronic disability, and reduced life expectancy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY LAS CRUCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Acute myocardial infarction (heart attack) is one of the leading causes of death in the United States and globally. Currently a non-invasive method of determining the underlying cause of an acute myocardial infarction does not exist, and it is unknown how different causes of acute myocardial infarction affect or alter metabolic processes. This project will use previously collected blood plasma from humans experiencing an acute myocardial infarction to develop a diagnostic method for determining the underlying cause of the event and how the different causes alter metabolic processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease affects one in ten people over the age of 65 and our current understanding of the cause is limited. Recent data from experimental models and human neuroimaging indicates that impaired vascular function is a key component of disease and understanding the cause of these changes could greatly enhance our approach to slowing or even preventing cognitive decline. These studies will identify specific changes in gene expression within the brain’s smallest blood vessels, will examine how these changes contribute to altered vascular integrity in disease, and will determine if these findings could be used to develop new vascular-directed therapies for use in Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intracerebral hemorrhage is complex, has long-term significant cognitive and functional impairment, and has no proven treatment, resulting in a disproportionate disability rate and lifetime cost among stroke survivors. By employing novel cognitive outcomes methodology to study long-term outcomes in ICH with enhanced retention, we may accelerate understanding of the causes of cognitive impairment after ICH. In the REpeated ASSEssment of SurvivorS in IntraCerebral Hemorrhage study (REASSESS ICH), we will determine whether reduction of ICH volume with minimally invasive surgery is a critical target to reducing the risk of progressive cognitive decline, targets for residual hematoma volume and whether inflammatory pathways in particular predict patients with cognitive impairment independent of gene risk scores for dementia and surgical status.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid Withdrawal Syndrome (OWS) consists of many negatively affective and physical symptoms that often incentivize individuals to relapse. Understanding the mechanisms underlying this stage of Opioid Use Disorder may inform future therapeutics and treatment options for OWS, preventing relapse and continued opioid misuse. Specifically, this proposal lays out experiments designed to investigate the effects of opioid withdrawal on the GABAergic signaling between two implicated brain regions, the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST) and the ventral tegmental area (VTA).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the most interesting questions in science is how individual cells robustly communicate with each other in complex and rapidly changing environments using signaling pathways, whose mechanistic details are not understood. Quantitative characterization of signaling pathways in living cells would lead to accurate computational models of emergent signaling outcomes in health and disease, as well as better therapies in a range of conditions including infection, autoimmunity, and cancer. We will use live-cell experiments, modeling and bioengineering approaches to study information processing by individual cells and cell populations, and develop enabling new technologies with improved accuracy and throughput for better study of biological information processing by single cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative This study is to understand neuronal underpinnings of the sex-specific diverse consequences of adolescent stress. Combined approaches will be used to test the hypothesis that circuit-specific alterations of neuronal functions in stressed males and females, which are driven by circuit-specific changes in gene expression, mediate the sexually dimorphic effects of early life stress. It will offer insights into the development of novel precision therapy to mitigate the distinct deficits in males and females after stress exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cancer development is associated with immune suppression, and therefore lifting the suppression has achieved a certain degree of success to effectively treat a proportion of cancer patients. A family of protein called PIM kinases (1, 2 and 3) plays a prominent role in promoting tumor growth, but our recent study indicates that one family member (PIM-2) strongly restrains T lymphocyte responses against tumor. In the current research, we will test how inhibition of PIM-2 kinase promotes immunity against cancer while directly suppressing tumor growth, which may reveal a novel strategy for effective cancer immunotherapy.

A better understanding of howresistance develops, and the specific vulnerabilities each resistance mechanism poses, will provide new treatment opportunities. The inclusion of selective Bcl2 family inhibitors into clinical care, driven by this fundamental knowledge, will have broad reach in improving cancer outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epigenetic alterations have been identified as playing a critical role in the development and progression of cancer. Current epigenetic assays require large numbers of cells (thousands to millions) with limited capability to analyze rare cells or tumor heterogeneity. This proposal seeks to develop new microfluidic technologies to evaluate epigenetic alterations in rare cells that can be used to improve our understanding of cancer, develop new therapeutic interventions and support biomarker development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE. The Harvard Aging Brain Study is a longitudinal study aimed at improving our understanding of brain aging and the earliest (preclinical) stages of Alzheimer’s disease. This study acquires imaging data to detect early brain changes related to Alzheimer’s disease, including amyloid plaques and tau tangles, as well as functional and structural imaging data, and detailed assessments of memory and other cognitive processes. Our ultimate goal is to provide knowledge that will accelerate progress towards the successful prevention of cognitive decline due to Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The comorbidity between posttraumatic stress disorder and borderline personality disorder (PTSD-BPD) is a serious public health concern characterized by high suicide risk, healthcare utilization, and economic burden. This project examines a brief, target-informed, integrative treatment for individuals with this comorbidity, in efforts to improve accessibility beyond current emerging treatments which are lengthy, resource-intensive, and challenging to implement. Findings from this investigation have high potential for therapeutic reach by providing a briefer treatment alternative to facilitate implementation efforts in every day practice and ultimately decrease the burden of this public health problem.

PHR: Narrative: Modulation of behavioral responses is a fundamental process, yet the underlying molecular mechanisms are poorly understood. This proposal aims takes a phenotype based molecular genetic approach using genetic mutants to determine the molecular and neural circuits mechanisms underlying a simple learning behavior. and to determine the molecular identity of six zebrafish mutants with defects in habituation of the acoustic startle response. Altered startle habituation have been linked to several cognitive disorders, autism and attention deficit hyperactive disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) are rare cells within human bone marrow that are responsible both for the life-long replenishment of all blood cell lineages and for the curative effects of bone marrow transplantation. The creation of human induced pluripotent cells holds great promise for cellular regeneration therapies, but we cannot currently instruct these cells to specifically generate HSCs in vitro. The overall goal of this application is to determine the molecular cues and behaviors that instruct HSC fate in the vertebrate embryo and from human pluripotent stem cells such that these events may ultimately be replicated routinely to generate patient- specific HSCs for clinical utility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Atrial fibrillation (AF), the most prevalent sustained cardiac arrhythmia in the human population, is associated with a high incidence of stroke leading to substantial disability, suffering, and enormous health care costs. Because AF prevalence increases with age, affecting approximately 5% of the human population over 65, the incidence of AF will increase and continue to be a large public burden. In this proposal, we will perform an in depth study of genes that are important in AF.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common neurodegenerative disorder, currently accounting for 60–80 % of dementia cases. PHR: Project Narrative Deep brain stimulation is an emerging treatment for individuals suffering from severe obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), which is a common and disabling neuropsychiatric condition. To prepare this treatment for broad dissemination, we must build the knowledge and tools to enhance the precision with which stimulation is applied to individual brains. This research constructs a connectomic atlas for deep brain stimulation in OCD using the association of brain pathways and optimal behavioral outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma is exceedingly aggressive and refractory to conventional and targeted therapies, including those directed at mutant KRAS-signaling (hyperactivated in >90% of cases); but the underlying mechanisms that determine therapeutic response/resistance—including pancreatic cancer stem cells—are poorly understood, and effective strategies to overcome therapeutic resistance are unavailable. These studies will mechanistically explore the regulation of the novel pancreatic cancer stem cell driver, HNF1A, define a strategy for targeting HNF1A using BET-inhibitors and specific depletion of BRD4, and assess the efficacy BET-inhibitors/BRD4-ablation in overcoming HNF1A-mediated resistance to targeting KRAS-signaling and pancreatic cancer stem cells. The data generated from this proposal will identify a clinically viable strategy to target HNF1A-dependent pancreatic cancer stem cells, overcome resistance to KRAS-targeting strategies, and improve outcomes for patients with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks to understand how endocrine disrupting chemical (EDC) mixtures cause the brain and behavior to develop abnormally in a sex dependent fashion. Our previous research revealed that a curated EDC mixture, representative of maternal and infant exposures, targets the perinatal testosterone surge in male mice. The proposed research will define the epigenetic mechanisms of sex-dependent behavioral toxicity following androgen disruption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major goal of science is to understand mechanisms of basic cell development and differentiation processes in order to use such information to design strategies to prevent disease and improve the quality of human life. This application aims to address the question of how autophagy, a key cellular degradation system, degrades an amyloid-like protein to enable meiotic cell progression. This basic research aims to provide a rationale for developing new strategies to remove or prevent deleterious amyloid-like aggregation that is ubiquitously observed in aging neurons and to prevent chromosomal disorders such as Down syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Our study examines the role of melanin pigments in melanoma susceptibility, based upon several recent discoveries: that the redhair background is associated with numerous “invisible” moles, that these moles have significantly elevated risk of melanoma transformation (spontaneously or after UV exposure), and that the Parkinson’s Disease drug L-Dopa further amplifies this melanoma risk by unexpectedly stimulating red pigment synthesis. These studies will employ a series of genetically engineered mouse models to dissect pathways of elevated melanoma risk and several strategies aimed at diminishing the melanoma risk, based on elucidation of the underlying mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Percutaneous needle placement plays a fundamental role in biopsy and focal ablation of prostate cancer. The goal of this project is to develop and disseminate free open-source software named OpenIGTLink to support advanced image-guided robot-assisted systems, where a robotic system guides a needle into the prostate based on biomechanical, data-driven, and hybrid models that predict the tissue and needle deformation in the patient during insertion. We expect that the accurate prediction will enable individualized planning and control for robot-assisted needle placement and improve accuracy biopsy and focal ablation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The University of Washington and the Duwamish River Community Coalition propose a randomized control trial that evaluates the effectiveness of low-cost box fans equipped with filters to reduce asthma symptoms among children and improve indoor air quality. This community engaged research project will also evaluate individual and community level empowerment and engagement as well as conduct a community-directed air pollution monitoring campaign to better characterize air quality in the Duwamish Valley.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Persons with COPD benefit from being physically active, but they are often limited by chronic musculoskeletal pain. This project will determine whether a non-pharmacologic, integrated, technology- mediated walking and Tai Chi mindfulness intervention can improve physical function in Veterans with COPD and chronic musculoskeletal pain. The proposed research addresses VA Rehabilitation R&D Service's high priority area of improving health-related quality of life by reducing disease burden and maximizing function in Veterans with chronic disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Significant resources have been devoted to the immediate rehabilitation needs of persons undergoing lower- limb amputation, but there needs to be greater consideration for the early identification and modification of potential risk factors responsible for long-term development of secondary health conditions such as low back pain. Prosthesis users are known to walk with distinct asymmetries, which may relate to prosthesis design and fitting procedures. Poor trunk posture and abnormal pelvic motions may be implicated in the development and persistence of low back pain in some unilateral, transfemoral prosthesis users. The purpose of this study is to investigate and compare the effects of two prosthetic socket designs on the trunk posture and pelvic motions of transfemoral prosthesis users to determine if current sockets and prosthetic fitting procedures may contribute to the risk of development of low back pain. This work is directly applicable to the Veteran Health Administration’s Patient Care Mission because the results may improve the gait and quality of life of Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The over-arching goals of this research proposal focused on C3 Glomerulopathy are to study the role of genetic variation in driving disease, to define the underlying characteristics of autoantibodies identified in C3G patients by epitope mapping, and to develop and clinically validate predictive models of disease outcome based on a longitudinal study of the natural history of C3G that includes analysis of clinical, genetic, complement and biopsy data. Completing these goals will provide a better understanding of C3G and improve care for C3G patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: There are no known cures for neurodegeneration—the progressive loss of neurons that can occur sporadically in the human population with age and also in patients with specific genetic mutations. Here we use early-onset, familial cerebellar neurodegeneration as a model to understand the molecular events that occur early in the progression of disease. We hypothesize that unrepaired breaks in DNA are a key component of this progression and use human neurons in culture as well as biochemistry-based approaches to characterize the origin and consequences of this DNA damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL Viruses that affect the respiratory system are the most common global illness and can have significant medical consequences for people with chronic inflammatory diseases. In this project, we will study immune responses in the airway and blood to these viruses in both adults with rheumatoid arthritis and children with asthma, allergies and obesity. We will use multiple –omics approaches to determine how immune response to respiratory viruses differs in these vulnerable populations and examine how that affects the severity of their viral illness and chronic inflammatory conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Public health relevance Damage to the nervous system often leads to persistent deficits due to failure of neurons to regrow their axons after nervous system lesion. Axon regeneration is governed by close interactions between extrinsic glial environment and intrinsic growth ability. Investigating how glial control of axon regeneration is of therapeutical significance. In the current proposal, we propose to investigate the cellular and signaling mechanisms by which glial cells control neuronal type- specific axon regeneration in Drosophila, a genetic model organism that shares conserved axon regeneration mechanisms with mammals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We are testing the hypothesis that the brain-gut-retina communicate through the regulation of immune cell function and that in diabetic retinopathy this communication is disturbed. Specifically, diabetes induces loss of expression of key neurotransmitters (somatostatin) in special centers in the brain and this loss of somatostatin results in the intestine, an immune tissue, becoming hyperstimulated. We postulate that this hyperstimulation results in the intestine generating pathological cells that leave the intestine, enter the circulation and go to the retina where they accelerate the development of diabetic retinopathy.
