IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: We will examine whether a combination of blood-based measures that reflect three different aspects of Alzheimer disease (AD) pathology better predict current or future AD symptoms than amyloid PET, a gold standard for AD brain pathology. If a blood test can provide better diagnostic information than more logistically complex tests, this could accelerate efforts to find drugs that prevent AD symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The goal of this research project is to address the NIH and NIA's grand challenge of using a person's own vehicle as a passive-detection system for flagging potential age- and/or disease-related aberrant driving behaviors that may signal early warning signs of functional decline of Alzheimer's disease (AD), even before standard clinical tests do so. Our Specific Aims will assess and combine key factors affecting driver behavior and clinical status in aging, mild cognitive impairment (MCI), and Alzheimer's clinical syndrome (ACS) as markers and moderators of risk: SA 1) Extract key real-world driver behavior features over a 3-month continuous, baseline period that classify NIA-AA core clinical criteria of MCI and ACS in drivers who are normally aging (N = 60), MCI (N = 80), or ACS (N = 40); SA2) Determine the extent to which real-world driver sleep and mobility mediate the relationship between extracted driver behavior and clinical features; SA3) Develop models (statistical and supervised machine learning) that combine features of driver behavior (from SA 1) and driver sleep and mobility (from SA2) to detect early signs of MCI and AD and predict disease progression. By building on our extensive successes in the current phase, the project directly advances NIH and NIA goals lo detect early warnings signs of decline and incipient AD-with the goal of screening, identifying, and tracking individuals at risk for AD from passive-monitoring of real-world behavior to predict clinical status and progression-promoting early treatment of AD and the next stage of interventions to prevent the progression of AD even in its preclinical stages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a major public health problem. Currently there is no effective treatment for AD. Genetic studies aiming to improve our understanding of the pathogenesis of AD and underlying mechanisms may contribute to personalized medicine goals and better therapies and/or preventive measures This study is focused to delineate the genetic basis of two AD-specific proteinopathies, amyloid-beta (Aβ) and pathologic tau, by whole-genome-sequencing. The successful completion of the proposed comprehensive study using biomarkers of two AD-specific proteinopathies in living people with well characterized amyloid-PET and CSF Aβ42/tau datasets along with clinical outcomes of dementia followed by functional studies will make a major contribution to our understanding of the pathogenesis of AD and underlying mechanisms, which may contribute to personalized medicine goals and better therapies and/or preventive measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A long-standing goal of neuroscience is to understand how cognitive functions are implemented through interactions of large neural ensembles in order to provide practical solutions for altering cognitive behavior through manipulations of neural circuits. Here, we develop a theoretical framework to infer functional causal interactions through sparse sampling of large neural ensembles and test our framework on the prefrontal cortex of the monkey brain. This advance enables us to innovate a technique for targeted manipulation of the prefrontal circuit and alter the monkey’s cognitive behavior in real-time, a key step toward advanced brain- machine interfaces and novel enhancing or therapeutic interventions in the human brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic widespread pain (CWP) is an obesity-related disparity that disproportionately burdens non-Hispanic Black and Hispanic/Latino/a/x adults with obesity. Bariatric surgery is often prescribed for obesity and musculoskeletal pain comorbidities, but there is significant intra-group variability in pain improvement. The proposed work will identify key driver(s) of pain resolution or maintenance after bariatric surgery that could serve as targets for culturally informed, multimodal pain interventions for adults with obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Photomedicine avoids traditional side effects of systemic chemotherapy, yet effective outcomes are dependent on direct irradiation from an external light source that limits the scope and the types of cancers that may be treated. This proposal develops a precision photomedicine platform that exploits natural disease-homing properties of the immune system to mediate bioluminescent-activated phototherapy, which will be evaluated in 3D cancer–immune co-culture and a mouse model of cancer metastases by paring with our tumor-targeted, activatable photoimmunotherapy platform. Successful, proof-of-concept studies will establish a new paradigm of systemic, whole-body phototherapy by enabling immune cell-based light delivery to deep and diffuse metastatic disease that would otherwise be impractical to treat using an external light source, thereby overcoming a major limitation of conventional phototherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Social adversity is strongly associated with susceptibility to diseases of aging, as well as with lifespan itself. These patterns are also observable in other social mammals, suggesting that animal models can be strategically leveraged to understand how social environments influence aging in humans. This proposal supports a Research Network for integrating animal models into studies of social aging, with the goal of mentoring and recruiting new investigators, building visibility across disciplines, and ultimately producing a self- sustaining research community that helps improve human health and well-being during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Heart transplantation is a potentially life-saving treatment for end-stage heart failure but unfortunately donors are scarce and only a fortunate minority of patients receive hearts. Current heart allocation policy relies on the intensity of treatment to decide who receives a heart, but this system cannot consistently identify the sickest candidates who stand to benefit the most from heart transplantation. This proposal aims to improve heart allocation by 1) developing a data-driven, objective heart allocation score with cutting-edge machine learning techniques, and 2) building novel, more flexible simulation software.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With more than 1,000 Fontan palliations performed in children with single ventricles in the US every year, there is a burgeoning population of Fontan patients at risk for progressive heart failure and death. The proposed research will assess the impact of a live-video-supervised exercise intervention on key health measures that have been associated with poor long-term outcomes in pediatric Fontan patients. Our ultimate goal is the translation of this model to clinical application as an ”exercise prescription” to intervene early in pediatric Fontan patients and decrease long-term morbidity and mortality, in alignment with the NIH’s mission to develop evidence-based data for new approaches to improve outcomes in youth with chronic conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer-specific mortality in the US, and Hispanics experience worse lung cancer outcomes due to advanced stage at presentation. Lung cancer screening (LCS) can save lives and improve disparities through early detection among Hispanic current and former smokers. Still, without tailored interventions, Hispanics will continue to die from lung cancer at higher rates. This K08 NCI proposal entitled Health Opportunities & Promoters of Equitable Screening for Lung Cancer (HOPES for Lung Cancer) offers an innovative approach to promote LCS uptake among Hispanic current and former smokersby elucidating barriers and facilitators to consistent documentation of smoking status to promote LCS uptake opportunities and leveraging the rise of digital health to assess the reach of the digital delivery of an educational video tailored to promote LCS uptake among Hispanic communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposed studies address how sigaling molecules converge on chromatin to regulate chromatin remodeling, tissue-specific gene expression and tissue differentiation. Using skeletal muscle differentiation as a model, our work will provide molecular mechanisms defining how signaling pathways modify a specific chromatin remodeling enzyme to mediate embryonic and adult skeletal muscle differentiation and maintenance. The work will have significant impact on our overall understanding of muscle development in the embryo and muscle regeneration in the adult. This work will also increase our understanding of changes that occur in muscle diseases where increased muscle growth (hypertrophy) or reduced muscle development (hypotrophy) are exhibited and on the formation of rhabdomyosarcomas, which are tumors of myogenic derivation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH End-stage renal disease (ESRD) is most effectively treated by renal transplantation, but 46% of deceased- donor and 28% of living-donor grafts will fail by ten years after transplantation predominantly (63%) due to chronic antibody-mediated rejection (AMR). AMR is currently detected by invasive biopsy with associated safety risks. The goal of this work is to develop an ultrasound-based, noninvasive alternative to biopsy to safely detect AMR and monitor its response to treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Crohn’s disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that has no cure and often leads to disease complications requiring bowel resection surgery. The origin of two phenomena correlating with development of Crohn’s disease complications, mesenteric adipose tissue wrapping around inflamed intestine, or “creeping fat”, and circulating anti-microbial antibodies, are poorly understood. By studying how Crohn’s disease-specific bacterial translocation to mesenteric adipose tissue leads to activation of stromal cells and adipocytes, in turn driving inflammatory B cell responses, this proposal has the potential to uncover mechanisms underlying CD pathology, identify novel therapeutic targets, and expand the study of mucosal immunology to mucosa-associated adipose tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal addresses the emerging concern that paternal exposure to toxicants such as arsenic affects sperm quality and male fertility in offspring. It seeks to identify unique changes in sperm RNAs that explain the intergenerational effects and the sensitive period in the life course to such insult. Its long-term goal is to understand how gene-environment interactions bring about the disease across generations through modified small RNA population.

PHR: Project Narrative The successful completion of this project will lead to new insights into mechanisms involved in the pathophysiology of type 2 diabetes mellitus and will advance an innovative method to ameliorate these disease mechanisms. IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: The National Academy of Sciences has identified a critical shortage of veterinarians in biomedical research careers. The proposed training program provides veterinary students early in their veterinary school careers with training in all aspects of biomedical research, and provides them with information and advice on biomedical research careers. Outcomes data indicate that Program graduates are much more likely to pursue further education, PhD training, and research careers in academia, industry, or government, and are less likely to pursue private practice clinical careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal responses to stress have long-term effects on offspring, through as yet poorly undertood mechanisms. We have discovered that the stress-induced release of serotonin from maternal neurons in C. elegans enables the transcription factor, HSF1 to modify chromatin in pre-fertilized oocytes through a piRNA-mediated chromatin silencing mechanism, and thereby influence offspring development and stress-resilience. Here we propose to understand the molecular mechanisms by which this occurs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: The current treatment strategies have failed patients diagnosed with diffuse midline glioma (DMG) driven by oncogenic histone H3 mutations (H3.3K27M and H3.1K27M) as less than 20% of patients will survive two years post-diagnosis. The overall goals of this research are to characterize novel roles for genes regulating Pol II transcriptional elongation in promoting DMG tumorigenesis and to determine how H3K27M mutant histones co- opt the activity of specific elongation factors to induce aberrant transcription underlying DMG malignancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. CCNE1-amplified ovarian cancer is among the most aggressive forms of ovarian cancer and is associated with primary treatment resistance and reduced overall survival. Despite intense efforts, targeted therapies for the treatment of this disease remain elusive, in part, due to the paucity of druggable molecular targets. Here we present a new approach to selectively target CCNE1-amplified ovarian cancer and describe novel small- molecules that will enable the preclinical evaluation of this strategy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Children with brain cancer have a dismal prognosis and urgently need new therapy options. This project will investigate “theranostic” (combined therapeutic and diagnostic) nanoparticles (TNPs) activated by specific tumor enzymes to release the highly potent therapeutic drug azademethylcolchicine. Because TNPs are only activated in brain cancers, this strategy circumvents dose-limiting toxic effects to the normal brain, and can lead to substantially more efficacious brain cancer therapies than currently available.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: With advanced age there is an increased likelihood of disturbances that impact the quality and quantity of sleep. Unraveling the underlying mechanisms that contribute to sleep disturbances in aging – which may lead to new therapeutic approaches to alleviate these outcomes– is of great importance. The following proposal is designed to test the novel hypothesis that kynurenic acid represents is a key molecular link between aging and sleep disturbances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma is the most common cancer originating in the brain with ~12,000 new diagnoses per year in the U.S.A. and median survival about 18 months. Miami has formed a partnership with ViewRay Inc., makers of a new combination MRI and radiation therapy (RT) device (MRIdian), to improve daily MRI acquisition and processing during RT to identify early glioblastoma growth. Using this data, we will identify glioblastomas that would benefit from earlier, more aggressive intervention to improve survival of patients with glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative - The role of liver progenitor cells in liver regeneration In the proposed work, we will utilize a severe hepatocyte injury model in adult zebrafish combined with single-cell transcriptomic and high-resolution imaging analyses to investigate whether and when biliary epithelial cells undergo transcriptional and morphological changes to become hepatocytes. We will elucidate the role of biliary epithelial cells as facultative liver stem cells and define signaling pathways to enhance liver regeneration. The results of this work may reveal therapeutic opportunities to enhance biliary-derived liver regeneration after severe hepatocyte injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the neural mechanisms of attention, the subject of this project, are central to human cognition and its impairments in a wide range of neurological and psychiatric disorders, including hemispatial neglect and simultagnosia. Studies proposed in this application will determine the neural circuits and elucidate the neural mechanisms that control the focus of attention, a core cognitive function. Thus the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite intensive efforts to understand the molecular mechanism underlying the neuroadaptations associated with addiction phenotypes, current knowledge can only partially explain which cell type orchestrates specific transcriptional responses to addictive drugs in the brain. By systematically analyzing the cell-type specific transcriptional and chromatin accessibility changes that occur in brain regions of rat with different history of oxycodone use, this application aims to provide unprecedented insights in the biological basis of opiate addiction. This project focuses on the emerging and complex problem of prescription pain relievers and opioids abuse in this country.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our genetic material, albeit being nearly identical from one person to another, is littered with many variations, some of which are associated with the development and progression of Alzheimer's Disease (AD). In this project, we are proposing a robust and economical approach that will enable identification and study of AD-associated genetic variations. The resulting data is expected to transform our mechanistic understanding of disease progression, and identify potential targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Breast cancer is only rarely cured by chemotherapy because tumor cells can survive by entering cellular senescence, which results in early relapse and poor patient survival. Senescence enables evasion of death by mitotic catastrophe and apoptosis by arresting the cell cycle, and, as we recently discovered, death by nutrient depletion is averted by a novel cell engulfment phenotype. The goal of this project is to identify the mechanisms of immune evasion by senescent cells and how this can be therapeutically targeted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Although the current SARS-CoV-2 vaccines have shown impressive protective capacity upon subsequent exposure, recent emergence of new viral variants threaten to significantly reduce the efficacy of these vaccines. Whether lung resident anti-viral memory T cells are generated and can promote a second line of protection against SARS-CoV-2 infection is currently unknown. In this proposal we will study the ability of SARS-CoV-2 infection or vaccination to promote tissue resident memory T cell generation in mice and humans and whether these memory T cell populations can provide significant protective ability in animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The time demands of cancer and its treatments are significant and take away from other activities important to individuals with cancer. Using automated sensor data, we will measure objective cancer-related time use over a 28-day period, augmented by self-reported specific cancer activities, well-being, and quality of life to develop a scoring system of cancer-related time burden among adults with advanced ovarian or metastatic breast cancer. The project will have a positive impact by creating measures of cancer-related objective time use and subjective burden, enabling us to develop and measure the efficacy of future interventions to reduce cancer time demands.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurocognitive impairment (NCI) in persons living with HIV infection (PWH) is a major public health challenge that is expected to grow as PWH reach older age. This proposal will determine whether women with HIV are more vulnerable to NCI than men with HIV due to greater burden and progression of cerebrovascular injury from increased susceptibility to the effects of CVD risk factors and immune activation. Understanding sex differences in the mechanisms driving the development of NCI in PWH will inform the rational design of clinical trials of preventive and therapeutic strategies optimized by sex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Understanding why lymphoma patients respond or are resistant to state-of-the-art immune therapies is essential for these approaches to reach their full potential. To understand the impact of immune therapies on direct tumor killing and reactivation of the immune system, we propose to directly visualize in vivo the dynamic interplay of lymphoma B cells with their microenvironments in the spleen of the syngeneic mouse model upon immune therapies by 6- color and longitudinal three-photon microscopy. This study will provide the first direct evidence for the nature of the anti-lymphoma immune response and the manner in which lymphomas evade host immune cells and CAR T cells, allowing us to generate new hypotheses for the design of combination immune therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Worldwide, corneal scars are a leading cause of monocular blindness. Initial wound healing responses can prevent infection but subsequent tissue repair often results in scarring that leads to obstructed vision or blindness. Our proposed research is focused on the molecular underpinnings of a novel anti-scarring target for the cornea.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver cancer is a deadly form of malignancy with limited treatment options. The proposal seeks to understand the functional roles of mTORC2/AKT, TSC/mTORC1 and FOXO1 cascades during liver tumorigenesis. The study is likely to provide new insight into the signaling pathways in liver tumor development and strong evidence to support the development of therapeutics targeting mTOR and FOXO1 as new treatment strategies for this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because we will use advances in brain imaging and machine learning prognostic modeling to considerably reduce time to diagnosis of learning and behavioral problems and subsequent school readiness. This will allow earlier, more targeted interventions, thereby reducing rates of developmental disorders and school failure. The project is relevant to NINDS’ mission because this approach should yield fundamental knowledge about the most common developmental disorders in children born very preterm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to study the delicate balance between two essential types of white blood cells, which provide protection against infection but can also dangerously contribute to inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD). Prior research highlights how the bacteria that peacefully live within our intestines can heavily influence this equilibrium, but the specific conditions that lead to either type of imbalance remain a mystery. Our work to define all the cells and molecules involved in this process will uncover brand-new therapeutic targets to optimally treat IBD while minimizing infectious risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and other neurodegenerative diseases involve a loss of brain function and brain cells over time and eventually cause death, affecting one third of people over the age of 85. Recent research has found that brain cells build up new mutations in the DNA (known as somatic mutations) as we get older, which appears to harm the brain cells. This proposal will test the hypothesis that somatic mutations contribute in important ways to Alzheimer’s disease, and are related to two other kinds of disease damage in brain cells, oxidative stress and Tau neurofibrillary tangles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement This project seeks to develop a new understanding of how the spinal cord controls motor output through advancement of experimental and statistical approaches by recording the discharge of spinal neuron populations. We will use this approach to better understand acute and chronic changes in the firing of spinal neurons following spinal cord injury. This knowledge will provide new avenues to improve and monitor rehabilitation following neurological injury.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Chronic non-cancer pain is common among Veterans, and more work is needed to understand how best to support Veterans with chronic pain to improve pain-related function and quality of life. Peer specialists may be valuable resource to support Veterans in pain management. Peer specialists, individuals with lived experience who are hired and trained to work with Veterans, are increasingly being used outside traditional mental health settings. More research is needed to understand how best to train peer specialists to work in new settings and with new presenting problems, such as chronic pain. Peer support to help Veterans improve pain-related function, increase physical activity, and engage in recommended pain care, is especially needed. In this study, we will finalize a peer-led intervention and then pilot it with 24 Veterans with chronic pain in order to establish feasibility and acceptability; results will be used to develop a larger proposal testing our intervention in a randomized trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Tau pathology causes shrinkage of brain tissue (neurodegeneration) and ultimately cognitive decline in Alzheimer’s disease (AD), but some people have more or less tissue shrinkage than expected for a given level of tau in specific brain regions. This project will study the regional patterns of this “mismatch” between pathology and brain damage as a tool to categorize people who may be more vulnerable to decline due to other underlying conditions or more resilient to brain damage. This approach may ultimately help improve clinical management, make drug trials more efficient, and enhance understanding of the heterogeneity in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Urinary tract infections (UTIs) and specifically catheter-associated UTIs (CAUTIs) and stent infections pose increasing problems for treatments due to increasing antibiotic resistance. Further, catheter and stent- associated infection management is complicated by the polymicrobial nature of these infections. This proposal aims to greatly increase our clinical knowledge and understanding of mechanisms by which polymicrobial communities form on urinary medical devices, direct same-day antimicrobial resistance (AMR) gene profiling to improve antibiotic stewardship and develop antibiotic-sparing treatment therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lyme disease is the most common arthropod-borne illness in the United States. The causative agent, Borrelia burgdorferi, maintains itself in nature through a complex tick-mammal life cycle involving an Ixodes tick vector and mammalian hosts. This study will elucidate molecular components critical for the maintenance of the infectious cycle of B. burgdorferi, which will provide new modalities for the development of innovative disease intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE The olfactory epithelium is not only important for the sense of smell, but also as a site of immune defense against inhaled microbes and viruses. In this proposal, we utilize mouse models and human samples to study how olfactory tissue defends itself and the body against infection and injury. The experiments will provide new insights into neuro-immune interactions in the olfactory system, which will potentially lead to new strategies for treating the loss of the sense of smell, which is a health problem that markedly diminishes the quality of life of affected individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric diabetes has been steadily increasing in recent decades by far greater rates than can be predicted by diet and lifestyle alone. This research utilizes computational modeling to characterize how exposures to pharmacological or toxicological agents during development can impair pancreatic organogenesis and potentially predispose individuals to diabetes later in the lifecourse. Here, we employ a rigorous multilayer network and topological clustering approach, rather than simple regression, to build predictive quantitative structure-activity relationship (QSAR) models and adverse outcome pathways (AOPs) with broader toxicological translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Physicians’ struggle to accurately distinguish patients who will awaken from coma after cardiac arrest from those with irrecoverable injury. This proposal brings together a diverse team of world-class experts in post- arrest care, statistical modeling and machine learning to develop a tool that rapidly and accurately delivers prognostic information to doctors. Improving the speed and accuracy of post-arrest prognostication will save lives, allow appropriate resources to be directed to patients who are likely to benefit, avoid long and difficult care for patients who cannot recover, and spare families the agony of prolonged uncertainty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: In 2018, more than 60,000 people died from opioid overdose. The rapid escalation of opioid substance abuse that contributes to the development of addiction is, in part, driven by activation of endogenous opioid systems in nucleus accumbens, a brain area implicated in mediating the pleasurable and rewarding effects of natural and drug rewards (Koob and Volkow 2016; Richard et al. 2013). Therefore, the goal of this proposal is to refine and elucidate the mechanistic substrates of this opioid system in motivation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Modulation of the cellular composition of immunologically cold tumors such as glioblastoma (GBM) may be a useful approach for combination treatments alongside systemic immunotherapies. We have identified that delivery of chemically-modified derivatives of the Chinese traditional medicine component indirubin via a novel nanoparticle formulation promotes survival of GBM-bearing mice and alters tumor cellular composition. Here we will perform mechanistic and survival studies in mouse GBM models to provide support for new therapeutic approaches in GBM patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Primary cilium is an important cellular organelle that senses and integrates cell signaling responses to environmental cues. Human ciliopathies comprise a wide spectrum of human diseases caused by ciliary defects. Due to major gaps in our knowledge about ciliary structure and signaling, the molecular bases of ciliary dysfunction in many ciliopathies remain obscure. Our proposal is aimed at elucidating the mechanisms underpinning cell signaling of a ciliopathy-associated protein kinase that has a highly conserved role in negative regulation of ciliogenesis and cilia length. Anticipated outcomes from this continuation proposal will significantly advance our understanding of the basic mechanisms underlying human ciliopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding how elevated NADH contributes to non-alcoholic and alcoholic fatty liver disease will enable novel approaches to treat these conditions, which are the most common forms of liver disease in the United States but which have no effective pharmacologic therapies. Thus, the proposed project is relevant to the NIH’s mission to seek and apply knowledge to lengthen life and reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it represents a new and alternative strategy for detecting lung nodules that would have been otherwise missed. This project will show clear and reliable behavioral and physiological biomarkers of non-conscious detection at the location of missed lung nodules using high-speed eye-tracking. These eye-tracking biomarkers of non-conscious detection can be used to train Machine Learning modules to detect the location of missed nodule: disrupting the current standard in Radiology AI by reading the radiologist and not the image, making use of the full trained expertise of the radiologist by tapping into these non-conscious expert processes, and improving detection accuracy and subsequent cancer outcomes beyond that currently constrained by solely conscious recognition. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NCI's mission to reduce lung cancer and increase cancer survival rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate how the brain uses rules to guide our behavior. Rules define how we should act in a given situation and so disrupting one’s ability to learn and follow rules carries significant social and economic costs for many neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative diseases, including schizophrenia. Our work will provide insight into the neural mechanisms of rule-based behavior, providing the foundation for a better understanding of these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients receiving radiotherapy for rectal cancers often suffer from debilitating side-effects due to radiation damage to tissues surrounding the tumor. Currently, there are no radioprotectors approved to be used with rectal cancer radiotherapy. An antioxidant drug, BMX-001, shows promise as an effective, clinical, radioprotector because the drug protects healthy tissues from radiation damage while, simultaneously, inhibiting growth of colorectal cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE  The annual health care costs for neurodegenerative disorders range in excess of a hundred billion dollars. Sadly, we do not have cure yet for any of these diseases. Understanding cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying effects of apolipoprotein E (apoE) on the cerebrovascular system and how these effects may contribute to development of neuronal dysfunction and neurodegeneration, amyloid-beta and tau disorders will have profound implications for our understanding of Alzheimer’s disease pathogenesis and may ultimately guide the development of new therapeutic approaches for this devastating brain disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autophagy is a recycling process with the ability to recruit selective type of cytosolic components like lipid droplets and protein aggregates for degradation. While accumulating evidence indicates that these selective types of autophagy play crucial roles in cellular health maintenance with application to age-related diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease, the regulatory functions of selective autophagy remain elusive. I will study the molecular mechanisms of lipophagy in the cells to further understand how lipophagy can be regulated during aging and neurodegeneration, using a small molecule approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Current IBD therapies often fail as a long-term treatment option and have undesirable side effects, leaving an unmet clinical need for new strategies that can sustain immune tolerance in IBD. The current proposal is aimed at understanding PD1 signaling in IBD patients, a major pathway implicated in peripheral immune tolerance, and leveraging these insights to maximize the efficacy of PD1 agonist monotherapy and low-dose IL-2 combination therapy in humanized IBD mouse models. The successful completion of this clinically-oriented proposal has the potential to advance novel therapies for IBD and other autoimmune disease patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health: The current clinical method to evaluate and classify neurological impairment of spinal cord injury (International Standards for Neurological Classification of Spinal Cord Injury (ISNCSCI)), causes anxiety in children up to eight years of age, is difficult to administer (invasive), and does not provide a direct assessment of damage to white matter tracts within the spinal cord. The creation of the first pediatric spinal cord structural template, which will be made available to the scientific community, will allow for examination of the spinal cord in a standardized space for group studies and can remove user variability during the analysis process. Also, if functional imaging measures such as DTI, DKI, NODDI, and SCCSA can be established as valid and reliable methods to quantify viable neural tissue within the spinal cord in young children, it will be a critical non invasive neurodiagnostic tool and a useful adjunct to the current ISNCSCI (The Standards).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Antibodies have emerged as one of the most powerful and effective classes of drugs to treat a wide variety of human diseases including cancer, autoimmunity and inflammatory conditions. While much effort in the past has been devoted to engineering antibodies to recognize distinct targets, the next generation of antibodies will derive enhanced clinical efficacy from engineering efforts aimed at manipulating the manner in which antibodies engage immune receptors and the subsequent immune system reactions that they induce, which is driven nearly entirely by sugar molecules attached to the antibody. Experiments proposed in this application are designed to create a suite of uniquely glycosylated antibodies with customized effects on stimulating the immune system that could form the basis of a new generation of monoclonal antibody therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the fundamental biology of bacterial phenotypic heterogeneity during infection will improve care success. Although Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Pa) is a leading cause of hospital acquired infections and chronic cystic fibrosis lung infections, there is a little information about why some Pa successfully transition from the environmental reservoirs to humans. This project aims to elucidate how cyclic-di-GMP metabolism and single cell variation alters the success of Pa during this important transition.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is an important human pathogen. The knowledge gained from our studies will be important for improving the treatments for chronic HBV patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Neurons are able to restore their activity when challenged by external or internal perturbations. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative  Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), the causative agent of tuberculosis (TB), is one of the deadliest pathogens on the planet, and TB is one of the leading causes of death due to infectious disease. The cell envelope of Mtb forms a barrier around the cell, protecting the bacterium from antibiotics and our immune system. We will study protein-based systems that facilitate the transport of nutrients across the cell envelope, including the building blocks of the barrier itself, which may aid in the design of new antibiotics to treat TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE As programmatic and research efforts shift from malaria control to malaria elimination, understanding host, parasite and environmental factors that contribute to parasite investment in sexual reproduction versus asexual replication will be critical for predicting the impact of new interventions on malaria transmission. In this study, we will examine the effect of host, parasite, and environmental factors on P. falciparum sexual commitment and gametocytemia in the context of a longitudinal cohort study, with particular emphasis on the impact of infection complexity and clone composition on gametocyte production by a given clone. In addition to providing important insights into parasite biology, we anticipate that this research will provide actionable associations to predict transmission reservoirs and identify target populations for transmission-reducing interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Up to 30% of patients with treatment refractory ulcerative colitis (UC) require colon removal and the creation of an ileal pouch anal anastomosis (IPAA) to serve as an internal pelvic stool reservoir and allow for defecation per anus. Approximately 20% of patients with an IPAA develop Crohn’s disease-like pouch inflammation (CDLPI) which causes symptoms similar to their original UC, and up to 50% of these patients do not respond to therapy and require surgical pouch removal and the creation of a permanent ostomy. We aim to characterize the genetic variants, ileal transcriptome, microbial and metabolomic profiles associated with CDLPI in patients with UC after IPAA in order to identify predictive disease markers and potential therapeutic strategies.

PHR: High blood pressure is the leading cause of cardiovascular disease and death world-wide. Young women are protected against high blood pressure, but this protection is lost after menopause, indicating a crucial role for estrogen. This study is designed to investigate the role of a new estrogen receptor and previous pregnancy on blood pressure later in life in women, with the intension of understanding the potential of targeting estrogen signaling in elder women suffering from high blood pressure.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project focuses on studying a new mechanism leading to salt-sensitive hypertension, which contributes to substantial morbidity, mortality, and healthcare costs. The proposed research will study a novel role of a cytoskeletal protein—previously known to be linked to glomerular disease— in sodium homeostasis and blood pressure regulation. Defining the role of this protein in salt-sensitivity will provide critical insights into salt- sensitive hypertension, laying the foundation for future targets for anti-hypertensive therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While mechanically assisted circulation (MAC), such as mechanical circulatory support (MCS) with ventricular assist devices (VADs), extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) and cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB), is routinely implemented to treat patients with advanced heart failure and respiratory failure, infections are a common postoperative complication in patients with MAC. Infections can develop into life-threatening events. Current MAC devices are based almost exclusively on rotary blood pump technology, in which an impeller rotating at high-speed pumps the blood, inevitably resulting in high mechanical shear stress (HMSS) that can damage blood components, including leukocytes. The goal of this project is to gain a better understanding of HMSS-induced neutrophil dysfunction associated with MAC through quantifiable measurements with well- controlled experiments. This knowledge can be used by clinicians to better diagnose and treat patients, and by engineers to develop less traumatic, next-generation biocompatible devices for MAC therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure and muscular dystrophy are devastating diseases that affect tens of millions of people worldwide, and while these disorders are highly complex in nature, a common feature they share is dysregulated calcium signaling. We recently discovered a small protein called DWORF that can rescue calcium defects in the heart when it is overexpressed and protects from disease. The studies proposed here will leverage a newly developed gene therapy strategy that is optimized for enhanced heart and skeletal muscle gene delivery to comprehensively test the therapeutic potential of DWORF as a novel gene therapy target for the treatment of heart failure and muscular dystrophy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is used to treat life-threatening blood disorders and often requires a healthy living donor. Recent medical advances have allowed parents to donate to their children and vice versa, but little is known about how these parent/child donors experience the donation process – particularly if the recipient has complications or dies. With this project, we hope to better understand donor experiences and quality-of-life and how transplant physicians make decisions about when to use a parent or child donor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epilepsy surgery can result in seizure freedom in patients with drug-resistant epilepsy. Current clinical tools that guide surgical decisions are limited, in part due to an incomplete understanding of brain connectivity patterns in focal epilepsy. Using magnetic resonance imaging and intracranial recordings, we will develop new network- based tools that can be applied broadly at epilepsy centers to improve patient selection, outcome prediction, and localization of surgical targets in epilepsy surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Anterior cruciate ligament tears are a common injury, and in spite of surgical reconstruction and rehabilitation there remain significant impairments in the quadriceps muscle, which contribute to poor long term outcomes. This project has identified a molecular signature of quadriceps neuromuscular dysfunction that contributes to the initial loss of quadriceps muscle strength. An innovative combination of pre-clinical studies and a mechanistic clinical trial will determine the ability of neuromuscular electrical stimulation to mitigate this early molecular signature and restore quadriceps strength.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH CTR AT TYLER
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks to define new regimens of drugs at optimal dose combinations to cure pulmonary Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infections for which current therapeutic regimens are empirical and clinical trial evidence to guide precision dosing is lacking. When causing the disease, MAC pathogens are inside the cells, thus, we selected the drugs for this proposal based on their ability to penetrate and accumulate inside cells, thereby effectively killing the MAC in relatively less time compared to the current guideline-based combination regimen. Since the safety and toxicity profile of the proposed drugs in humans is well documented, the new short-course regimens could be quickly advanced into clinics for the treatment of MAC pulmonary disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Metoidioplasty and Phalloplasty Gender Affirming Surgeries (MaPGAS) are complex, high risk procedures that require patients to make several decisions affecting long term gender congruence, fertility, urinary and sexual health. Many patients considering MaPGAS have decisional uncertainty without access to validated decision support which limits the quality of shared decision making, potentially leading to poor quality decisions and unexpected outcomes. The purpose of this study is to 1) evaluate the usability, acceptability, and 2) preliminary efficacy of a novel, community developed web based MaPGAS decision aid designed to reduce decisional uncertainty, improve decision readiness, and facilitate quality MaPGAS shared decision making.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drosophila is an important model organism used extensively in evolutionary and developmental biology studies. Drosophila research laboratories often maintain hundreds to thousands of genetically modified stocks, requiring routine maintenance and risk of strain loss or genetic drift. The goal of this project is to develop autonomous cryopreservation methods for Drosophila, such that strains can be banked indefinitely and available for on- demand use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the eradication of smallpox, members of the poxviridae family remain Category A Priority Pathogens and pandemic threats while others are used as oncolytic therapeutics and vaccine vectors. With their unusual level of self-sufficiency and cytoplasmic mode of DNA replication, mechanisms of host sensing and poxvirus evasion strategies are highly complex, and many outstanding questions remain. This proposal explores a unique strategy whereby poxviruses dysregulate the activity of the metabolic sensor and effector kinase, mTOR, to counteract poorly understood aspects of innate responses to infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The effective causative therapies for Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and related dementias associated with Frontotemporal Lobar Degeneration disorders (FTLDs) remain elusive as the patients are often diagnosed at an advanced disease stage. Non-coding RNAs, including those longer than 200 nucleotides referred to as long- noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs), have recently emerged as key regulators of brain functions derailed in AD and FTLDs. The unprecedented combination of human postmortem brain tissue and plasma samples from cross- sectional and longitudinal epidemiologic studies, Alzheimer’s Disease Neuroimaging Initiative, Framingham Heart Study, and Germany’s cognitive impairment and dementia studies, enables us to study lncRNA expression in human cortex, perform functional studies of disease lncRNA biomarker candidates in experimental models, and determine if brain disease lncRNA biomarker candidates may be found in plasma as specific biomarkers for AD and FTLDs permitting subsequent testing of stratified therapeutic approaches in future studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  T cells engineered to express chimeric antigen receptors (CARs) can cure some patients with B cell cancers but have failed to meet their potential of widespread efficacy. In this proposal we aim to elucidate how a core CAR functional domain that normally supports T cell function can instead drive a novel form of T cell failure when persistently activated. We further evaluate genome engineering strategies to overcome this failure, with the goal of developing more effective CAR-based therapies that can cure more patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because IgE antibodies that recognize innocuous environmental, food, or insect proteins cause allergic diseases that affect more than twenty percent of the world’s population. Although little is known regarding the role of sugars attached to IgE our preliminary data suggests these sugars play important roles in IgE biology. This project is relevant to the mission of NIH because it will generate basic immunology knowledge relating to the role of the sugars in relating IgE-mediated inflammation, and will establish IgE-related sugars as novel biomarkers and therapeutic targets for allergic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes affects more than 8 million people worldwide, shortens lifespan by an average of 10 years, and increases the risk of all ten leading causes of death in the United States. Despite strong evidence that tight control of blood sugar reduces the risk of diabetes complications, most people with type 1 diabetes do not achieve recommended blood sugar targets. This randomized controlled trial will test whether a very-low- carbohydrate ketogenic diet can effectively and safely improve blood sugar control in adults with type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinicians rely on pulse oximeters to non-invasively estimate oxygen levels in the blood, which is a key piece of data used for diagnosis and treatment of sick children. Studies in adults indicate that pulse oximeters may be less accurate in people with dark skin color, and we therefore seek to investigate how accurate pulse oximeters are in children with different skin colors. Ensuring pulse oximeter accuracy across skin colors is essential for effective and equitable care and the findings of this study will be widely relevant to the millions of children who seek healthcare each year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have made a number of unexpected observations regarding vitamin A storage and metabolism in important cells within the adult lungs and its critical role in maintaining lung health. The studies being proposed in this application are paradigm-shifting for understanding the mechanisms of how local vitamin A stores are acquired, redistributed and processed among the cells, and how these are understood by the research field. The outcomes of these studies will impact the current strategies, including nutritional interventions, aimed at alleviating lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Major musculoskeletal trauma, such as volumetric muscle loss (VML), requires advanced regenerative therapies capable of bulk muscle tissue replacement while promoting myogenesis and neurovascular integration. We are advancing the first pre-innervated three-dimensional Tissue Engineered Motor Units (3D-TEMUs) comprising dense centimeter-scale bundles of fascicle-like, aligned myofibers fabricated through the guided self-assembly of human induced-pluripotent stem cell derived skeletal myocytes with axonal inputs from discrete pools of motor neurons. This project will advance the fields of muscle biology and bioengineering by validating a new class of 3D engineered composite soft tissue capable of serving as a biofidelic testbed to study neuromuscular development as well as an implantable substrate to replace lost muscle and augment regeneration following VML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Sleep in depression is characterized by disinhibited rapid eye movement (REM) sleep with an increased density of rapid eye movements. The proposed studies aim to dissect the circuit mechanisms by which the prefrontal cortex, a brain area hyperactivated in depressed patients, regulates REM sleep and the eye movement density through interaction with subcortical areas in hypothalamus and brainstem. The results are a critical precursor to understanding the causal relationship between cortical dysfunction in psychiatric disorders and sleep disturbances.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Chronic liver diseases, including non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), alcoholic liver disease (ALD), and cholestatic liver diseases, are major health problems both for Veterans and the general population. Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a trauma- and stressor-related mental disorder which poses a significant impact on veterans’ health. The prevalence of PTSD is much higher in Veterans than in general populations, especially in combat Veterans. PTSD can result in end-organ damage, such as liver cirrhosis. Both cirrhosis and PTSD independently lead to dysregulation of the gut microbiome and brain dysfunction. Understanding bile acids and sphingolipids in regulating hepatic lipid metabolism, immunity, and biliary function under different pathological conditions will provide a foundation for discovering new diagnostic markers and novel pharmaceutical interventions for the prevention and treatment of various liver diseases and PTSD-associated liver injury, which are important problems for our Veteran patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Taste is important for making decisions about what to eat, and altered taste perception is associated with obesity and eating disorders. This proposal uses a tractable model system, the fruit fly, to investigate basic mechanisms of how taste signals are processed in the brain. Given the similarities in how flies and mammals respond to taste, we expect to uncover fundamental principles of taste processing that generalize across species, laying the groundwork to study how these mechanisms are dysregulated in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Powassan virus (POWV) is a tick-borne virus that causes a 10% fatal brain disease, and a new tick POWV isolate, LI9, was found to cause highly lethal brain damage in aged mice, a finding that mimics POWV disease in elderly patients. In contrast, an attenuated POWV, LI9-P, fails to cause brain damage in mice and is a potential vaccine that differs in its ability to regulate antiviral responses of cells that form brain barriers. Paired lethal and attenuated POWVs, and our unique ability to modify POWVs, permit us to propose defining determinants of POWV disease, mechanisms of POWV entry into the brain, age-dependent POWV virulence mechanisms and potential inhibitors of brain damage applicable to elderly POWV patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Nearly all pregnant individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus experience either maternal or newborn morbidity, with disparities seen in socially disadvantaged groups. The proposed study seeks to improve outcomes in pregnant individuals with type 2 diabetes by testing the effectiveness of continuous glucose monitoring, which was shown to be beneficial in type 1 diabetes pregnancies. Successful completion of the study will not only determine if continuous glucose monitoring is superior to self-monitoring of blood glucose, but also identify optimal glucose targets for management of type 2 diabetes in pregnancy and the key social determinants of health affecting outcomes in this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic peripheral nervous system injuries have a devastating impact on patient quality of life and currently lack therapies for consistent functional recovery. The proposed project will develop and demonstrate the feasibility of an ultrashock-mediated, biocompatible, piezoelectric scaffold integrated with integrated bioactivity. The scaffold will transmit the necessary electrical, physical, and chemical signals to initiate and improve cell-biomaterial interactions, minimize the immune response, and facilitate peripheral nerve regeneration in critical injury gaps.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although cardiovascular congestion is the hallmark of heart failure our understanding of mechanisms that lead to cardiovascular congestion and potential treatment options remain limited. Supported by our recent work, cardiac congestion and decompensation could be the result of internal volume redistribution from the splanchnic vascular compartment but validation of this innovative concept and novel therapeutic intervention requires detailed physiological testing. During this project, we will test the safety and mechanisms of action of prolonged splanchnic nerve blockade on exercise performance in patients with chronic heart failure and we will learn relevant methodology in phenotyping patients with chronic heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE BRAF activating mutations occur in approximately 10% of metastatic colorectal cancer (CRCs) and are associated with worse prognosis due to an inferior response to standard chemotherapy. With the use of more potent targeted therapy, shifts in cell identity due to epithelial cell plasticity is an emerging cause of therapy resistance. The overall goal of this study is to develop an epigenetic inhibitor-based therapeutic strategy to block therapy-induced shifts in cell identity in BRAF mutant CRC and prolong responses to targeted therapy and improve clinical outcomes for patients with this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will integrate and analyze longitudinal multi-omics data, which spans epigenome, metabolome, and microbiome, to comprehensively characterize the molecular connections between maternal exposures to traffic-related air pollution and preterm birth among 700 participants in a socio-economically diverse, exceptionally phenotyped African American Maternal-Child cohort. The study approaches will include novel exposure assessment through existing external, traffic emission exposure modeling paired with internal, high-resolution multi-omics data integration. We expect this work to contribute to elucidating potentially sensitive TRAP biomarkers and preclinical indicators for PTB - a meaningful step for defining novel intervention strategies to mitigate traffic-related air pollution exposure risk and improve birth and health outcomes in exposed mothers and children.

PHR: Project Narrative Identifying neural markers of increased vulnerability for obesity in very young children exposed to maternal diabetes may enhance our understanding of etiologic pathways of obesity development and serve as a springboard for the development of early interventions before the risks manifest as long-term consequences. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Congenital Heart Defects (CHDs) are the major cause of mortality in children with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (DS), the most common deletion syndrome in humans. While it is known that the CHDs in 22q11.2DS patients are caused by reductions in the transcription factor TBX1, the precise mechanism remains unclear. Here, we will use zebrafish tbx1 mutants as a model of 22q11.2 DS to uncover how Tbx1 regulates cardiovascular development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Congenital heart disease (CHD) affects about 40,000 births per year (1%) in the United States and these children require life-long monitoring of their heart health. This project aims to develop, validate, and clinically evaluate a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) method to measure blood ﬂow in pediatric CHD patients. We will disseminate a “push-button” MRI package to increase diagnostic accuracy and improve clinical conﬁdence in decision making for pediatric CHD patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Public Health Relevance Information on how the risk of death varies with age during the late fetal and neonatal periods in a resource- poor setting like India represents critical evidence for health policy. This information, together with risk factors such as preterm, low birthweight and small for gestational age, will help understand which newborns are most at risk of death, guide policy action and improve progress for children. The present study will make important substantive and methodological contributions to understanding the dynamics of late fetal and neonatal mortality in the Indian context, with implications for other low- and middle-income countries where stillbirth and neonatal mortality rates remain high.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We plan to investigate the effect of implant design and surface architecture on the foreign body and fibrotic responses to glaucoma drainage implants. We will then incorporate optimal materials and surface features into a novel glaucoma drainage implant design and compare its effectiveness to commercially available implants. This research may influence the design of a next generation of implants with improved biological integration and long-term efficacy, and help prevent disease progression and vision loss in glaucoma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Diabetic cardiomyopathy is a major complication and the leading cause of death and disability in patients with diabetes. Exercise is an effective strategy for the prevention and treatment of diabetic cardiomyopathy, however, the underlying molecular mechanisms remain poorly understood. The proposed research will explore the role of METTL3, a N6-methyladenosine methyltransferase, in diabetic cardiomyopathy and the cardiac benefits of exercise, with the vision of establishing clinically relevant approaches targeting METTL3 to treat diabetic cardiomyopathy. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Gut bacterial pathogens need to obtain nutrients to colonize and infect intestinal environments. The consumption of preferred substrates and micronutrients by commensals offers opportunities to target critical events in pathogen colonization and infection. The pathogen Clostridioides difficile has a diverse metabolism that supports gut colonization. Using target fermentable substrates metabolized by protective commensals and/or by C. difficile, we will evaluate molecular mechanisms by which target fermentable substrates interact with the host, pathogen and commensals to modulate critical events in pathogen colonization, infection, and resolution. Findings will be evaluated in conventional mouse models to inform targeted approaches using small molecule, bacteriotherapeutic, or combined approaches to mitigate risks for these infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cannabis and alcohol are the two most widely used substances among emerging adults (~ ages 18-25), with elevated rates of use among sexual minoritized emerging adults in college settings. This K23 involves developing a technology-driven, app-based intervention with input from community partners (e.g., campus resource centers) and students with lived experience that will lead to the development of a novel adaptive intervention for sexual minoritized emerging adult college students who report cannabis and alcohol co-use (i.e., using both substances within the same period [e.g., past month], which could be different occasions or simultaneously so drug effects overlap). Given the high rates of smartphone use among this population, if the efficacy is established, this intervention will have great promise for increasing delivery of efficacious co-use interventions for sexual minoritized emerging adult college students, thereby benefiting public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this R01 proposal is to assess the efficacy of a new precision cancer targeting approach using CRISPR technology that brings together a “split” endonuclease precisely at structural variant junctions in bladder cancer cells. This approach is targeting only the cancer cells and is not dependent on the specific tumor biology of the cancer. This personalized and tumor-specific targeting approach is a paradigm-shifting platform technology that could transform bladder cancer treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative For patients with end-stage renal disease, kidney transplantation is the best clinical treatment. Weight and adipose gain following kidney transplantation has been implicated for deleterious cardiometabolic effects. This pilot and feasibility clinical trial is being implemented to evaluate the feasibility and plausible effectiveness of a lifestyle intervention on change in weight, effects on cardiometabolic biomarkers, and kidney function in kidney transplant recipients. If feasible and plausible this will provide the foundation for a full-scale clinical trial.

PHR: Project Narrative A molecular pathway that links N-glycosylation to birth defects Damage to cell-cell communications systems can cause a variety of human birth defects. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal we study the role of a novel inflammatory pathway in suppressing immune regulation and promoting allograft rejection. In particular, we study an inflammatory cytokine, macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF), secreted by myeloid cells and alloreactive T cells during rejection and inflammation that binds CD74 (MIF receptor) on the surface of activated Tregs to dampen their function and homeostasis with opposite effect on alloreactive T cells. These finding open the possibility of CD74 based therapies in transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is a type of stroke that usually results from rupture of an intracranial aneurysm. One of the most feared complications of SAH is delayed cerebral ischemia, which occurs in approximately 30- 50% of patients and is responsible for significant morbidity and mortality. This proposal uses a novel noninvasive optical instrument called pathlength resolved diffuse correlation spectroscopy to better understand the mechanisms of ischemic damages in patients with aneurysmal SAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Despite the availability and promise of transcranial alternating current stimulation, its effectiveness at arresting memory decline has hitherto been limited and highly variable across Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) patients. Our experimental AD model studies will leverage novel approaches to cellular-level interrogation of neuronal function and relate the cellular scale changes in brain activity elicited by tACS to mesoscopic scale changes in neurotransmitter levels and flux, and working memory. We will establish multi-scale machine learning models for predicting the effects of transcranial alternating current stimulation on neuronal activity and working memory using clinic-ready neuroimaging protocols, so as to lay the foundation for development of personalized neuromodulation interventions for treating memory deficits in the early stage of AD pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Top-down signals from higher-order cortical areas are crucial for appropriate cognitive control of sensory processing, behavior, and learning. Top-down processing is profoundly disrupted across a range of disease states including schizophrenia, autism spectrum disorder, addiction, and dementia. Here we simultaneously record somatic and dendritic activity in large networks of neurons to reveal how top-down inputs control learning, thereby providing general mechanistic principles for how cortex ultimately produces the computations that guide behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Targeting RAS-mutant tumors using RAF and MEK inhibitors has shown preclinical promise, but only modest results in the clinic. Our preliminary data indicate that the extent of tumor-selective inhibition of MAPK signaling by these drugs is determined by paralog and conformation selectivity of different biochemical classes of RAF and MEK inhibitors. This proposal is aimed at elucidating mechanisms determining tumor-selective potency of RAS pathway inhibitors to enable the design of more effective therapies for RAS-mutant cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The integration of biomarker guidance with transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) could individualize and optimize dosing to improve its clinical utility. We propose to develop a tDCS system that includes the collection of the nonspecific biomarker of heart rate variability (HRV), by validating impedance-based heart rate (i-HR) and its clinical response to tDCS intervention in adults with depression. With the advantage of home-based data collection, this proposal rigorously builds a breakthrough system that includes wearable neuromodulation and monitoring of vital signs linked to brain health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Immunotherapy has become a standard therapy for many cancers, but it is associated with a risk of acute kidney injury, resulting in significantly increased mortality. Overall goal of this study is to delineate the roles of antigen-specific T cells in immunotherapy-associated acute kidney injury, using novel animal models. The study will lead to better understanding of the mechanisms of immunotherapy-associated kidney injury and identification of potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to recent changes in state reproductive health policy landscapes, U.S. obstetrician- gynecologists may experience policy-related stressors and threats to their mental health and wellbeing. This study will produce novel evidence about the effects of state reproductive health policies on obstetrician-gynecologists’ work experiences, mental health, and work-related wellbeing, a nd will identify organizational-level policies and practices that may buffer the effects of policy stressors. By generating actionable recommendations to improve work-related stressors for obstetrician-gynecologists, the study will lead to improvements in the mental health and work-related wellbeing of this essential workforce.

PROJECT_TITLE: Mental health and work-related wellbeing of U.S. obstetrician-gynecologists in a shifting policy climate
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The presence of tertiary lymphoid structures (TLS) in solid tumors is prognostic for survival in cancer patients, including pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, associated with the expression of MHCI-neoantigens and markers of enhanced immune memory. However, there is no evidence that TLS directly augment tumor specific T cell immunity or the mechanisms of how this occurs. We hypothesize that TLS in pancreatic tumors promote the differentiation of stem-like T cells through IL-21 programming, thereby enhancing effector T cell responses leading to improved tumor control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insulin resistance (IR) is a common and increasing health problem that precedes development of type 2 diabetes and causes cardiovascular disease, but its genetic determinants are largely unknown. We will combine innovative methods including colocalization studies followed by single cell transcriptomics and single cell epigenomics to establish causal genes and mechanisms of action for novel genes involved in development of IR, and validate the physiological role of causal genes in vitro and in vivo using mouse models in a fat-depot specific way. Our work will lead to mechanistic insights into the development of IR and to better treatments for IR and related conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Linda Duska, MD, MPH is an experienced and prolific Clinical Scientist whose overall research goal is to improve the lives of patients with gynecologic cancer and other solid tumors by offering opportunities to participate in clinical research and by developing novel biomarker driven therapies through the clinical trial mechanism. The goal of this proposal is to increase both overall accrual and diversity of accrual to nationally sponsored clinical trials at the University of Virginia Comprehensive Cancer Center (UVACCC) and to increase UVA’s leadership and collaboration in new clinical trials within the national framework. These goals overlap with the goals of the UVACCC, which include increasing accrual and diversification, as well as building multi- disciplinary teams focused on a biomarker-driven approach to clinical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: The combination of heart rate and accelerometry provides better estimates of energy expenditure and sleep compared to either metric alone, but current wearable devices that measure both heart rate and acceleration are not designed for children and may be distracting or uncomfortable. Furthermore, current wearable devices use proprietary processing techniques, which means they cannot be truly validated. Therefore, our research team has created and calibrated an open-source wearable PATCH device designed to measure heart rate and acceleration among children 3-8, and the current project will develop and validate open-source algorithms to predict energy expenditure and sleep among children in both laboratory and free-living contexts.
