IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Single-cell methods for assaying RNA, chromatin state, protein abundance, and other molecular features are becoming increasingly common means to investigate biological phenomena, especially in complex, heterogeneous tissues. However, while single-cell data sets are being generated rapidly, creating a massive corpus of single-cell data across multiple measurement modalities, computational methods for interpreting these large-scale data and extracting biological insights from these rich, diverse data modalities are lagging behind the molecular methodological advances that have enabled this prodigious data generation. In this proposal, we aim to address this critical need of the field by further extending a widely used analysis platform, ArchR, to 1) further improve performance on large data sets, 2) elegantly interpret and explore multi-modal data sets from diverse cellular assays, and 3) deploy cutting-edge deep learning platforms to use single-cell data sets to link regulatory activities to individual bases in the genome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE: Recent FDA conditional approvals of two anti-amyloid antibody treatments for early-stage Alzheimer’s disease provide the first disease-modifying treatments to date, albeit with modest-to-moderate slowing of cognitive decline and vascular side effects. Here, we will test the efficacy of a Glucagon-Like Peptide 1 Receptor (GLP- 1R) agonist, semaglutide, a drug with strong anti-inflammatory, neuroprotective and pro-vascular health effects that is FDA approved for type 2 diabetes and obesity, both alone and in combination with anti-amyloid antibodies in mouse models of Alzheimer’s disease. We hypothesize that the combination therapy will enhance the efficacy beyond that of either treatment alone, and attenuate the vascular side effects seen with anti-amyloid antibodies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Relevance statement Perseverative and repetitive behaviors accompany multiple psychiatric disorders and require cellular and molecular level understanding in order to develop novel disease modifying therapeutic strategies. We discovered that a specific population of astrocytes in the striatum regulate neurons to cause perseverative and repetitive behavioral phenotypes in mice. We will explore how this happens and thus provide potentially new astrocyte and neuronal targets for therapeutic and diagnostic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammation associated diseases have been recognized as the most significant public health problem, not only in the United States but also worldwide. This work will provide mechanistic insight to link defects in DNA polymerase beta to mitochondrial dysfunction and cytosolic nucleic acid signaling in Helicobacter pylori associated inflammation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Excessive vascular remodeling is a major disease feature of pulmonary arterial hypertension, but how pericytes are involved in capillary remodeling is unclear. We show for the first time that lung pericyte dysfunction reduces distal vessels and increases vessel muscularization in severe pulmonary hypertension. Through a combination of established cellular assays, novel transgenic mouse models and cutting-edge stem cell-derived culturing techniques, we will demonstrate the essential role of RGS5 signaling pathway activation for PC dysfunction. We will use our findings to discover new therapeutic approaches to reverse muscularization and restore lung vascular health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Vertebral compression fractures, the most common fragility fractures secondary to osteoporosis, are effectively treated with vertebral augmentation, which rapidly reduces pain and restores function. The goal of this project is to advance surgical robotics technology for vertebral augmentation to reduce radiation dose, increase safety, and improve efficacy. This will be accomplished by developing a novel class of tool-mounted robots and a suite of powerful image-based algorithms for automated intra-operative planning, verification, and control, integrated in mixed reality for remote actuation and assurance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arf1 is one of the molecular determinants driving oral cancer development and progression. We propose a novel and more effective Arf1-targeted therapy that can simultaneously inhibit tumor survival and promote antitumor immune response. The successful completion of this project will lay a scientific foundation for the design and execution of Arf1 selective inhibitors and offer new opportunities to revitalize targeted treatment for patients with advanced HPV-unrelated oral cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insulin resistance is a major factor in the pathology of obesity-associated type 2 diabetes mellitus. We have identified two enzymes that together control the functional state of the insulin receptor through a novel negative feedback loop, and demonstrate that this receptor inhibition is increased in obesity to drive insulin resistance. Understanding this novel mechanism regulating insulin sensitivity may allow identification of new drug targets to treat insulin resistance in metabolic syndrome and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Critical to controlling drug-resistant tuberculosis (DR-TB) are early detection of the disease and accurate detection of drug resistance; however, traditional drug susceptibility tests (DST) are either too slow or too expensive for use as first line diagnostics. Here, we propose to utilize novel probes based on the sugar trehalose to develop a phenotypic, drug-agnostic, rapid, and low-complexity DST designed for resource limited settings. As most countries in the WHO list of high burden countries are developing countries with limited resources, successful development of the proposed DST will significantly impact DR-TB control worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuropsychiatric manifestations are common in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (22qDS), affecting brain development and functioning with marked heterogeneity. We propose to examine developmental trajectories in a cohort of adolescents and young adults and their parents, integrating prospective dimensional and categorical phenotyping of psychopathology, neurobehavioral, environmental exposures, and medical burden. This work will identify convergent risk mechanisms for developmental neuropsychiatric disorders that have relevance to the broader population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Many eukaryotic cells undergo rapid changes in shape or size, which changes the cell surface area. To accommodate these changes, cells fuse the cell surface to internal membrane structures to allow for the rapid exchange of membranes. This mechanism seems to play an important role not only to avoid cell rupture but also in the function of many human cells, including blood platelets and neuronal development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women and those of non-white races are over-represented among patients who experience delays in care for the deadliest form of a heart attack, ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Each minute of delay increases the risk of death, so we will develop diversity-inclusive artificial intelligence (AI) to support early diagnosis of STEMI. This AI will calculate the risk for a heart attack, with attention to improving the identification of women and non-white patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antiobesity medications can help patients increase their weight loss and achieve better health. Unfortunately, there is very little research comparing the safety and impact of the different available antiobesity medicines, and most eligible patients with obesity are not prescribed one. To make prescribing decisions easier for patients and doctors, we will use insurance claims data from across the United States to study how different antiobesity medications impact health and health care use.

However, providers fail to prescribe statin therapy for about half of patients meeting guideline criteria for initiation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease, characterized by a progressive decline in cognitive function, is the most common form of dementia. Large-scale genomics studies have recently converged on VGF as a critical driver (regulator) in the signaling networks that underlie Alzheimer’s disease pathogenesis and progression in human patients, and data from our labs further demonstrate that VGF overexpression or intracerebroventricular administration of VGF-derived peptides to the 5xFAD mouse model reduces amyloid plaque load, microgliosis and astrogliosis, in the brain. The proposed studies will optimize intranasal nose-to-brain VGF peptide delivery, will determine whether these VGF peptides engage targets in the brain, and will investigate efficacy of intranasal peptides to rescue neuropathology and memory impairment in mouse models of neurodegeneration, providing a firm foundation for future translation of VGF therapeutics to human subjects with Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excess dietary fructose consumption is common and elicits an array of metabolic consequences, including obesity, inflammation, fatty liver, insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes. The human gut microbiome has also been associated with these conditions and may be modified by excess fructose consumption, yet the role of the microbiome as a mediating factor between fructose and metabolic health in humans has not been examined. In this proposal we will evaluate causal relationships between the gut microbiome and metabolic risk using a controlled human dietary trial followed by fecal transplant microbiome studies in germ-free mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite being rare, MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma (NB) accounts for ~7% of all pediatric cancer related deaths and is driven by the oncogenic transcription factor MYCN and a MYCN-directed adrenergic (ADRN) core regulatory complex (CRC) of self-regulating and inter-regulated transcription factors that drive the MYCN- amplified NB transcriptome. In this proposal, we demonstrate MYCN drives a SUMOylation program in NB and MYCN confers synthetic lethality to the in-clinic SUMOylation inhibitor, TAK-981. TAK-981 disrupts the ADRN CRC, only in the presence of MYCN, to induce ADRN CRC collapse and cell death, and thus represents an exciting new therapy for this recalcitrant pediatric tumor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  This multi-disciplinary proposal leverages molecular biology, deep-network learning, and in vivo microscopy to develop a suite of first-in-class tools to directly observe synaptic plasticity in living animals using minimally invasive methods. We seek to explain how dynamic modulation of specific synaptic circuits encodes learning and memory. By studying the fundamental mechanisms of memory encoding, we endeavor to gain insights into treating neurological disorders involving aberrant memory function, such as Alzheimer’s disease and PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Engagement in evidenced-based diabetes prevention programs has historically been low, particularly in the Latino population, who are disproportionally affected by type 2 diabetes. Identifying both clinical and social determinants of health factors that increase diabetes risk and act as barriers for participation in prevention programs is crucial to improve equitable access to diabetes prevention programs. The proposed research aims to use clinical and social determinants of health data readily available in the electronic health record to develop and validate a diabetes prediction model specific to the needs of Latino patients, and engage with patients, clinicians and health care systems to increase enrollment and engagement in diabetes prevention programs.

PHR: Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a life-threatening clinical syndrome prevalent in hospitalized patients and have multiple etiologies and diverse outcomes, which highlights the need for personalized intervention. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urinary tract infections (UTI) affect millions of US women, and there is an urgent need to develop better ways to prevent and treat this painful and costly disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will identify how reactive oxygen species associated with ischemia/reperfusion injury elicit mitochondrial calcium entry and depolarization of mitochondrial membrane potential resulting in vascular apoptosis, and we will investigate how these mechanisms elicit greater cell death in males as compared to females. Our complimentary expertise in microvascular physiology with neurobehavioral analysis will allow us to understand how deficits in vascular function following ischemia/reperfusion effect neuronal survival and function. These experiments will provide fundamental new knowledge for identifying innovative avenues of therapy after ischemia/reperfusion injuries such as stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG), a leading cause of irreversible vision loss worldwide, is more visually damaging but also more preventable than other common types of glaucoma. Gonioscopy, the current clinical standard for detecting patients at risk for PACG, is ineffective and inconvenient for doctors to use, which contributes to poorly defined practice guidelines, delayed disease detection and treatment, and high prevalence of blindness. We propose to establish anterior segment OCT (AS-OCT), a convenient and precise form of ocular imaging, as the new clinical standard to detect and evaluate individuals at risk for PACG and reduce PACG- related vision loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The pending introduction of novel vaccines and monoclonal antibodies to prevent respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) holds promise for reducing the burden of disease in infants. We propose a large-scale epidemiologic study that integrates data from different modalities (e.g., clinical, demographic, virologic, immunologic) to evaluate the real-world effectiveness of perinatal RSV immunoprophylaxis. The results of this work will inform on the optimal implementation strategies and help build public confidence in these novel immunization programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Influenza viruses can exchange genes when they infect the same cell, creating variant viruses that can evade immunity, become more transmissible, or cause more severe disease. Predicting which strains are more likely to exchange genes has remained a challenge and the specific viral factors that influence the propensity for exchange remain understudied. This project will identify specific parts of the viral genome that restrict or promote genetic exchange to improve risk assessments, pandemic preparedness, and reveal new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Newly emerging spatial omics experiments can promote our understanding of spatial and molecular patterns and relevant biological mechanisms associated with various organs and diseases such as cancers and neurodegenerative disorders. The proposed power analysis framework will help improving design of spatial omics experiments, which in turn will help guarantee biologically meaningful findings. The high impact of this framework will be reflected through an interactive web interface with a coding-free environment that will assist basic scientists, clinical scientists, and bioinformaticians in their design of spatial omics experiments.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This research aims to understand how optimized ankle and hip exoskeletons in combination with biofeedback can impact walking speed, gait energetics, gait biomechanics and clinically meaningful outcomes in stroke survivors. Through the use of novel deep learning systems and optimization systems, exoskeleton assistance can be personalized to a patient’s unique walking pattern, which can then be further improved through use of targeted biofeedback. These results have the potential to enhance quality of life for individuals post-stroke by improving independent community ambulation through improvements in mobility, independence and overall quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overactive bladder (OAB) is an extremely common symptom complex that is challenging to treat clinically due to several underlying etiologies. This proposal seeks to elucidate OAB subtypes utilizing comprehensive clinical and demographic data from two NIDDK-funded consortia networks and to further identify if the addition of microbiome characteristics aids in defining OAB subtypes. We additionally will determine if stratification by OAB subtype improves predicted response to OAB treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with advanced neuroblastoma continue to have poor outcomes despite intensive, multimodal therapy. One of the most effective therapies utilized when patients have relapsed or refractory disease is 131I-MIBG radiotherapy. Through an existing clinical trial testing novel targeted agents in combination with 131I-MIBG (NANT 2021-02), we will investigate whether liquid biopsies can identify biomarkers to help predict why some patients respond or become resistant to combination radiopharmaceutical approaches which will lead to optimized treatment selection and new candidate therapies in patients with neuroblastoma.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep Apnea is a common chronic disorder affecting over 1 billion patients worldwide. Current method of diagnosing OSA using the apnea hypopnea index has demonstrable limitations and to overcome those limitations our proposal utilizes state-of-the-art artificial intelligence/machine-learning model that provides risk of short- and long-term outcomes using data from routine sleep studies. The present proposal will assess the real- world performance of our artificial intelligence/machine-learning that has the ability to enhance clinical management of sleep apnea

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Friedreich’s ataxia (FRDA), a neurodegenerative disease, is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion within the frataxin gene, which is a protein located within mitochondria. We showed in the mouse model of FRDA that bone marrow hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) that give rise to blood cells, holds great promise to treat FRDA, by differentiation of the transplanted HSCs into microglia/macrophages (type of immune cells) within tissues, that will transfer the functional frataxin to the brain cells (neurons). The contribution of innate immune cells to FRDA and the exact mechanism of frataxin transfer is still unknown, we will utilize induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) derived from FRDA patients and healthy donor fibroblasts to generate microglia, neurons, and cerebral organoids (mini-brains) to probe the therapeutic potential of repeat correction in immune cells, and transfer of frataxin and potentially mitochondria to affected neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is a highly desmoplastic cancer with extensive collagen (Col) accumulation. Col remodeling and differential activation of the Col receptor DDR1 by cleaved (c) and intact (i) Col I or III control PDAC metabolism and malignancy. We will investigate how Col I/III cleavage by matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) enables DDR1 activation, how iCol I triggers DDR1 degradation and identify MMPs responsible for Col I/III cleavage, thereby providing new targets for PDAC treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite growing evidence of the complex, interconnected pathways linking the mind and body, scalable interventions that efficiently target whole-person health upon diagnosis of a life-altering disease such as cancer have not yet been developed. We plan to address this gap and build on our extensive foundational research, completed over the past 6 years with support of the NIH New Innovator Award (DP2 AT009511), to test a novel mHealth intervention, MINDSET, which targets the mindsets of people with cancer at the point of diagnosis. By promoting health at the psychological, behavioral, and biological levels, MINDSET interventions have the potential to become a highly impactful and complementary tool for more patient-centered cancer treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic inflammation contributing to the development of cardiovascular disease is difficult to treat because innate immune cells become primed to a hyperinflammatory response. This research project will address formation of inflammarafts, reprogrammed plasma membrane microdomains hosting complexes of inflammatory receptors, and mitochondrial dysfunction in atherosclerotic lesion macrophages. Strategies to target inflammarafts and mitochondrial dysfunction will advance the development of novel therapeutics to treat atherosclerosis and cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The misfolded proteins associated with neurodegenerative disease can adopt a variety of different conformations, some of which are toxic. Because these proteins have identical amino acid sequences, the cellular environment clearly influences the final state, yet most structural studies do not include the cellular context and, perhaps because we are not studying the correct conformation, not a single therapeutic strategy for these diseases addresses the underlying protein misfolding pathology. Using new sensitivity-enhancement technology for solid state NMR spectroscopy, we will study protein structure in native environments - inside living cells - to reveal how cellular environments influence protein structure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While immune checkpoint blockade is an effective cancer treatment, many individuals do not respond. Patients with a mutation in the ARID1A gene respond better to immune checkpoint blockade, indicating that ARID1A may be a biomarker for immune checkpoint blockade therapy. ARID1A mutation results in DNA replication stress in the form of R loops, which may drive heightened anti-tumor immunity and immune checkpoint blockade responsiveness through activation of an inflammatory response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative This project develops a revolutionary new microscope based on a technological breakthrough called Scanned Line Angular Projection two photon laser scanning microscopy. This microscope will enable optical imaging of neuronal activity at subcellular spatial resolution with a temporal resolution in the millisecond range both in vivo and in vitro using a variety of fluorescent indicators (e.g. voltage and neurotransmitter). As a result, new avenues of neuroscience research will become possible providing promise for the elucidation of novel biological mechanisms associated with human brain disease, and ultimately the basis for developing novel therapies to prevent and treat complex brain diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will advance our understanding of how the human thalamus contributes to goal-directed behaviors (cognitive control). Many psychiatric and neurological disorders, such as schizophrenia, attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), stroke and traumatic brain injury, affect thalamic function and have significant impairments in cognitive control. The proposed research is relevant to NIH's mission because it can provide insights into the diagnosis and treatment of clinical disorders inflicted by dysfunctional cognitive control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Skin and soft tissue infections are a major public health threat. The skin creates a physical and immunological barrier against invasive infection, however, we have an incomplete understanding of host defense mechanisms in the skin. In this proposal we show that sebaceous glands express small proline-rich proteins (SPRR) and investigate the impact of these proteins on cutaneous host defense.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome) is an acute inflammation of the lung’s air sacs (alveoli), which normally causes 75,000 annual US deaths; though that number has been multiplied dramatically by COVID-19, which kills via ARDS. While developing nanotechnology-based drug carriers for ARDS, we discovered that one of the most ancient immune components, the complement pathway, interacts with nanocarriers in ways that are both therapeutic and produce side effects. Here we will develop nanotechnologies that will augment complement’s therapeutic effects and prevent its side effects, with implications for other acute inflammatory conditions, such as sepsis, stroke, and heart attack.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Only around 30% of human pregnancies progress to live birth with a great majority failing due to developmental defects, often resulting from aneuploidy. We will use a mouse model to assess how aneuploid cells can be eliminated or side-lined in development that will establish the circumstances in which pregnancies can be successfully established from aneuploid mosaic embryos. Our work will thus inform IVF strategies in the clinic enabling a more accurate assessment of the developmental potential of mosaic aneuploid embryos and permitting the development of better methods to assess the probability of successful pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Inhibitory neurons of the dorsolateral hypothalamus regulate sleep, but little is known about how these neurons are generated and maintained. We have identified a new class of hypothalamic neurons that require the transcription factor Lhx6 for their development and survival. We propose to identify the molecular mechanisms by which Lhx6 controls the development of these neurons, and determine their precise role in control of sleep.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE G protein-coupled receptors are responsible for regulating nearly every physiological process in the human body, which makes them an important target for drug development. The purpose of this project is to detail the effects of dynamic post-translational modification s-palmitoylation on the conformational plasticity and subsequent intracellular signaling of the β2 adrenergic receptor, utilizing a combination of electron paramagnetic resonance techniques along with pharmacological and cellular signaling assays. The results from this project will generate a more adept understanding of β2 adrenergic receptor signaling and regulation within the context of a physiologically relevant cellular environment, thus allowing for the design of more effective treatments targeting cardiac β2 adrenergic receptor signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to define how NMNAT1 as an NAD+ synthetase provides NAD+ to fuel chromatin remodeling enzyme activities to regulate chromatin structure and gene expression dynamics. Impairments in regulating these processes lead to a significant number of human pathologies, including cancer and age- related diseases. Therefore, understanding the functions of NMNAT1 as a nuclear metabolic enzyme in regulating chromatin remodeling and gene expression is crucial to define new paradigms regarding gene expression and regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed ITN UM1 funding addresses major unmet health needs. In the United States, autoimmune diseases affect >5% of the population, and allergic diseases affect another ~15%. Transplantation is a life- saving intervention for organ failure, but risky and burdensome. In each area, pre-clinical studies show that immune tolerance should be an achievable therapeutic prospect, and progress towards that goal is evident in recent clinical trials. Successful tolerance offers long-term freedom from immunosuppressive therapy, radically improving quality of life, disease burden, and health care costs. 1 Abstract

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: This project addresses a number of issues that of central importance for understanding how behavioral set-points for motivated behaviors are regulated during the critical transition between adolescence and full maturity. Specifically, using a mouse model, this project will examine how serotonin, acting through 5-HT1A receptors affects maturation of medial pre-frontal cortex dependent circuitry in adolescence to affect lifelong motivational states. This work has implications for our understanding of human conditions where motivation is dysregulated such as depression, and may reveal new developmentally specific approaches to treating such problems.

PHR: Project Narrative Discrete neuronal activity patterns define how information is processed in the brain. The manner in which disruption of these patterns by disease-associated mutations impacts behavioral regulation is poorly understood, but likely contributes to the etiology of many symptom domains of mental illness. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Findings from the proposed research are important for furthering women’s options for management of fistula- related urinary incontinence and are expected to inform changes to clinical practice for fistula management in low- and middle-income countries. Ultimately, expanding management options for women with fistula is likely to reduce stigma, improve economic opportunity, and have a transformative effect on quality of life. By prioritizing global implementation research early in the interventional research process, culturally appropriate, cost-effective, and acceptable implementation strategies can be planned for this and similar contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Diaphragm vascular dysfunction portends and contributes to the diaphragm atrophy and contractile dysfunction associated with prolonged mechanical ventilation (MV) and such diaphragm muscle abnormalities (e.g. atrophy, contractile dysfunction) are present in heart failure (HF), however, the role of diaphragm vascular dysfunction in HF, as well as the impact of HF with the added insult of prolonged MV on diaphragm vascular function, has never been investigated. Therefore, using a unique combination of techniques (fluorescent microspheres, isolated blood vessel preparation, contractility measures), the current proposal will determine the distribution of diaphragm blood flow and diaphragm vasomotor function in HF and HF + prolonged MV as well as the efficacy of pharmacological treatment (Angiotensin-(1-7)) to improve diaphragm blood flow, vascular function, and in vivo contractile function with prolonged MV and HF + prolonged MV rats. Diaphragm vascular function is a neglected field of research in both health and disease and yet preventing the harbingers of respiratory muscle failure, if possible, will do much to lessen the human burden of major pathologies such as HF and COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative How cognition and brain function stabilize in the transition from adolescence to adulthood is not understood limiting our understanding of the formation of normative and importantly non-normative adult trajectories, such as in mental illness, which predominantly emerges during this transition. Here, informed by the important results of the earlier grants in this line of inquiry regarding brain development in the reward system, we propose innovative new studies to understand how changes in brain and reward behavior from adolescence to adulthood lead to retaining established behaviors. Together, these studies will provide new integrated evidence of how brain development leads to establishing adult trajectories informing impaired trajectories in mental illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE 38 million people worldwide are living with HIV. Despite successful antiretroviral therapy (ART), 15-40% of these people with HIV develop HIV-associated neurocognitive impairments (HIV-NCI) that gravely impact morbidity and mortality, for which there is no effective therapy in the ART era. Since HIV-infected intermediate monocytes are major contributors to neuropathogenesis and the development of HIV-NCI, defining and characterizing novel subsets is paramount to identifying new targets for potential therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Macrophages are critical to the maintenance of healthy joints, but increased macrophage number is associated with inflammation in rheumatoid arthritis (RA). We propose to investigate macrophage heterogeneity and transcriptional regulation using mouse models and patient samples to better understand their dynamics in health and disease. These studies will elucidate the role of different macrophage subpopulations in RA and provide potential targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many diseases have their origins prenatally and in childhood, making investment in research on pediatric disease and health an important goal for improving the health of people of all ages. While there is a critical need to advance the science related to childhood diseases and health and translate basic research findings into novel interventions, the numbers of physician-scientists devoted to these causes are stagnating. We propose herein an innovative program where renowned faculty with extensive research and training expertise will mentor outstanding junior pediatric faculty embarking on careers in academic medicine, and help them to become successful, independent physician scientists who conduct cutting-edge basic and translational research of importance to children.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metformin use in pregnancy is associated with potential maternal benefits but also adverse neonatal and childhood outcomes. This projects seeks to study the effects of metformin on placental trophoblast function and potential epigenetic mechanisms that contribute to the detrimental offspring outcomes reported in the larger clinical trials. These data will add to the critical gap in our knowledge of the effects of metformin on placental health, role on potential beneficial and adverse perinatal outcomes, and inform future safety and targeted interventions for use of metformin in pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE We will examine the toxicity of arsenic to the developing immune system in children exposed in utero and early life and how it affects their response to vaccination against Streptococcus pneumoniae. It is known that arsenic disrupts the development of immune T cells important in protecting children against airway infections, such as Streptococcus pneumonia. We will measure how arsenic impacts the response to vaccination and microbial communities in the upper airways and gut.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are studying the process of blood vessel formation and trying to understand how the growth of endothelial cells, that form the lining of blood vessels, is regulated and to what extent this is necessary in order to develop a proper blood circulatory system. By defining factors that are needed for endothelial cell growth control and arterial-venous network development, we will gain insights needed to treat arterial-venous malformations, enhance neovascularization of injured tissues, and engineer circulatory networks from human stem cells that can be used for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative LBD, also known as Alzheimer's Disease Related Disorder (ADRD), is the second most common cause of dementia after AD affecting approximately 1.4 million Americans, with no FDA-approved medications to treat LBD and few medications in clinical trials, leaving a great unmet need for patients and their families. Recently we developed the PV-1950R/A vaccine based on a MultiTEP platform technology that is highly immunogenic in mice, rabbits, and monkeys and demonstrated the efficacy in the αSyn D line mouse model of LBD. In this U01 project, we propose to manufacture the cGMP adjuvanted vaccine, PV-1950R/A, complete IND-enabling safety/toxicology studies in LBD mouse model and non-human primates, submit and obtain all of the necessary regulatory documents for an FDA-approved investigational new drug (IND) and conduct pilot phase 1 trial in healthy individuals (Phase 1a) and individuals with patients with rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder (RBD) who are at the risk of LBD (Phase 1b).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application focuses on using genetically engineered mouse models and cell culture models of neurofibromatosis type 2 to characterize the role of focal adhesion kinase (FAK) signaling in the development of NF2-related schwannomas. These complementary in vitro and in vivo studies will determine the genetic contribution of FAK1/PTK2 in schwannoma development, the potential utility of post-IND FAK inhibitors, alone or in combination with other phase I/II or FDA approved kinase inhibitors, and molecular response signatures to treatment. Collectively, the genetic, pharmacologic, and genomic approaches will enable rapid translation to early phase clinical trials for NF2 schwannoma patients who currently lack effective targeted therapy options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Our preliminary data indicate that inhibition and deletion of STIM2 attenuates acute and chronic itch behavior in mice. Blockage, deletion of STIM2 almost eliminates GRP-induced calcium entry in dorsal horn neurons and LPS-induced cytokine production in astrocytes. Successful completion of this project will not only identify STIM2 as a novel key modulator of itch sensation, but will also decipher the molecular mechanisms underlying chronic itch.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This study will use a cross-sectional design and mixed-methods to examine mental health among recently arrived Latinx immigrant adults through the development of mental health phenotypes shaped by the intersection of trauma exposure, symptom severity (of depression, anxiety and PTSD), and individual characteristics. Extreme violence has been a main contributor to migration to the U.S. from Latin America. This K01 Award proposes to develop mental health phenotypes in this population in order to develop longitudinal studies on the evolving mental health of immigrants and inform the development and delivery of appropriate interventions for the right person at the right time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: WHO Grade II and Grade III astrocytomas are common gliomas occurring in early middle adult life. Almost all progress to higher grade including secondary GBM. Grade II/III astrocytomas are distinguished from other gliomas by their typical mutational background consisting of IDHmut/p53mut/ATRXloss and are understudied relative to glioblastoma. Immunotherapy offers great promise in other cancers but has not yet been effective against brain tumors including astrocytoma. This research will use pre-clinical models to identify immunosuppressive transcriptional mechanisms of astrocytoma and amplified by standard-of-care radiation therapy. Positive results will develop a novel combinational immunotherapy strategy for IDHmut/p53mut/ATRXloss Grade II/III astrocytoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The loss of endogenous tumor suppression is an obligatory step towards cancer, but the mechanisms are elusive. We have now discovered that Parkin, a molecule altered in early-onset Parkinson’s disease, functions as a unique dual mode tumor suppressor, inhibiting intrinsic tumor traits of cell motility and metabolism while also reprogramming an antitumor immune microenvironment. This pathway involves Parkin “priming” of immunogenic cell death, control of cytosolic and mitochondrial danger-sensing pathways and transcriptional activation of interferon gene expression. The proposed studies will elucidate the cellular and molecular requirements of Parkin innate immunity in cancer and uncover novel strategies to improve the response to immunotherapy in advanced disease patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Epidemiologic studies have demonstrated that sickle cell trait (SCT) is associated with both venous thrombosis and chronic renal injury. We propose that unique biophysical conditions within venous clots and within the inner renal medulla promote sickling in sickle trait erythrocytes that can result in an increased tendency to blood clotting and kidney dysfunction. Our project will examine this hypothesis in human samples and a mouse model in order to identify the best therapeutic approach to attenuate these complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE STATEMENT Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is the leading cause of blindness in the United States. We are developing a sustained drug delivery system to target two components of wet AMD that cause irreversible blindness, the growth of new blood vessels and fibrosis. By targeting both phenomena with a long-term delivery system, we may be able to reduce progression of the disease and protect vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal is about the human brain and how it makes impressions of other people’s social attributes such as age, gender, trustworthiness, competence, etc., immediately after viewing their face. It is also about how these impressions change by the social contextual information. The cognitive functions probed in our proposal have a pervasive influence on many aspects of our social interactions with and is at the core of dysfunction in several psychiatric disorders such as autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: While several medical and surgical weight reduction strategies are available, with newer, transformative medications recently approved, little is known about their safety and effectiveness in clinical practice. This proposal’s goal is to develop, implement, and test approaches to produce large scale, high-quality evidence on the comparative safety and effectiveness of medical and surgical weight loss strategies in clinical practice. This work will develop more accurate, methodologically rigorous approaches to conduct real-world evidence studies of medical and surgical weight reduction strategies using large scale, real-world data and will create an invaluable infrastructure to conduct future studies on the comparative safety and effectiveness of various cardiometabolic treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The necrotic tumor microenvironment could significantly modulate glioblastoma development and therapeutics. The proposed study will focus on understanding the mechanism and function of necrosis during glioblastoma malignant progression and exploring specific vulnerabilities in this process for therapeutic purposes. Results from this study may provide a new horizon to explore the necrotic tumor microenvironment as a diagnostic marker or therapeutic target in glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease is correlated with vascular disease; however, the nature and mechanism by which these diseases interact to develop clinical dementia remains relatively unknown. The novel MRI techniques in this project enable new insights into vascular health. The overarching objective is to enable characterization of cerebrovascular involvement in Alzheimer's Disease pathology through the development and study integration of a new battery of non-invasive cerebrovascular health measures including tools to image vascular stiffness and flow oscillations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Extracellular vesicles (EVs) are microscopic particles, produced by all cells in the body, that circulate in the trillions in every milliliter of blood. EVs can potentially provide signatures of aging and resilience and carry proteins and other molecules that can communicate and have effects at a distance. Using large numbers of already collected precious human specimens from individuals aged 20 to over 90 years old, this project characterizes the types and role of these vesicles in aging and develops new blood biomarker tests for these vesicles to better understand mechanisms of aging and the ability to recover from stressors with aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Sexually transmitted infections (STI) disproportionately affect adolescents, and adolescents often rely on emergency departments (ED) for care. This application proposes to leverage health information technology in the ED by 1) integrating patient reported outcomes into the electronic health record to drive patient-engaged clinical decision support for improved STI detection, and 2) using mobile health through two-way text messaging for improved STI treatment to improve adolescent sexual health outcomes and reduce disparities in the STI epidemic. The development of an ED-based intervention to tackle the STI epidemic through implementation of broad screening into the clinical workflow is timely and needed as it may confer significant public health impact and is consistent with the mission of Healthy People 2030.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in therapy, people with cystic fibrosis (CF) develop progressive airway obstruction that is worsened by airway smooth muscle dysfunction. In this proposal, we will study how the CF disease modifier TGF drives CF lung disease through airway smooth muscle dysfunction and define its mechanism of action. These results will directly improve our understanding of CF obstructive airway disease and identify novel therapeutic targets to improve the health of children with CF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The objective of this project is to validate an innovative diagnostic ultrasound imaging technology that will allow for noninvasively detecting atherosclerotic plaques that have high chance of rupturing, which will result in heart attacks and strokes. The innovative technology so called super resolution ultrasound imaging provides unprecedented high resolution that enables to image abnormal growth of microvessels in atherosclerotic plaques at great details, which is well known as a key indicator of plaque rupture. If successfully validated through novel rabbit plaque rupture model that is known to be most close to human plaques, the technology development and findings through this project will provide strong foundation and potential for future clinical translation. Upon successful clinical validation in future on human subjects, an immediate clinical application will be for carotid atherosclerosis clinics where this imaging technology incorporated into a current ultrasound scanner will be able to identify plaques at high risk of rupture for most appropriate interventions or/and treatments to prevent strokes and save life. The immediate outcomes from this project include an accurate, affordable, well-validated robust animal imaging tool for important diseases which are associated with microvessel abnormalities such as atherosclerotic plaques proposed in this project, cancer angiogenesis, and kidney diseases to name a few.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) has been established to be an important plasticity factor implicated in depression and anxiety disorders, due to its decreased levels in the adult CNS. We propose here to study the requirement of BDNF during peri-adolescence in regulating the development and function of a specific social behavior circuit. As social behavioral impairments are key features of these affective disorders, our studies point to a new function for this brain growth factor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project focuses on understanding how mechanisms associated with chronic tissue damage influence the development and progression of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Our proposal builds on our previous findings that similarities exist between a rare genetic SCC disease model, recessive dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa (RDEB) and metastatic subtypes of sporadic head and neck SCC. Our goal is to identify and characterize the molecular events contributing to tumor initiation and progression in the context of tissue damage, with the over- arching aim of uncovering potential new avenues for the effective prevention and treatment of SCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Multiple sclerosis is a debilitating neurological disease caused by immune-mediated loss of myelin in the central nervous system. While existing drugs that downregulate the immune system provide some benefit, no therapies are available that can regenerate lost myelin and reverse neurological deficits. Our proposed aims will use organic synthesis as a key tool to build upon a highly novel sterol signaling mechanism we recently uncovered that explains how dozens of small-molecule drugs promote myelin repair. These studies are likely to identify optimized EBP inhibitors to accelerate the development of the first ‘remyelinating therapeutics’ while also identifying new sterol-binding drug targets for promoting myelin repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The hemodynamic response induced by neural activity is the principal means of studying brain function and brain connectivity in humans and animals. Methods like functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and optical imaging of intrinsic signal (OIS) are essential in basic science, developmental, cognitive and clinical studies of normal and impaired brain function. This proposal will reveal the contributions of sub-populations of inhibitory neurons on vascular regulation and imaging signals like fMRI and OIS to improve our understanding of brain function and dysfunction in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies will establish a basis for treating impairments in limb coordination during walking that result from spinal cord injury (SCI), stroke, or Parkinson’s disease, as well as those associated with normal aging. A better understanding of the neural and biomechanical mechanisms controlling limb coordination before and after SCI will provide essential insights for the development of future clinical strategies to restore and promote motor functions by identifying specific targets (e.g. reflexes, muscle synergies) for activity-based interventions, such as electrical or pharmacological stimulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE Efficient generation of contractile force in muscle requires the proper assembly, maintenance and activation of actin-containing thin filaments. Here we propose to take a multidisciplinary approach to decipher how the leiomodins (LMODs), a family of actin-binding proteins, regulate assembly and activation of the thin filament and how mutations in LMOD2 lead to human dilated cardiomyopathy. These studies will provide missing links in our basic understanding of muscle contraction and have a broad impact on determining the etiology of a spectrum of diseases, across all three muscle types, that result from mutations in the LMOD family of genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: A mutation in the C9orf72 gene causes ~25% of cases of frontotemporal dementia (FTD), the most common type of inherited dementia after Alzheimer’s disease. The mechanisms by which the repeat expansion leads to disease is not known. Our studies will test if protein degradation pathway previously associated with cancer might also be leveraged to treat or diagnose this currently incurable disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE Cell free hemoglobin and iron accumulate in circulating monocytes/macrophages that are subsequently recruited to lung. In the lung adventitial space these macrophages lose iron homeostasis (resulting in incorrect iron extrusion). This extruded iron along with extravasated Hb mediated cellualr lipid peroxia- tion, may alter the cross talk betwee adventitial fibroblasts and macrophages creating pro-inflammatory micro-environment that drives pulmonary vascular disease. The goal of our studies is elucidate the mechanistic underpinnings of this process.

PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of the IMSD program at the University of Texas at San Antonio is to provide a comprehensive evidence-based training and support infrastructure that enables underrepresented UTSA doctoral students to develop as biomedical scientists. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Multiple hypotheses have been put forward regarding cortical circuit dysfunction in autism spectrum disorders. Nevertheless, we currently lack a comprehensive mechanistic understanding of how cortical circuits malfunction during sensory processing in autism. Here we undertake an effort to densely map cortical circuit properties and connectivity in the MECP2-duplication syndrome of autism and use this information to create a neuro-realistic cortical circuit model, which will allow a detailed, “in computo,” interrogation of the mechanism of dysfunction and how to ameliorate it. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Technological advances are leading to unprecedented abundance of increasingly complex, voluminous, and multi-dimensional data on a wide range of health outcomes and their determinants, including those related to lung, heart, allergy, and infectious diseases—creating a critical need to train biostatisticians and data scientists with multidisciplinary skills to properly analyze such data. Also evident is the need for a diversified workforce of biostatisticians and data scientists well-versed in public health principles to properly tackle the acute and growing challenges of health disparities. To fill this critical gap, the Summer Training Institute in Biostatistics and Data Science at Columbia (SIBDS@Columbia) proposes an innovative curriculum in quantitative skills anchored on data immersion related to research challenges in studies of heart and lung diseases as well as infectious diseases, to train the next generation of adept biostatisticians and data scientists poised to address these pressing challenges.

PHR: Gene silencing using small interfering RNA (siRNA) is a viable therapeutic approach but, limited in translation due to lack of effective delivery systems. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Over the last 20 years, the number of older adults (aged≥55) undergoing live donor nephrectomy has increased 4-fold. In light of an aging US population, the new kidney transplant allocation system, and recent changes to Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) practice guidelines, this trend is likely to continue. The goal of this project is to improve our understanding of the perioperative and long-term risks most pertinent to older donors in order to inform dialogue with care providers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Our research focuses on the kinases and phosphatases targeting RNA polymerase II and transcripton. Malfunction of RNA polymerase II phosphorylation leads to cell death, developmental defects, and cancer. We use chemical and analytic biology to investigate and modulate this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Most of the over 40,000 patients diagnosed with pancreatic cancer each year in this country will die from metastatic disease. Irreversible electroporation (IRE) is a non-thermal ablation technique that is currently being used clinically to treat locally advanced tumors. The goal of this research is to understand effects of IRE on the immune system and to augment these effects using immunotherapy agents to eradicate distant micrometastatic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Due to epidemics of opioid overdose and hepatitis C virus (HCV), organs from HCV+ donors are increasingly available, however thousands are currently discarded that could benefit individuals in need of a transplant. A new practice of transplanting HCV+ donor organs into individuals without HCV, in combination with HCV medications, has shown early success. This proposal includes a trial of HCV+ donor kidney transplantation in order to determine the best timing and duration of HCV medications, and scientific studies that will improve our understanding of HCV infection and immune responses, as well as novel viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proposed project will address a gap in knowledge regarding Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) investigators’ data sharing practices, perceptions of policies, and navigation of barriers. Despite demonstrated benefits of data sharing in the health sciences - prior data shows suboptimal data sharing practices (e.g., data withholding, misuse of data, and inequity in sharing). An increased understanding of factors that facilitate or impede data sharing will support interventions that enable broad data sharing practices and will advance therapeutic discoveries in ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adeno-associated viral (AAV) mediated gene therapy is an approach for delivering genes to treat genetic diseases including hemophilia, an X-linked bleeding disorder. Recent studies show that a large portion of the AAV vector DNA is rearranged before and/or after delivery into the target cell/animal model which reduces the long-term effectiveness of the therapy, and vector genomes can become integrated in host cells with risk of genotoxicity. The goal of this project is to determine the nature of these rearrangements over time and in different animals or tissues and to identify strategies to prevent these changes in the DNA from occurring to improve AAV gene therapy efficacy and safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by multifocal arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) that impair brain and other organ functions. There is currently no preventative treatment or cure for HHT or AVMs in general, but success of the proposed work will establish a robust preclinical animal model for HHT and AVMs and identify causal events for disease progression. Our findings will greatly advance the understanding of the molecular mechanisms of HHT pathogenesis and aid in the development of new therapeutic strategies that will impact future clinical practice for HHT and AVM patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this project we will develop quantitative criteria to identify patients who need additional drug treatment after surgery for kidney cancer. This treatment is expected to delay or avoid disease recurrence, however because of its toxic side effects only patients who are at high risk of cancer recurrence should be treated. Here we propose to develop better criteria for selecting the right patients for treatment after kidney cancer surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Bacteria that cause infections in humans exploit human cellular factors to promote disease. We propose to investigate how human factors that are used by Shigella, a bacterium that causes severe diarrhea, contribute to disease. Understanding these processes will potentially reveal new avenues for treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative NEXMIF is a novel X-linked ASD gene originally diagnosed only in males, but increasing reports have identified that female individuals of NEXMIF haploinsufficiency also demonstrate autistic symptoms. Using a female mouse model of NEXMIF haploinsufficiency, this grant proposes to determine the behavioral phenotypes and elucidate the alterations in neuron structural development and synaptic function resulting from the mosaic expression of NEXMIF in female mouse brains. Findings from the study will provide mechanistic insight into NEXMIF encephalopathy and set the basis for the development of therapeutical strategies for NEXMIF ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is widely known that the eukaryotic genome is segregated within three-dimensional nuclear space, with large, heterochromatic domains sequestered proximal to the nuclear lamina. Elucidating the molecular mechanisms responsible for the organization of the genome at the nuclear periphery will delineate how cell-type and differentiation-state specific chromatin configurations and higher-order genome organization are directed in health and disease. The results of my studies will identify the mechanistic drivers of lamina-associated domain establishment and maintenance, providing a fundamental principle governing peripheral heterochromatin organization that links gene expression, local genomic context and radial positioning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer metabolic reprogramming plays an essential role in tumor development resulting in differential utilization of many essential metabolites by cancer cells compared to normal cells and has been recently recognized as a promising therapeutic target for the improved cancer treatments. However, cancer metabolic reprogramming is poorly understood due to the lack of tools that can quantify nutrient uptake in relevant animal models of human cancers. Here, we propose to develop a novel optical imaging platform that would become a universal analytical method for monitoring nutrient uptake in tumors and would help to understand metabolic vulnerabilities of many different cancers with the overall goal to generate novel, effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work will elucidate the molecular basis of altered nucleoside diphosphate kinase (NDPK) activity in patients and animals with atrial fibrillation. The effects of enhanced NDPK signaling, altered cAMP levels near the ryanodine receptor channel complex, and abnormal intracellular calcium signaling will be studied in human and dog atrial cells and mouse models. These studies may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches for atrial fibrillation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The adrenal glands produce androgen precursors, which are known to be important during fetal and early development. Recent data suggest that a set of unique adrenal androgens, called 11-oxyandrogens, might play important roles in aging individuals. The proposed research aims to deeply characterize the patterns of 11- oxyandrogens in aging men and women, and to derive associations between 11-oxyandrogens and various age- related health outcomes, including bone, metabolic, cardiovascular, and general wellbeing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our project aims to develop child-tailored quantitative imaging tools for assessing treatment effects in children with cancer while ensuring the lowest possible radiation exposure. We are testing novel diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging and positron emission tomography technologies for therapy response assessment of pediatric cancers. We anticipate that child-tailored imaging tests will introduce a new, safer, more efficient, and more accurate generation of imaging exams for children that can be widely applied to interrogate health and disease without the risk of radiation-induced secondary cancers later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Here we study how elevated serum triglycerides worsen pancreatitis severity by being cleaved to unsaturated ω6, ω9 fatty acids via pancreatic and lipoprotein lipase, and how the dietary replacement of these fats by ω3 or saturated fats, or inhibition of lipases may reduce the severity of hypertriglyceridemia associated pancreatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: This project will investigate the role of tissue factor (TF) and TF-dependent signaling in venous thrombosis and growth of human pancreatic cancer, as well as its contribution to antiviral innate immune responses. We will use a novel mouse model of human pancreatic cancer. In addition, we will improve the current assays to measure extracellular vesicle TF and will identify risk markers for thrombosis in plasma. Furthermore, we will use two well described infection models with Coxsackievirus B3 myocarditis and H1N1 influenza A pneumonia. Our long-term goals are to further understand the protective and pathologic roles of TF, coagulation proteases and PARs in cancer and infections. Our studies might lead to new therapies to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: We are seeking effective regimen for therapeutic or prophylactic vaccination against the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). The strategy is to use targeted immunostimulants to guide the immune system to production of antibodies that neutralize the virus, which are thought to be an essential component of an effective vaccine. We will test newly developed immunostimulants for their capacity to elicit such neutralizing antibodies and determine the breadth of suppression achieved against diverse HIV strains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Millions of Americans are exposed to repetitive head impacts (RHI) through contact and collision sports (CCS) annually and may be at increased risk for later-life cognitive decline, mood and behavioral disturbances, and dementia. Yet, specific risk factors for these outcomes are unknown due to limitations of previous research, including: small samples, focus on male professional American football players, recruitment biases, and reliance on retrospective reports from informants of deceased athletes. The proposed study will address these limitations and be among the first to examine risk factors for, and characterize the frequency, severity, and profile of cognitive impairment, mood and behavioral disturbances, and dementia, in female and male former soccer players and male former American football players, by leveraging the existing Brain Health Registry to create the Head Impact and Trauma Surveillance Study (HITSS), which will be the largest longitudinal registry of female and male CCS athletes to date.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Cortical inhibitory interneurons (INs) balance and shape excitatory pyramidal neuron (PN) activity in normal cortical circuits and have been implicated in the etiology of brain disorders such as autism, schizophrenia, and epilepsy. However, little is known about the molecular mechanisms shaping synaptic connectivity of local IN circuits. Our studies will provide novel insights into the molecular identities and their interactions that govern synaptic specificity of IN networks and eventually open the floodgate to restoring brain function in disordered/damaged brains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Resistance to therapies is a cross-cutting and significant challenge. The challenge exists even for cancers targeted by precision therapies, as is the case with HER2-positive breast cancer. New tools capable of measuring understanding the mechanisms that cancer uses to subvert therapy are critical to informing design of next generation therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Legionnaires’ Disease is a type of bacterial pneumonia caused by the pathogen Legionella pneumophila, which infects the elderly and individuals who suffer from chronic lung disease or are immunocompromised. During infection of host cells, Legionella secretes a number of effector proteins that alter cellular signaling, including lysine methyltransferases that methylate chromatin to repress the expression of genes involved in immune response. Structural and biochemical studies of these enzymes will yield new insight into their biological functions in Legionella pathogenesis and inform the development of therapeutics to treat Legionnaires’ Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Substance use and dependence (SUD) develop and progress within problematic family interactions and relationships, yet traditional methods of analyzing interactions do not capture key dynamic parameters. This research will apply state-of-the art statistical methods to study the longitudinal effects of early family dynamics on adolescent SUD, and test mediation of genetic risk and family intervention effects based on randomization to the Family Check-Up and control conditions. The advanced investigation of the intervention mechanisms will inform the specification and refinement of more potent and effective family-based interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to study the intrinsic and synaptic adaptations of pyramidal neurons in the layer V of the primary motor cortex using experimental models of Parkinson’s disease (PD). With this research, we will gain mechanistic understanding of the aberrant motor cortical activity seen in individuals afflicted by PD, providing critical insight into PD’s pathophysiology that can help us to improve the treatment of this devastating disease. Therefore, this research is relevant to the missions of the NIH and the NINDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE As the World Health Organization works with local officials to eliminate malaria in the Greater Mekong Subregion, local information about parasite migration will be important for stratifying malaria risk. In the proposed research, we will identify recent and local malaria parasite migration patterns within a well-characterized border region of northern Cambodia and Thailand and determine how these patterns are affected by local human travel. If successful, this research will illuminate the contribution of movement by local population groups to spatial patterns of malaria parasite migration and will provide a framework to identify specific geographic areas for targeted intervention, which can be adapted to other malaria-endemic areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite the major advances in cardiac interventions, diabetic ischemic heart failure morbidity and mortality continue to rise. It is increasingly recognized that integrative approaches, rather those purely focusing on cardiomyocytes, must be undertaken for diabetic ischemic heart failure prevention/treatment. The current application endeavors to explore the basis of diabetic cardiac impairment mechanisms, adiponectin-resistance mediated microvascular circulatory dysfunction, with the ultimate goal of identifying new therapeutic targets at the molecular, cellular, and organ level in in vivo animal models, for the purpose of ameliorating diabetic ischemic heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multidrug resistant organisms (MDROs) are bacteria that have become resistant to more than one antibiotic and disproportionality affect the elderly residing in nursing homes, while high-throughput sequencing and large-scale data collection are integral to understanding the microbiome and its relation to age related disease. Our goal is to assess the gut microbiome of nursing home residents to determine carriage risk of MDROs and to assess the microbiomes influence on local and systemic immune functioning. We will develop novel rapid sequencing technology to better track these pathogens and define a microbiome and clinical based model to understand how age-related microbiome alterations as well as systemic immune functioning predicts the risk of both MDRO colonization and infection, in order to provide the basis for informing rational interventions and public health policies to better combat nursing home associated infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will consider (a) latency (lag) effects of both harmful and beneficial effects of exposures in ophthalmic studies (b) ordinal regression models to assess change in ordinal scales in longitudinal ophthalmic scales, such as the AREDS severity scale as an alternative to survival analysis to precisely capture changes in disease severity before a final endpoint (e.g., advanced AMD in studies of macular degenration, or total blindness in studies of diabetic retinopathy) is reached (c) assessment of measures of discrimination and risk reclassification when comparing risk models in ophthalmology using the eye as the unit of analysis, and (d) translational work on clustered data methods for the eye research community with a focus on (a) survival analysis, (b) binary longitudinal outcome data and (c) sample size/power estimation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: This project address the major challenge of improving the quality of vaccine-elicited responses against the neutralizing antibody targets on the virus pathogen by novel immunogen design. This study proposes to modify vaccine candidates derived from Zika virus (ZIKV) envelope glycoprotein for efficiently activating and expanding ZIKV neutralizing antibody precursor to achieve potent antibody response elicitation, and to avoid stimulating non-neutralizing precursors that cross-react with envelope glycoproteins from Dengue virus (DENV) with potential risk of mediating antibody dependent enhancement for DENV infection. The outcomes of this study will contribute to the development of a safe and effective Zika virus vaccine as well as increase understanding of host/pathogen interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: This study examines the possibility of using administrative data (e.g., Medicare; electronic health records) to ascertain outcomes in pragmatic clinical trials through automated algorithm development. If successful, the study will position us to make a large contribution to the field of aging research by establishing a framework for more efficiently designing and running pragmatic clinical trials, especially from a cost perspective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For symptomatic long QT patients prone to life threatening cardiac arrhythmia, pregnancy can facilitate a unique period of anti-arrhythmic protection of maternal life, when estrogen hormone level is at its highest. The current proposal seeks to employ LQT patient-specific induced pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes (iPSC-CMs) as a platform to investigate the effect of estrogen on arrhythmic propensity and the molecular pathways that facilitate its activity. The identified beneficial anti-arrhythmic molecular targets will be employed to optimize the design of an estrogen analogue with the intention of proposing new therapeutic entities that take advantage of hormone-based anti-arrhythmic benefits, for the treatment of both male and female patients at all ages, thus promoting the field of sex-specific therapeutics and translational and precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Relevance Our brain’s ability to generate decisions can be severely disrupted by psychiatric disorders, such as anxiety, depression, bipolar disorder, and obsessive compulsive disorder. This proposal develops novel analytical and experimental approaches for understanding decision making at the level of populations of individual neurons in human and non-human primate premotor cortex, an area tightly linked to decision making. By integrating a large collection of new and existing datasets reflecting the involvement of premotor cortex in a wide range of decision- making tasks, the proposed research is expected to generate fundamental knowledge about unifying principles of decision-related neural computation, which may ultimately lead to improvements in the diagnosis and treat- ment of decision-impacting psychiatric conditions.
