IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: This proposal describes a comprehensive plan for the applicant, Dr. Jerod Rasmussen, to obtain expert training and conduct research that aims to identify novel MRI-based measures of energy homeostasis-related brain circuitry in the human newborn, identify their gestational biology determinants, and determine the prospective association of these measures with subsequent risk for childhood obesity. The identification of brain-related biomarkers of childhood obesity risk that predate the influence of the obesogenic environment will contribute to an improved understanding of the neurological underpinnings of obesity, early identification of at-risk individuals, and intervention targets for primary prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Molecular mechanisms of intersecting human telomeric functions Narrative Telomeres are structures found at the ends of our chromosomes that are instrumental in ensuring the integrity of our genomes. This proposal aims to understand at a molecular level how human telomeres help maintain chromosome ends in different biological contexts, including in cancer cells, stem cells, and cells undergoing meiosis. These studies will enhance our knowledge of how telomeres uphold genome integrity and help develop strategies to counter telomere dysregulation in human diseases like cancer and infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Poor motor and cognitive function are related to AD and related pathologies (ADRD), but despite the accumulation of these pathologies in their brains, some older adults exhibit little loss of function. This study will identify and validate resilience proteins in older adults which may offset the effects of ADRD pathologies that accumulate in older brains. This work is timely as it will provide novel targets for further drug studies that can yield treatments to maintain motor and cognitive function in millions of older Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evidence suggests a role for pro-angiogenic macrophages in neovascular age-related macular degeneration pathogenesis, but currently there are no therapies to specifically target these cells. Our preliminary data demonstrates that beta-adrenergic receptor antagonism inhibits laser- induced choroidal neovascularization by reducing interleukin-6 expression in macrophages. We aim to dissect the beta-adrenergic receptor -> interleukin-6 -> angiogenesis pathway, and to determine how beta-adrenergic receptor inhibition influences the transcriptional profile of macrophages in order to identify new therapeutic targets that will inhibit macrophage-driven angiogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Young adults under criminal justice supervision are at an increased risk for development of substance use disorders; however, there is limited understanding of the real-time contextual, psychological, and behavioral antecedents of substance use in vulnerable young adults. This project will test the momentary psychological, behavioral, and geospatial risk for substance use in young adults enrolled in drug treatment court (DTC) by integrating geographically-explicit ecological momentary assessment (GEMA) data with risk terrain modeling (RTM). This project will develop a novel just-in-time adaptive intervention (JITAI) to reduce substance use in young adult DTC clients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Type 2 diabetes, even in adolescents, leads to damage to blood vessels that plausibly extends to the brain. Using advanced imaging methods, this project will comprehensively determine how the structure and function of blood vessels in the brain are impaired by type 2 diabetes and how that might lead to tissue loss and cognitive problems in teens. This new knowledge will drive optimal design of treatment approaches to prevent or reverse brain complications due to diabetes in adolescents that could otherwise extend to adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Desmoids are a rare and poorly understood type of tumor with outcomes that are highly variable, leaving patients and physicians uncertain about how aggressively the individual patient's treatment should be. We propose to pursue the hypothesis, suggested by our prior research, that proteins called β-catenin and HIF1α are central to the biology of desmoids. By discovering which other proteins act with β-catenin and HIF1α and testing whether these proteins are correlated with disease progression in patients with desmoids, we expect to discover markers that can predict patients' outcomes and that may allow for better decisions on whether a patient requires therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Therapeutic interventions in stroke, the fifth most common cause of death and the leading cause of adult disability in the United States, are currently limited to thrombolytic therapy within a narrow time window and development of effective therapies is urgently required. The object of this application is to test our hypothesis that Malat1 functions as a critical regulator in post-ischemic cerebral angiogenesis, thus affecting long-term neurological outcomes after ischemic stroke. The successful implementation of this proposal will elucidate the essential role of Malat1 in post-stroke angiogenesis and may eventually lead us to identify novel neurorestorative targets for the treatment of ischemic stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a blood cancer that often generates poor clinical outcomes, whereas antibody- mediated inhibition of MICA/B shedding is a new means of promoting immunity against a variety of cancers and that now has entered into clinical phase. Here we show that the first-of-its-kind inhibitory antibody of MICA/B shedding induces Fc receptor-driven immunity against AML in pre-clinical models, and now we modified it to display higher affinity to Fc activating receptors while maintaining the low affinity to inhibitory receptor. We propose to establish the anti-AML activity of this new molecule, thus generating important information about how to induce protective immunity against AML and supporting clinical transition with the best version of such MICA/B-targeted antibody.

PHR: Project Narrative Identification of the lung carcinogenic driver and elucidation of the molecular mechanisms involved in environmental lung carcinogenesis will be of high significance in facilitating our understanding of lung cancer development and will provide valuable information needed for the design of more effective agents for prevention and therapy of lung cancers. This application will test the hypothesis that MEG3 downregulation plays a crucial role in lung carcinogenesis caused by nickel exposure. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The alarming potential for deadly systemic infections, and the high prevalence of multi-drug resistant Serratia marcescens in hospital settings drive the need to identify additional targets for bacterial growth inhibition, which is currently impeded by the lack of reliable animal models. The proposed study will uncover novel details on the spatiotemporal spread of S. marcescens following intraperitoneal infection and will unveil a biological role for the extracellular nuclease produced by this organism during infection. This project will also chart a unified approach for the detailed analysis of other bacterial pathogens with secreted nucleases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA) progression following knee injuries remains problematic in spite of extensive and prolonged post-injury rehabilitation remediation. This proposal aims to determine the responses of knee cartilage to three most commonly modifiable rehabilitation elements that alter the knee joint loading environment following knee injuries using a well-established preclinical rat PTOA model: 1) duration of initial non-weight bearing; 2) level of physical activity; and 3) lower-limb joint kinematics. This innovative work will provide foundational groundwork to better understand the pathogenesis of PTOA and to determine the optimal regenerative rehabilitation principles aimed to mitigate PTOA after traumatic joint injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Molecular glues display several important pharmacodynamic advantages over drugs that operate through single targets, including enhanced on-target residence time and an ability to fundamentally rewire signal transduction networks. In this proposal, we will seek to build new compounds and next-generation drugs for targeting RAS-MAPK driven cancers that possess molecular glue-like features, thereby offering a new therapeutic path for selectively antagonizing RAS-MAPK driven malignancies in patients. Compounds will be built to overcome key efficacy and safety limitations of currently available drugs, thereby offering a new mode- of-action for targeting the RAS-MAPK pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is a frequent and life-threatening complication that significantly limits the successful outcome of transplantation. The proposal will study the interplay between humoral and cell mediated immunity in preventing viral recrudescence in newly established preclinical models of CMV reactivation after BMT. Thus, we will stringently define the mechanistic basis for cytomegalovirus reactivation following transplantation, enabling the development of readily translatable strategies with high potency that avoid the constraints that apply to current cellular therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transplantation is a cure for many end-stage organ diseases. Highly sensitized patients, those who have developed anti-donor antibody prior to organ transplantation via pregnancy, transfusion, or previous transplantation, remain challenging to transplant compared to their non-sensitized counterparts. As a result, sensitized patients stay longer on the waitlist and experience higher rates of mortality/morbidity. Xenotransplantation has long been proposed as a therapeutic strategy to address the ongoing organ shortage in transplantation and highly sensitized patients have been suggested to be potential first candidates. Xenotransplantation outcomes have improved over the last years due to progress in gene editing of the donor pig as well as improved immunosuppression. Despite this, antibody-mediated rejection (AMR) remains common and prevents long-term graft survival and clinical translation. Therefore, this project seeks to use a preclinical nonhuman primate model to test new therapeutic strategies targeting post-xenotransplantation humoral response, with the ultimate goals of minimizing graft rejection, preserving protective immunity, and maximizing patient health. The results of the study would directly inform the strategy for the first human xenotransplants and lower the risk of humans undergoing xenotransplantation. We anticipate future advances to move into clinical trials to help further prolong kidney transplant function and patient survival, thus extending the lifespan and quality of life of patients with kidney failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The retina is a small, disc-shaped piece of tissue located in the back of the eye that is responsible for vision. During development of the retina, over 100 diffent types of cells are produced that work together to allow for proper vision. This project aims to study how the production of this enormous cell diversity is regulated during development to ensure that the correct number of each of these cell types are produced and that they are produced evenly across the surface of the retina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: Project Narrative As the world’s population continues to age, the prevalence of Alzheimer’s disease will increase, generating greater urgency for creating methods capable of identifying individuals at risk for decline. This project will facilitate development of tools for enhancing early detection of Alzheimer’s disease, which in turn will allow for earlier intervention and improved methods to screen patients for clinical trials. Results will provide clinically applicable information on how olfactory deficit patterns manifest across early stages of the disease, and can potentially be used for improving diagnostic accuracy compared to normal aging, which in turn can reduce time spent in workups and can reduce delays in initiating treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The binding of glutamate to metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) and of g-aminobutyric acid (GABA) to GABAB receptors drives signaling cascades that start with G protein binding to the intracellular side of the receptor. We propose to obtain the cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structures of mGluR2, mGluR5 and GABAB receptor in complex with their G protein partners and interrogate the signaling mechanism with in vitro assays and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. As defects in glutamatergic and GABAergic signaling are linked to many neurological conditions such as Parkinson's disease, schizophrenia, drug addiction, depression, and pain, this knowledge will be ultimately used for the design of novel therapeutic strategies to combat these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The exponential growth in the nonmedical use of prescription opioids, including the commonly-prescribed oxycodone, has contributed strongly to devastating national public health consequences including addiction, overdose and transition to use of illicit opioids such as heroin. This proposal combines a novel rodent model of oxycodone abuse with cutting-edge chemogenetic technology for dissection of the neural circuits and mechanisms which underlie the development of opioid dependence and to help identify potential therapeutic approaches and targets for medications development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality, especially among individuals with low socioeconomic status, and addressing the lack of access to cardiac rehabilitation among individuals with low socioeconomic status may be an effective strategy for reducing cardiovascular disease disparities among these high risk medically underserved populations. We propose a theory-based intervention, delivered by community health workers, to increase cardiac rehabilitation participation among individuals with low socioeconomic status that addresses the multi-level barriers they face to enrollment. These research efforts will result in a cardiac rehabilitation intervention that will boost enrollment in patients with low socioeconomic status and reduce the cardiovascular disease disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Benzodiazepines are frequently prescribed to adolescents and young adults, yet we lack key data on misuse, abuse, and overdose risk following benzodiazepine treatment and on what policies reduce benzodiazepine- related harms in young people. The proposed research will examine the risk of overdose and harmful substance use following benzodiazepine treatment and will evaluate whether state prescription drug monitoring program features are associated with a reduction in benzodiazepine-related harms and risky benzodiazepine prescribing. As more young people seek treatment for mental illness, it is of urgent public health importance to investigate the misuse and abuse potential of commonly prescribed pharmaceutical treatments and to consider modifiable factors, such as existing prescription drug monitoring programs, that can be leveraged to reduce harms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Influenza virus infection causes severe lung damage and is associated with hundreds of thousands of respiratory deaths per year worldwide. A specialized subset of T cells known as regulatory T cells promotes resolution of lung inflammation and repair of lung damage following influenza infection. By studying how epigenetic mechanisms control regulatory T cells and how regulatory T cell-generated molecules induce lung repair, we will ascertain fundamental mechanisms of recovery from influenza, which will lead to novel therapies that decrease the morbidity and mortality caused by influenza.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Neural systems integrate response features (behavioral, HPA, and autonomic) to enable coping with stress. This proposal will utilize animal studies to elucidate novel neural pathways and mechanisms capable of linking active behavior with attenuated HPA and sympathetic responses, and passive behavior with exaggerated HPA and sympathetic responses following chronic stress exposure. Given the association between passive coping and disease susceptibility, these studies will help to link activity patterns in novel pathways involved in reversing behavioral, HPA, and autonomic features of passive coping responses, and in so doing will aid in the development of future interventions for the treatment of stress-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chagas disease is a major vector borne parasitic disease caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, and a major gap is that patients at increased risk of developing severe disease cannot be distinguished from those who may remain in the asymptomatic chronic stage, making any prognosis uncertain and complicating patient care and treatment. Our general objective is to determine the effects of T. cruzi parasite diversity on disease progression during the chronic phase by following naturally-infected Chagasic macaques and associating parasite genetic diversity with the immune response and clinical disease progression over time. These studies will allow testing for the role of parasite genetic diversity in shaping disease progression and are expected to lead to improved patient care and control of this important disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the hand’s sensorimotor control mechanisms have been extensively studied, our limited understanding of these mechanisms still challenges our ability to improve or restore sensorimotor function following traumatic or neurological injuries. We propose a novel approach – combining a dexterous manipulation task, robotic grasp analysis and surface electromyography – to quantify mechanisms responsible for coordination of grasp and manipulation forces. If the proposed exploratory studies are successful, our findings will enable clinicians to extract information about the state of the hand’s sensorimotor function that can potentially contribute to guide clinical decisions and the design of assistive and/or rehabilitation devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE While there are clear theoretical and well-documented empirical associations between more money and living longer, the size of the causal link is not clear because of practical and ethical challenges to giving money to people in a truly random fashion. This project studies the long-term consequences for mortality and life expectancy of a major land redistribution program in New Zealand that randomized the award of resources, allowing causal estimates of the link between wealth and health. The results of this research will inform health policy debates on wealth-transfer programs to improve later life outcomes across generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Project Narrative: APOBEC family cytidine deaminases are the cause of the second-most abundant type of mutation during cancer development. We recently identified APOBEC3A and APOBEC3B as, respectively, the primary and secondary sources of cytidine deaminase activity in breast cancer. This proposal investigates these enzymes' surprising ability to induce insertion/deletion mutations as well as how APOBEC3A-induced mutation is regulated through transcriptional activation, proteasomal degradation, and DNA repair mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Persistent pain is severely under-detected and under-managed in older persons with Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias (ADRD). Training family caregivers of persons with ADRD in observational pain assessment and subsequent communication of the assessment results to a health care provider has the potential to help address under-detection and under-management of pain in this population. This research will test the efficacy of the Pain Identification and Communication Toolkit (PICT), a multicomponent intervention for ADRD caregivers that provides training in observational pain assessment and coaching in effective pain communication techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Despite making up ~40% of acute kidney injury (AKI) cases, women are considered protected from AKI and are underrepresented in AKI research studies. Pregnancy is a unique physiological condition that places high demands on the kidneys, and recent clinical studies have identified AKI as a risk factor for poor fetal and maternal outcomes. Results from our proposed studies will establish a role for subclinical renal injury after AKI to impair the necessary renal, hemodynamic, and immune adaptations required for a health pregnancy, and potentially provide mechanistic insight to guide better clinical care for all AKI patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Sepsis is a deadly condition caused by a dysregulated immune response to infection which affects 700,000 patients per year in the US alone. Early and accurate diagnosis of sepsis, and infection underlying sepsis is critical to inform treatment choices and to prevent serious organ injury and death, but diagnostic options remain limited. This proposal addresses this unmet medical need with the development of a minimally invasive blood test based on a multi-omics profiling of circulating cell-free DNA to simultaneously inform host responses, quantify organ injury and identify infection underlying sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Microbiome proﬁling can provide insight into risk and inform strategies to reduce the incidence of graft-versus-host disease, a frequent and life-threatening complication of stem cell transplantation, but there is a need for new data science approaches to untangle this complex, high-dimensional, and noisy data. We will develop new methods to improve visualization and prediction using microbiome data, along with eﬃcient and easy-to-use implementations. By applying these methods to microbiome data collected from stem cell transplant recipients, and providing free software to enable researchers to apply these methods to their own data, our work will enable new insights that will ultimately drive the development of strategies to predict and mitigate this serious complication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE Understanding the spatial organization of the gut microbiome can reveal crucial insights for its composition, stability, and resiliency, and improve our knowledge of its essential roles in digestion, metabolism, and immunity. This proposal aims to develop and apply new technologies for spatial metagenomics to dissect the micron-scale structure of the gut microbiome in mice models and in healthy and dysbiotic human cohorts. Findings from this study will have direct relevance for deciphering the principles governing microbial colonization of the gastrointestinal tract, which can help guide the development of clinical treatments using microbiome-based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative LINE1 (L1) retroelements are like dormant viruses that live in our genome, which are abnormally activated in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The proposed studies will investigate a novel hypothesis that involves the role of ORF0, a recently discovered antisense gene found in L1s, in the pathogenesis of SLE. The final goal of this proposal is to understand the importance of these “genomic parasites” in SLE, which may lead to novel diagnostic and therapeutic targets for the prevention and treatment of this severe and still incurable disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Ataxin-1 is a protein that, when mutated, causes the neurodegenerative disorder known as spinocerebellar ataxia type 1. Recent evidence suggests that the non-mutated form of ataxin-1 takes part in numerous cellular processes including the regulation of neuronal cell proliferation, Alzheimer's disease tissue vulnerability, and the control of autoimmune response. Here, we propose to develop a novel conditional knockout mouse model which allows the study of ataxin-1 pathophysiological activity in any selected cell type and developmental stage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Overall Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is a chronic psychiatric illness that affects 2-3% of the worldwide population. This Center examines the neural network that underlie impaired behavioral flexibility, especially in the assessment of aversive outcomes, a key feature of OCD. The results from the collective studies will have relevance to several psychiatric diseases and will help optimize targets and parameters for neuromodulation as a potential therapeutic approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Developmental defects in eye structure commonly account for visual impairment in newborns, yet we lack an understanding of the cellular dynamics and molecular pathways driving the proper formation of the eye. A compelling candidate to play a role in controlling eye formation is the complex, glycoprotein-rich extracellular matrix (ECM): mutations in certain ECM components can lead to specific structural defects in the eye that cause visual impairment in humans and model organisms. Here, our goal is to determine the mechanistic roles of specific ECM molecules in the formation and development of particular parts of the eye, using the small freshwater teleost fish Danio rerio (zebrafish), and a combination of microscopy, computational methods, and molecular genetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Our recent clinical and experimental work has for the first time revealed that UBR5, an E3 ubiquitin ligase with novel protooncogene properties, profoundly promotes breast cancer growth and metastasis at least in a major part through regulating the expression of two important targets: CDC73 (a tumor suppressor) and PD-L1 (an immune checkpoint regulator). The proposed project will further expand and deepen the exploration of underlying cellular and molecular mechanisms whereby UBR5 controls CDC73’s crucial activities and the broad IFN--mediated signaling in cancer cells. The results will lay the groundwork for developing innovative and efficacious therapeutic strategies for TNBC by targeting UBR5 and its downstream signaling pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project aims to bring the advancements in multi-high-b-value diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) to the breast to enable a comprehensive characterization of breast tissue. This will be achieved by developing a novel, distortion-resilient, and time-efficient diffusion pulse sequence – Steer-PROP for breast DWI (SPREAD) – and an integrated multi-modal MRI analysis framework – TERMINAL – for the breast. These important tools will enable DWI acquisition with a full b-value spectrum and DWI analysis for assessing malignancy and evaluating treatment response in breast cancer.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women are at greater lifetime risk for Alzheimer’s disease (AD). One potential contributing factor is the midlife neuroendocrine aging transition. PhytoSERM addresses a critical unmet need in women’s health for an alternative hormone therapy that is both safe and efficacious for menopausal symptoms and to reduce risk of AD later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the dynamics and regulatory mechanisms of guanosine signaling in the brain during ischemia is expected to advance knowledge of the brains immediate neuroprotection response and provide critical information on potential therapeutic targets for ischemia. Methods to monitor rapid guanosine signaling at the local site of ischemia during injury are lacking and we will bridge this critical gap by developing new platforms which combine millisecond-to-second guanosine recording with microfluidic focal brain stimulation. Thus, this proposal is relevant to part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to fostering fundamental creative discoveries and innovative research strategies as a basis for protecting and improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Although the gene ORMDL3 is highly associated with the development of asthma, little is known about the function of ORMDL3 and how it may contribute to the development of asthma. In this study we will use immune cells cells from humans as well as a mouse model of asthma to determine how ORMDL3 causes asthma. This may provide insight into novel treatments for asthma.

PHR: Project Narrative - Relevance to Public Health Spinal Muscular Atrophy with Respiratory Distress Type I (SMARD1) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no effective treatment or cure. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Dynamic rearrangements of the actin cytoskeleton are essential for countless biological processes, including cell motility, endocytosis, cell division, intracellular transport, and cell and tissue morphogenesis. Furthermore, defects in actin regulation lead to a range of disorders, including Alzheimer’s disease, Huntington’s disease, Parkinson’s diseases, Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), cardiovascular diseases, developmental disorders (e.g., limb deformities, infertility, and hearing impairment), and cancer. This proposal focuses on the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying actin dynamics and organization. It takes aim at major gaps in our knowledge of how groups of actin regulatory proteins work together in multi-component mechanisms to govern actin dynamics in living systems. The proposed research will resolve these mechanisms, and in doing so provide new insights into the molecular basis of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regulatory T (Treg) cells play a central role in immune homeostasis and mitigating organ-specific autoimmune disorders including multiple sclerosis (MS), in which the immune system attacks axons in the Central Nervous System (CNS). Our goal is to investigate how Treg cells function to limit MS using two-photon microscopy to directly visualize cellular interactions in the CNS during experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a murine model of MS. A better understanding of the cellular and molecular mechanisms of Treg cell function will aid in developing effective Treg-based therapeutic strategies to treat MS and several other autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Most common diseases afflicting human health result from complex combination of genetic, stochastic, behavioral and environmental factors interacting with age, whereas rare inherited retinal diseases (IRDs) are simpler single-gene defects that form the ideal basis for gene-based treatments. Despite decades of exciting progress, there is only one approved treatment for IRDs and a major contributing factor for this scarcity is the lack of biomarkers that can provide sensitive, reliable, and clinically meaningful measurement of photoreceptor degeneration over the duration of a typical clinical trial. This research plan is designed to fill this major gap for the most common molecular form of IRD which is Stargardt disease caused by ABCA4 mutations and forge a path to follow for other IRDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection can cause severe lung inflammation and life-threatening illness in young children but there are currently no available therapies to treat or prevent RSV. This study focuses on understanding how RSV infection triggers defective natural killer (NK) cell immunity and disrupts inflammation resolution pathways that contribute to lung inflammation and respiratory failure in children. Restoring host- protective NK cell immune pathways with specialized pro-resolving mediator molecules has the potential to lead to novel therapeutic approaches to accelerate the resolution of lung inflammation in RSV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Critical limb threating ischemia (CLTI), the most severe form of peripheral arterial disease, is characterized by rest pain and tissue loss, is a major risk factor for amputation, and accounts for over 10 billion dollars in medical costs annually. Surgical treatment for CLTI often is unsatisfactory or not a viable option, and there are no effective pharmacological therapies, especially for diabetic patients; thus, a great need exists for novel treatment strategies to stimulate vascularization, counteract ischemic muscle damage, and ultimately reduce the incidence of lower limb amputations. This proposal is designed to determine the potential of a novel vertebral bone adherent mesenchymal stromal cell, encapsulated in an alginate hydrogel, to ameliorate effects of CLTI and to determine mechanisms by which these cells promote muscle regeneration, ultimately leading to the development of molecular therapies for this major cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Infants born to mothers with obesity during pregnancy are at greater risk of developing obesity. Lifestyle interventions, such as exercise, during pregnancy may be a viable strategy to offset this risk; however, mechanisms are lacking. This research project will be the first step to understanding the cellular mechanisms, using human umbilical-cord mesenchymal stem cells, of how maternal exercise decreases obesity risk in infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will develop working prototypes to enable imaging technology and provide previously unavailable polymer-based, indexing-patterned substrates and methods for correlative light and electron microscopy (CLEM) study of cells grown on porous substrates. These designable porous substrates will not only facilitate cells to obtain in vivo-like morphology and function but also simplify and streamline CLEM protocols, leading to better understanding of diseases at molecular and ultrastructral levels. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Treatments are limited for infections of Trypanosoma brucei, which sequentially expresses different variant surface glycoproteins (VSGs, its major surface antigen) in a strictly monoallelic manner to evade the host’s immune response. We have found that RAP1 silences all but one VSG genes and suppresses VSG switching. In this proposal, we will investigate how RAP1’s novel nucleic acids binding activities and its interactions with other telomeric proteins, histones, and chromatin remodelers contribute to monoallelic VSG expression and proper antigenic variation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There are many possible ways for an infection in the lung to become a severe pneumonia. We will test whether a subset of pneumonias is severe because of a deleterious interaction between our coagulation system and our immune system within the infected lung. If so, this particular subset of pneumonia patients may respond favorably to therapies that interfere with these activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: We have found that the gene TWIST1 increases the risk for multiple vascular diseases in humans, likely by causing smooth muscle cells in the blood vessel wall to multiply and change their cell properties, but the mechanisms by which this occurs are unclear. Our studies are designed to uncover how smooth muscle cells multiply and change their cell properties in very granular detail, and to determine how TWIST1 modifies this process to cause disease. We will also determine how common genetic changes in people with vascular disease affect TWIST1 expression and the risk for disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In individuals with neuropathic pain, females show increased expression of interferon gamma (IFNγ) induced genes in their dorsal root ganglia (hDRG) suggesting a potential sex specific mechanism in the production of pain. To elucidate which cells in hDRG are capable of releasing IFNγ, I will isolate each immune cell type from hDRGs of both sexes and perform transcriptomic and proteomic assessments looking for IFNγ genes and proteins. Then I will expose cultured hDRG neurons of both sexes to IFNγ and perform a comprehensive analysis looking at the functional, transcriptomic, and proteomic changes that occur to determine what alterations IFNγ could be causing at the hDRG to produce neuropathic pain.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will test the delivery of a tailored music intervention as an evidence-based therapeutic approach for very preterm infants hospitalized in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) during a critical period of brain development. We will test the effects of the intervention on acute and cumulative stress during the NICU stay, relevant measures of regional brain volumes (amygdala) and intranetwork connectivity (language and salience networks), and a range of neurodevelopmental outcomes, with a primary outcome of language performance at 2 years corrected age. The overall goal is to establish music medicine as an evidence-based innovative therapy in the neonatal intensive care unit that improve long-term neurodevelopmental outcomes for the ~63,000 very preterm infants born each year in the U.S. and many more worldwide.

PHR: Project Narrative: VEXAS (Vacuoles, E1 enzyme, X-linked, Autoinflammatory, Somatic) syndrome is a newly identified inflammatory and hematologic disease caused by somatic mutations in UBA1. VEXAS syndrome is present in tens of thousands of Americans, confers higher morbidity and mortality, and remains treatment resistant. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative The cyclical nature and repercussions of the associations between addiction, incarceration, and traumatic stress have been thoroughly documented in decades of research. However, evidence-based, trauma-focused interventions are not often used in prisons, despite promising evidence that they may reduce drug use and crime by improving the mental health of incarcerated people prior to release. This study will: 1) test the effectiveness of a trauma-focused group therapy to reduce post-incarceration drug use; 2) evaluate implementation facilitation, a promising strategy for supporting uptake of the therapy in prisons, and 3) measure the cost of the therapy and the implementation strategy to inform later scale up.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Relevance/Project Narrative Although a number of medicines have been used for the treatment of hypertension, more than 10 million of the patients are resistant to medications. The objective of this project is to develop a tissue-like bioadhesive electronic device that is soft, stretchable, and suture-free for the treatment of resistant-hypertension. Compared to existing devices for resistant-hypertension therapy, this novel device will significantly reduce the risk of tissue damage and inflammation, introduce minimal invasiveness to patients, providing the next-generation device for hypertension therapies and helping a huge number of resistant-hypertension patients control their blood pressure. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative  Dysregulation of gene expression is a frequent cause of disease. Expression of two genes is frequently coupled, for example in the case of bidirectional promoters which control the expression of about one in ten human genes, yet are poorly understood and we lack the technology to study them. We therefore propose to develop an integrated experimental and computational toolkit to study coupled expression of two genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Androgen receptor signaling is a major player driving prostate cancer progression. This application is designed to elucidate the molecular mechanism by which loss of the chromatin remodeler gene CHD1 results in abnormal intratumoral androgen synthesis, aberrant activation of the androgen receptor, and resistance to antiandrogen therapy in prostate cancer. Studies in this propose will evaluate the anti-cancer efficacy of the newly identified small molecular inhibitors of the signaling pathway that drives antiandrogen therapy resistance in prostate cancer with loss of the CHD1 gene.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative This project will equip neuroscience researchers, radiologists, MRI technologists, and study coordinators with au- tomatic, objective, fast, and accurate tools for image quality assessment so that timely decisions for re-scans can be made to improve the likelihood of collecting usable structural MRI data of sufficient sample size for subsequent analyses. Our tools will allow (i) high-speed image quality assessment with high specificity and sensitivity, (ii) ret- rospective artifact correction without the need for modification of pulse sequences or mounting of motion markers, and (iii) method generalizability and optimality for multiple sites, scanners, and imaging protocols without explicit data sharing. Successful completion of this project will allow image quality assurance to be done automatically in large-scale, multi-site, and longitudinal studies, and increase the amount of usable data for improving statistical power.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health with the goal to improve orthopaedic management of foot deformity for individuals with cerebral palsy by evaluating hindfoot function using biplane fluoroscopy and establishing standardized bone coordinate systems for consistent and accurate measurement of kinematics. Our contribution here is expected to include a robust approach for defining accurate standardized bone coordinate systems that are agnostic to asymptomatic, pathological, and deformity morphometric variation. This study is expected to identify long-term surgical correction strengths and deficiencies in adult patients living with CP and to provide knowledge to guide future clinical decision-making to improve long-term surgical interventions that benefit these patients as they grow into adulthood and achieve independence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fungi, including the spore-forming environmental yeast Cryptococcus, are emerging pathogens that cause life- threatening diseases in humans. The proposed research is relevant to public health because determining the fundamental biology of Cryptococcus spores and how they infect the mammalian lung will provide information necessary to understand how fungal pathogens infect people and cause fatal diseases. This project is relevant to the missions of the NIH and NIAID because it proposes basic research that will ultimately lead to new strategies to prevent and/or treat severe fungal disease, which will enhance human health and reduce illness, particularly among immunocompromised patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE We discovered a new posttranslational modification of TDP-43, citrullination (citR), and confirmed its accumulation in Limbic-Predominant Age-related TDP-43 Encephalopathy (LATE) human brain and TDP-43 animal models. We state that the "coordinated activation state” of peptidyl arginine deiminase 4 (PAD4) induces citrullination of TDP-43, impairs protein function, promotes cytoplasmic accumulation and aberrant protein phase-separation dynamics. This application will unravel mechanisms of PAD4-mediated citrullination implicated in TDP-43 pathogenesis that characterize LATE and ADRDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Although brain arteriovenous malformations (bAVMs) are a high-risk factor for intracerebral hemorrhage, especially for young patients, the pathophysiology is not well understood, and the treatment options are severely limited. By the notion that endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EndMT) is involved in human bAVM, the current proposal addresses the underlying molecular mechanisms of the EndMT in bAVM development by in vivo and in vitro approaches using our novel mouse model of bAVM. The proposal is relevant to the NIH's mission because understanding the pathomechanisms of bAVMs could lead to the development of therapeutic strategies for bAVM patients, subsequently preventing hemorrhagic stroke and improving their life quality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thoracic aortic aneurysm is a prevalent and currently incurable cardiovascular disease associated with significant morbidity and mortality, which affects children and adults. The proposed research seeks to identify novel genetic factors that modify its degree of severity and to develop a novel echocardiographic image analysis algorithm. We anticipate that the knowledge arising from this research will benefit patients by increasing the ability to give more precise assessment of prognosis and tailor management accordingly as well as identify mechanisms that may be amenable to future therapeutic targeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Recent experiments reveal that the scaffold and neurotransmitter receptor proteins that make up synapses are not homogeneously distributed as previously thought, but cluster into one or more distinct nanometer- scale structures within the synapse. The functional significance of these structures remains unclear. To investigate their role in synaptic function, we propose to apply novel tools we previously developed to rapidly and reversibly control their size and position within the synapse. Understanding how these structures influence synapse function will deepen our understanding of how they contribute to neural signaling in the healthy brain and whether they play a role in synaptic dysfunction responsible for numerous brain diseases and disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative: Alopecia is a major side effect of Taxol (paclitaxel), a key drug in the current treatment of ovarian and other cancers, used as a frontline agent in combination with carboplatin/cisplatin, and a second line drug with a dose intensive regimen following recurrence. We have made an important finding that low intensity ultrasound can effectively neutralize the cytotoxic effect of paclitaxel on cultured cells by disrupting paclitaxel-induced rigid and stabilized microtubule bundles, removing the cell killing activity of paclitaxel. The proposed study aims to develop and apply this discovery to protect the highly proliferative hair follicle cells from paclitaxel cytotoxicity, which will prevent short-term and permanent alopecia and improve the quality of life for cancer patients undergoing treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of cases of pediatric acute respiratory distress syndrome (PARDS) are triggered by lower respiratory tract infections, and more that 40% of children who die PARDS-related deaths were previously healthy, very young children. The unique airway environment of each child contributes to the heterogeneity of PARDS, and there is a lack of insight into how the airway environment influences immunity, resulting in a lack of therapies that hasten recovery from PARDS. The goal of this research is to determine whether neutrophil death promotes sustained inflammation leading to poor clinical outcomes in intubated children with PARDS, to explain the heterogeneity of PARDS, to enable risk stratification, and to inform the development of targeted therapies to reduce the high occurrence of PARDS-related disability and death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is an inherited genetic condition in which benign tumors develop along the nerve tissues. Challenges for the clinical management of this disease include the surveillance patients must undergo, a relative paucity of treatment options for late-stage disease, and the monitoring for recurrence following surgical treatment. We propose to apply state of the art genomic technologies and novel computational algorithms to profile blood combined with radiology to support noninvasive risk assessment, early detection, and post- treatment monitoring of this population and to improve patient outcomes.

PHR: Narrative Albeit intensive mitigation strategies are applied to manage known clinical risk factors, atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risks remain high in the type 2 diabetic (T2DM) population. This project will functionally test the impact of these regulators and assess their contribution to improving T2DM-ASCVD predictive modeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) affects 15% of the adult population in the United States and these patients have a fracture rate 2 to 15 times that of the general population, yet our current approach to focus only on parathyroid hormone has not been effective in reducing fractures. In the current proposal, we will test if a toxin that accumulates in CKD is a cause of the extra fracture risk seen in patients with CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During the onset of vertebrate organogenesis, the emergence of repetitive morphological units is tightly coupled to the expression of morphogens. Using assays designed to infer supracellular material properties, here we study how morphogens enable interacting supracellular phases primed with the capacity to generate organ architecture. This investigation develops a generalizable paradigm for how morphogen modulation of supracellular dynamics shapes organs, which may serve as a foundation for future work aimed at tissue engineering and repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative The brain cells of a fetus give off small vesicles called “exosomes”, which find their way into the mother's blood and can be purified from the blood without disturbing the fetus. We will determine whether molecules in these fetal-derived exosomes can predict which at-risk fetuses will be born with fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), the most involvedend of the fetal alcohol spectrum disorders( FASD), or one of the partial forms, the most common cause of developmental intellectual disability in the US. Non-invasive in utero diagnosis could lead to earlier detection and better research into therapies to prevent or ameliorate FAS/D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed ancillary study will leverage an ongoing randomized controlled trial to address whether statins prevent two of the most common cardiovascular conditions experienced by older adults—heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). This proposal will also determine the negative impact of relying on diagnosis codes to identify HFpEF and AMI events in the modern era. The proposed research is consistent with the broader public health goals of disease prevention, and addresses NHLBI Strategic Vision Objective 5 to “develop and optimize novel… therapeutic strategies to prevent… diseases.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this research is to evaluate the effect of digitally delivered social support training for promoting sustained moderate-to-vigorous physical activity increases, using a cluster randomized controlled trial. Self- selected teams of 3-8 insufficiently active adults (about 60 teams comprised of a total of N=300 participants) will be randomized to receive either a 3-month, theory-based, remotely delivered physical activity intervention (mobile-compatible web app with behavior change content, Fitbit physical activity tracker, tailored goals, and feedback) or the same intervention plus digitally delivered social support training. The proposed research will yield essential, rigorous evidence on a novel and promising strategy for leveraging existing social relationships to enhance physical activity among insufficiently active adults, using a scalable platform that can readily be disseminated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An aberrant Unfolded Protein Response (UPR), due to continued protein folding and processing overload in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), is known to drive obesity-related co-morbidities. We found compelling evidence that UPR is dysregulated during osteogenic repair in obesity and may underlie poor fracture outcomes in obese individuals, that prolong disability and often necessitate surgical intervention. Using genetic and pharmacologic tools, this proposal will determine if targeting one or more response arms of the UPR in skeletal stem cells can alleviate the obesity-related fracture repair deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gene therapy for inherited and acquired cardiovascular diseases has been limited by either low efficiency or toxicity of the vectors used to introduce genes into cells of the heart. We will investigate how gene therapy using a promising vector approach that relies on bioengineered adeno-associated viruses (AAVs) can be improved by site-directed ultrasound-mediated cavitation of microbubble contrast agents. These studies are intended to produce vital knowledge of ideal conditions, efficacy, and safety of cavitation-mediated transduction needed for translation into humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The recent appreciation of memory CD8 T cell populations that strictly reside in tissues, where infections and cellular transformation occur, provides an exciting opportunity to create new approaches to enhance or modulate immunity in “tissue-tailored” immune responses. By identifying the unique transcriptional pathways and regulators of tissue-resident memory T cells and the distinct programming associated with different tissues, we will discover novel targets with the potential to inform strategic design of therapeutic and protective vaccines, the development of which are of crucial importance to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney disease (ADPKD) results from insufficient functional amounts of PKD1/Polycystin-1, yet no approved therapy is available to increase Polycystin-1 nor prevent this disease from resulting in 5-10% of end-stage kidney disease in populations across the globe. We have identified that Polycystin-1 translation from PKD1 mRNA is dramatically blunted in vitro due to alternative translation of upstream open reading frames (uORFs) from the PKD1 5’UTR without which Polcystin-1 expression could be 3-4 times more. For this award we propose testing the role of uORF translation in ADPKD and therapeutic potential of blocking PKD1 uORF translation using humanized mouse models genetically-edited to lack uORF initation codons or steric inhibition of uORF translation with antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are more than 2 million American women who have survived breast cancer for five or more years, and for whom risk of late recurrence is a never-ending concern. We propose to discover the first molecular test to predict a woman’s risk for late breast cancer recurrence. Such a test would allow risk stratification for initiating one of several new and emerging therapies to prevent late recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to generate novel endochin-like quinolones optimized for use in new malaria elimination strategies focused on preventing transmission of Plasmodium parasites by Anopheles mosquitoes. Taking a holistic, bench-to-product approach comprising in vitro medicinal chemistry to in vivo efficacy studies and product prototyping, this 5-year project will test the full potential of delivering antimalarials to mosquitoes as a way to prevent malaria transmission, and will pave the way for full-scale epidemiological trials in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In some forms of chronic inflammatory arthritis, T cells provide excessive help to B cells leading to local autoantibody production in the joints. Using samples from children with arthritis, this study aims to better understand how regulatory T cells restrain these aberrant T cell-B cell responses that occur in inflamed tissues. Our research may provide insights into how to control inflammation and better treat patients with arthritis and other autoimmune conditions characterized by autoantibody formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cannabidiol (CBD)-derived tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) products, such as Delta-8-THC (∆8-THC) are legal and increasingly used in vaping devices. Vaping-induced oxidation of CBD, ∆8-THC, and other THC isomers is likely enhanced by pro-oxidant constituents in the liquids, such as metals and flavoring chemicals. Studies outlined in this application will link pro-oxidant constituents in THC vaping liquids and vaping-induced oxidation products, with modified biological functions in epithelial cells using in vitro and in vivo models, thus providing novel, urgently needed, mechanistic information on vaping THC products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have identified a promising new active combination, ATR and BET family protein inhibition, that exploits a common genetic alteration, the ARID1A mutation. This mutation is found in ~50% of clear cell ovarian cancers (CCOC), which lack effective therapies. The genomic and proteomic studies described herein will validate ARID1A mutation as a predictive biomarker for ATRi-BETi treatment of CCOC and will also identify additional predictive biomarkers of response to further optimize this therapy for future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This project explores the fate of fatty acid substrate in organs impacted by primary mitochondria disease - specifically by a major defect in oxidative phosphorylation (oxphos) - and the potential consequences on the adaptive responses to the oxphos deficiency. We will test the hypothesis that substrate metabolism in an organism with primary mitochondrial disease in muscle is rewired such that the liver and heart each acquire a greater role to take up and to oxidize fatty acids, thereby mitigating lipid-induced stress responses in oxphos-deficient muscle while providing the liver with a gluconeogenic substrate. These studies are expected to provide insight into how multi- organ compensation could mitigate a lipid burden and reductive stress in oxphos-deficient muscle, which is a major issue that is understudied, and to uncover novel regulation of the stress responses to mitochondrial dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Currently there are no drugs that significantly alter the clinical hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease, such as impaired memory and loss of executive function. We aim to develop a novel compound that is both neuroprotective and able to harness the good aspects of the brain's immune system in order to prevent the loss of brain function in Alzheimer's disease. If successful in clinical trials, this approach could prove beneficial for the treatment not only of Alzheimer's disease but also a number of other age-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative  Inputting and editing text, which constitutes over 40% of one’s smartphone usage, remains a challenge for blind smartphone users vis-à-vis their sighted counterparts, with studies showing that blind users typing speed on smartphones is an order of magnitude slower compared to sighted users. This project will research and develop a new generation of intelligent text input and editing methods that will substantially enhance both the ease of use and efficiency of these operations and thereby bridge the gap in user experience between blind smartphone users and sighted users. More importantly, the intelligent text input and editing methods that will merge from this project will eliminate any barriers to productivity of blind smartphone users and empower them to utilize the power and connectivity of these devices to fully participate in this digitized economy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A tremendous problem in molecular therapeutics is the difficulty in targeting specific cell types or diseased cells within healthy tissue due to the lack of efficient delivery methods carriers that do not provoke an immune response or evade endosomal capture. In this project, new technology will be developed to utilize extracellular vesicles (EVs) as molecular cargo to deliver molecular therapeutics and to uncover the EV-cell interaction and delivery. This project aims to demonstrate the proof-of-principle of an EV-mediated therapeutic delivery system applicable to diverse diseases awaiting targeted therapeutic delivery for clinical application into EGFR-type tumors resistant to existing therapeutics by targeted delivery and efficacy in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a common health condition that affects about 10% of women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS have elevated levels of the male androgen hormone testosterone and a high prevalence of obesity, insulin resistance, and elevated blood pressure, which lead to cardiovascular disease. This proposed research will shed light on novel androgens-mediated mechanisms that will translate into effective and safe therapeutic agents to treat the cardio-metabolic complications frequently found in women with PCOS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative  RB1 is a tumor suppressor gene that is frequently mutated in various tumors, including retinoblastomas, small cell lung cancers, triple-negative breast cancers, prostate cancers, and osteosarcomas. Despite extensive studies of pRb family proteins, a therapeutic approach that specifically targets defects in this tumor suppressor is currently not available, underscoring the need for alternative strategies that can identify new targets for cancers with inactivated RB1. We propose to identify a pair of FDA-approved drugs targeting synthetic lethal partners of RB1 to develop a novel personalized therapy for RB1-mutated tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Urine drug testing (UDT) is an integral aspect of opioid use disorder treatment, yet no universal standards exist for how it should be used in clinical practice. The lack of clear guidance may result in inappropriate testing or missed opportunities to guide clinical care. The purpose of this project is to examine the use of UDT in a large, real-world population and assess the attitudes, knowledge, and practices of clinicians who order UDT.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebellar involvement in dysmetric reach movements provides a window into ethologically relevant kinematic features that can be studied across species. This proposal will use experimental approaches to test theories of early cerebellar computations that guide movement endpoint precision in practice. With the long-term goal of better linking actions to circuit functions, this has the potential to better inform us about where and when to apply therapeutic interventions in cases of injury or disease to the motor system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women who use drugs have a high risk of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and related adverse sexual and reproductive health outcomes, and treating drug use could reduce substance use and sexual risk behavior while also increasing STI/HIV testing uptake, which in turn may ultimately reduce STI risk. The goal of the proposed research is to measure the associations between drug treatment and STI incidence among women who use drugs, evaluate the potential mediating pathways, and examine whether individual, social, and structural factors may modify these associations. Results of this research will inform targets for actionable interventions to improve women’s health, reduce morbidity and mortality, and address inequities in drug treatment and sexual and reproductive health.

PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance The follicle associated epithelium (FAE) of the Peyer’s patch is comprised of Microfold (M) cells that are critical for the surveillance and delivery of gut luminal content to underlying immune cells. The current study will utilize human enteroids co-cultured with innate immune cells to advance our understanding of how gut microbes and immune cells specifically regulate human M cell function.

PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will lead to development of biomarkers that reflect granular neurobiological principles underlying ASD and related neurodevelopmental conditions. Among these individuals, understanding and addressing challenges related to atypical sensory processing is repeatedly noted as a common goal that would improve quality of life. In the long term, by developing objective brain-based measures of sensory processing (which has historically been a subjective phenomenon), this work has the potential to elevate research for a host of different diseases, alongside a wide variety of neurodevelopmental and sensory conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Aneuploidy has been associated with a worse clinical outcome in many solid tumors, and specific chromosomal aberrations can be prognostic. Yet, little attention has been given to the role of aneuploidy in MPSNT. Our prior work has shown that Chr8 gain is a near universal event in MPNST and that the Chr8 gene, UBR5 is highly expressed in MPNST compared to the benign precursor, and promotes cell survival in. The goal of this proposal is to define when in malignant transformation Chr8 gain and UBR5 expression occurs, to determine if there is a correlation with overall survival, and to dissect the mechanism by which UBR5 functions in MPNST. These studies have the potential to impact early diagnosis, prognostication, and development of therapies for MPNST through a better understanding of the pathogenesis of this deadly cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current hepatitis C virus diagnostics present the greatest barrier to viral cure and elimination, and an accurate, simple, rapid, and affordable molecular test for viral RNA is needed to increase detection of hepatitis C virus along with important coinfections such as human immunodeficiency virus. This proposal seeks to eliminate key barriers to low-cost molecular testing for RNA viruses using novel chemistries and bespoke microfluidics that enable minimally trained healthcare workers to perform on-demand duplex molecular testing in the clinic. Achieving device development proposed in Aim 1 or Aim 2 will represent a significant advance that can be leveraged to improve hepatitis C testing, and combined, these technologies will have an important positive impact on RNA virus detection with an economical, agile molecular detection system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fecal microbiota transplant (FMT) is a promising, novel intervention to promote restitution and repair of colonic dysbiosis, but does it adequately restore eubiosis of the small intestine which differs considerably in membership, function, and impact on the host? We will test the hypothesis that region-specific donor microbes transplanted into non-native intestinal niches inadequately restore microbiota composition and function, resulting in adverse effects on host health, metabolism and immunity. The insights gained from these studies are likely to raise awareness to the potential limitations and unintended consequences of current FMT practices and lead to a rethinking of strategies for the development of future live biotherapeutic products (LBPs) for maintenance of health and better clinical outcomes for many diseases that have a microbial basis.

We will also examine genetic risk markers in a large US genetic database - SPARK, and in a NIH funded genetic sample from Sweden. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WESTERN MICHIGAN UNIV SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative As the population of aged individuals rises so will the burden of aging -associated diseases that are counteracted by natural antibodies produced by a unique population of B lymphocytes termed B1 cells. B1 cells and the natural antibody protection they afford deteriorate with advancing age in males, but remain highly effective in females, although the reasons for this sex-associated disparity remain unclear. The present study is designed to fill this gap in knowledge by utilizing advanced genetic tools, biomolecular assays, and discrete antibody analysis to determine the mechanisms responsible for persistence of B1 cell number and function in older females so that it will be feasible to enhance B1 cell activity into old age for all.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This application centers on a major gap in our understanding of the inhibitory mechanisms hampering corneal nerve regeneration. Towards this purpose, we propose to examine the role of galectin-3 in modulating the neural pathways underlying corneal disease and investigating whether therapeutic inhibition of galectin-3 improves corneal nerve regeneration and sensation. In doing so, we anticipate developing new strategies to promote and preserve normal corneal nerve density in patients with ocular surface disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Corticolimbic circuits play an important role in maternal care, threat and stress responses postpartum, but it is still unknown which neuronal mechanisms connect corticolimbic circuits with core maternal circuits. To this end, we will determine the role of neuroplasticity in a specific corticolimbic circuit, using a multidisciplinary approach that uniquely positions us to address these questions. It will have a significant positive impact on our mechanistic understanding of the neurobiology of the motherhood and may contribute to the design of new therapeutic approaches to prevent and decrease the incidence of mental states with similar neural mechanisms, improving well-being of mothers and their offspring.

PHR: Narrative To lessen the negative impact of drug resistant epilepsy in children, a new pre-surgical noninvasive biomarker that identifies reliably the area of the brain that generates the epileptic seizures is essential. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial dysfunction is increasingly associated with many currently incurable late-onset diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease, heart disease, and cancer. Preliminary results suggest that mitochondrial dysfunction causes molecular oxygen-mediated tau hyperphosphorylation, aggregation, and proteotoxicity – which is thought to be a leading cause of Frontotemporal Lobar Degeneration, Alzheimer’s Disease, and other tauopathies. This proposal aims to mechanistically understand these phenomenological results and stands to enable the rational pursuit of innovative approaches to prevent tauopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Under-diagnosis occurs when an individual living with a medical condition has not been diagnosed. Overlooking of diagnosis prevents patients from opportunities of appropriate treatments and prevention strategies, and often is more serious in some population subgroups. Recent emphasis on electronic health records (EHRs) provides a unique opportunity for addressing under-diagnosis, which to date remains largely unexploited due to lack of suitable analytical methods. The overarching goal of this project is to develop data-driven methods to accurately identify patients from EHRs who possibly miss their diagnosis and provide insights for reasons of under-diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma (GBM) is a deadly disease with median survival post-treatment of 15 months, and no major advancements in therapy in the past decade. Based on the recent discoveries that neuronal activity promotes GBM growth and murine and human models of GBM have cell-intrinsic circadian rhythms that synchronize to the host, we propose to identify daily signals that entrain GBM cells and promote growth. The findings from these experiments should reveal treatments that slow tumor progression to improve individual patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is a life-threatening infection that affects many children and can frequently result in the failure of multiple organs, such as the lungs, heart, or kidneys. There are no existing effective treatments that are specifically designed for sepsis, but there is evidence that some subgroups of patients with sepsis respond differently to some treatments, including a subgroup with persistent lung and heart failure that we have previously described. We propose developing and testing an algorithm that can predict which children with infections will develop this specific high-risk type of sepsis and studying what treatments appear to result in more benefit using the medical records of tens of thousands of children with infections receiving care in an intensive care unit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative (relevance): Despite appropriate treatments, chronic blood disorders such as chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) and other myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPN) can transform into more aggressive conditions, i.e., respectively blast crisis (BC) CML or secondary acute myeloid leukemia (sAML), which are very poorly responsive to currently available treatments. This proposal seeks to understand the mechanisms through which deficit of a molecule called miR- 142 causes a loss of function of the immune system that favors BC/sAML transformation and to target these mechanisms with new approaches that address the otherwise unmet need for effective therapies for patients with these conditions. To this end, we will develop a novel drug called CpG-M-miR-142 to restore levels of miR- 142, enhance immune system function and eventually block disease transformation in these otherwise poor-risk patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: NARRATIVE Diastolic heart disease (DHD) is the leading cause of death and disability worldwide. Diastolic dysfunction is caused by stiffening of the heart and impaired relaxation which occur by unknown molecular mechanisms. In this proposal, the PI and colleagues determine if cardiac microtubules underlie diastolic dysfunction in DHD. In Aim 1 they demonstrate that hypertension and metabolic syndrome are cooperative stabilizers of the cardiac microtubule network and determine if cardiac microtubules are molecular regulators of myocyte and myocardial stiffness. In Aim 2 the PI and colleagues leverage newly developed working myocardial preparation to quantify the cardiac microtubules influence on diastolic performance in normal, hypertensive and DHD myocardium. Together, the results determine the contribution of cardiac microtubules to diastolic dysfunction and demonstrate the potential for microtubule target drugs as a new class of therapies for DHD.
