IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Endometriosis is a common but poorly understood condition, particularly in non-Whites, that is benign, and often harbors mutations in “driver” genes. This Study will use state-of-the-art single cell transcriptomics, epigenomics, exome-sequencing and a bioluminescent transplant model to catalogue somatic mutations across a diverse cohort of patients and dissect consequences of somatic mutations to identify new therapeutic opportunities. These insights are expected to pave the way to the development of precision medicine for endometriosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Acute pancreatitis (AP) is a common and serious condition, accounting for more than 300,000 hospitalizations and over $2 billion in health care costs per year in the United States alone. Patients with AP have an increased risk of diabetes (DM) which increases morbidity, mortality and costs. The overarching goal of this proposal is to determine whether continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) would be clinically useful to predict risk for developing DM, the need for insulin therapy and subtype of DM among patients who have experienced an episode of AP. This could support the use of CGM in routine care for patients who have experienced an episode of AP to diagnose DM at an early stage and predict likely need for insulin therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 700,000 U.S. hairdressers are likely exposed to mixtures of chemicals which could impact lung health. This will be the first study to comprehensively assess personal and workplace behaviors and occupational exposures to chemicals commonly found in salon settings (phthalates and volatile organic compounds) in a racially and ethnically diverse hairdresser cohort, and to examine their association with early markers of respiratory disease, lung function and respiratory symptoms. Findings from this work will have direct public health implications by informing effective interventions and federal policies to protect vulnerable populations and addressing exposures that impact population health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Human stem cell-derived three-dimensional (3D) models of the brain do not fully recapitulate the composition of progenitor cells present in the developing human cortex and the signals produced by non-neural cell types. Here, we will generate a 3D, microphysiological model of the brain that recapitulates human cortical development at improved resolution by producing a broader diversity of progenitor and neuronal cell populations (outer radial glia, cortical interneurons, mature cortical excitatory neurons), and by integrating signals from non-neuronal cell types (vascular and immune cells). This project addresses a major bottleneck in human stem biology and should result in better tools to study neurodevelopmental and cognitive disorders in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative Colon cancer is among the leading causes of death worldwide and host-bacterial microbiota immune interactions profoundly influence tumorigenesis, cancer progression and response to therapies. Nevertheless, the role of fungi (mycobiota) in these processes remain largely unexplored, missing a potential opportunity for developing novel diagnostic, preventative, and therapeutic strategies. Upon providing the first evidence for association of specific fungi with gastrointestinal cancers here we aim to define central mechanisms of mycobiota interactions within colorectal tumors to understand their role in cancer and therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Amyloid-β (Aβ) accumulation as toxic oligomers and plaques are hallmark pathological changes that occur early in an Alzheimer’s disease brain and progress throughout the course of disease. This proposal will determine if elevated synaptic activity, a basic function of the brain in action, not only causes formation of Aβ but also induces it to aggregate into toxic species. Furthermore, we will determine which neuronal type produces these aggregates and if chronic modulation of specific neurons has a long-term impact on Aβ plaques.

PHR: Narrative Virus-associated glomerular diseases are seen in increasing frequency in clinical practice with underlying mechanisms still unclear. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: AIM-UP Narrative: AIM-UP will combine data from nine large-scale teen pregnancy prevention projects to describe the use, examine the effectiveness, and describe approaches to adaptations of evidence-based programming for four youth at high-risk for unintended pregnancy. Using the FRAME framework, the project examines adaptations in the following four areas: (1) trauma and system involvement; (2) diversity, equity, inclusion and justice; (3) implementing in rural communities; and (4) adapting for virtual delivery. Effective adaptations will be translated into a toolkit using the Delphi approach for adapting evidence-based programs to local contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The basal ganglia are involved in many motor and non-motor functions, including the regulation of valence and mood. This project will study, in non-human primates, the anatomical connections and parkinsonism-associated pathophysiological changes of pallidal projections to the lateral habenula, which is involved in the processing of negative valence. Results of this project will further our understanding of the pathophysiology of the palllidohabenular projection in parkinsonism, and may help us to better understand the origin of some of the psychiatric aspects of Parkinson’s disease, such as depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Existing therapeutic interventions for single ventricle congenital heart defects, including synthetic or tissue- engineered vascular conduits made by seeding autologous patient bone marrow cells onto biodegradable polymeric tubular scaffolds, are insufficient for effective patient care due to vulnerability to infection, thrombosis, inability to grow, or a high incidence of graft stenosis after transplantation. Native blood vessel scaffolds and human induced pluripotent stem cell (hiPSC)-derived endothelial cells, capable of mitigating thrombosis and cellular over-proliferation during vascular conduit generation, may offer an opportunity to effectively address the above challenges. This project describes our efforts to develop universal, hypoimmunogenic contractile conduits based on hiPSC-derived cardiomyocytes, cardiac fibroblasts, and endothelial cells that can prevent graft stenosis and provide pumping activity to assist blood flow through both in vitro assays and in vivo implantation into an immune-humanized rat model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Reversible shape changes of arteries, which allow for efficient blood circulation, is provided to tissues by elastin, a protein polymer whose structure was not fully resolved. Through advanced experimental and modeling methods, we will determine the structure and function of the entire polymer of healthy elastin with age/disease-associated modifications and characterize the molecular mechanisms of arterial dysfunction associated with aging and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The real-world evidence generated by this project will identify which medication therapies maximize benefits and safety for pregnant people with chronic hypertension, including those with high-risk comorbidities. This evidence will be highly informative for treatment of chronic hypertension in pregnancy, which is an urgent public health need. Thus, the proposed project aligns with the mission of NHLBI to promote the prevention and treatment of heart, lung, and blood disorders so individuals can live longer and more fulfilling lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Study Description Patients with oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma who have an AJCC 8th edition stage of T0-T4, N0-N3, M0 will be enrolled on our double-blind, randomized clinical trial assessing the efficacy of MRI sialography guided parotid ductal sparing. Patient reported xerostomia and saliva mass will be compared between groups at 6 and 12 months post-treatment. Atlas-based duct segmentation analyses will be conducted to potentially facilitate broader implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project aims to understand how heart tissues differentiate during human development by studying a 3D, in vitro, temporally dynamic differentiation system that faithfully recapitulates fetal differentiation patterns of the heart. We will carry out aims that span efforts toward mapping, perturbing, modeling, and validating our model- based understanding of these data, with a goal of learning DNA sequence elements that drive gene expression programs during development. These efforts will enable us to identify specific genetic determinants of developmental heart defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Cytokines govern key cellular processes of pregnancy. We recently discovered that the cytokine Interleukin 27 (IL-27) is a critical player of immunity at the maternal-fetal interface, and here, we propose to define the mechanistic features of IL-27 signaling that underlie its protective capacity during congenital infection. Outcomes from our work will provide new fundamental insights into immune regulatory cytokine communication and function at the maternal-fetal interface with an overarching goal to improve neonatal outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks to develop a new molecular strategy to limit neurovascular injury in blinding eye disease. ACAT1 (acyl-Coenzyme A: cholesterol acyltransferase 1) is a critical regulator/activator of cholesterol metabolism and a promotor of an inflammatory microglia/macrophage phenotype. The proposed studies are designed to use a highly specific ACAT1 inhibitor and ACAT1 deficient mice and cells to investigate the specific role of myeloid cell ACAT1 in ischemic retinopathies and to define the underlying mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Surveillance for cancer incidence and mortality is crucial to cancer control and to cancer research, but measuring cancer registry completeness is extremely challenging. Current measures leave out the two most common cancers, as well as less common cancers, and universally include data only from Black people and White people, therefore routinely misestimating completeness for registries covering populations with high proportions of Asian people, Native American people, and people of Hispanic ethnicity. We propose a new comprehensive method to improve the rigor and reproducibility of measurement of completeness for US cancer registries and to guide choices of where registries can invest resources to optimize overall and group- specific completeness going forward.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: We propose a randomized controlled trial of a self-management support intervention for low-income, minority adults with COPD that involves comprehensive screening for and targeted management of barriers to COPD control and combines this with home-based pulmonary rehabilitation and pre-emptive medication prescribing for COPD exacerbations. We will compare the intervention with an attention control for effects on COPD controller medication adherence and other self-management behaviors, symptoms and exercise capacity at 6 months and hospitalizations and emergency department visits at 12 months.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to understand how regulatory DNA sequences quantitatively tune gene expression in specific cell types and/or disease contexts, and how we can engineer these sequences to reprogram gene expression to restore function in the context of Alagille Syndrome. Our approach combines reading and writing of the genome in human pluripotent stem cells that can be used to model the functions of cells from human blood vessels. Our study will lay the foundations for future studies to develop CRISPR therapeutics for Alagille Syndrome and other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cornea nerves can be damaged by trauma, surgery, infection or diabetes. In this proposal, we will investigate the regenerative potential and functional consequences of adding extracellular vesicles derived from mesenchymal stem cells to damaged corneal nerves. We expect to elucidate basic mechanisms that may lead to new clinical therapies for pathologies that affect the corneal nerves.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite aggressive treatment to lower lipids and blood pressure, a substantial burden of residual atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk remains. Currently, we have limited knowledge of (1) the underlying mechanisms, (2) risk prediction, and (3) novel treatments for residual ASCVD. We propose to integrate genetic and clinical data to elucidate the mechanisms underlying residual ASCVD risk, identify patients at high risk (additionally accounting for environmental and social factors), and facilitate repurposing of drugs for reducing residual risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Only older mosquitoes are competent to transmit pathogens to humans. This project is aimed to develop a rapid, accurate, and robust approach to determine the age of mosquitoes in the field which is critically needed to assess health risks associated with vector-borne diseases. Having the ability to detect vector age in the field would also enable rapid assessment of control strategies, especially those designed to manage or minimize insecticide resistance development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Research Narrative We propose to develop innovative generative AI approaches, with thorough and rigorous evaluation and validation in laboratories, to advance retrosynthesis for small molecules. Successful completion of this project will enable diverse and high-quality synthetic reaction libraries for any given drug-like molecule, which will be highly significant to accelerating drug development (e.g., lead generation). Successful application of the new methodology is ultimately expected to facilitate rapid retrosynthetic analysis of newly discovered or complex molecules as well as those with limited availability, enabling chemical synthesis for subsequent biological evaluations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Coronary heart disease accounts for almost half of all cardiovascular disease-related deaths in the US and many instances are due to heart attacks. While scar tissue (fibrosis) is a necessary step in replacing lost heart cells and recovering from a heart attack, too much can cause long-term structural changes to the heart. This project seeks to determine how a specific protein in a critical population of heart cells (cardiac fibroblasts) regulates the organ-level response to a heart attack.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Glutamate is a neurotransmitter in the brain that mediates cognition, memory, and learning; specialized proteins, called glutamate transporters, regulate the amount and movements of glutamate in the brain in processes controlled by ions. This proposal aims to understand how these transporters evolved to perform their essential functions and how they interact with ions in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Gene cargo delivery systems remain the major challenges to advance cell-based and patient-specific therapies. The goal of the proposed study is to develop an in vitro non-viral intracellular delivery approach for effective gene engineering by combining gas vesicles, protein shells containing gas in the core, and Cas9- ribonucleoprotein (RNP) to form protein clouds as delivery cargo, controlled by ultrasound excitation for safe and efficient manipulation of target cells. The proposed approach has the potential to provide advanced genetic modifications that are required to treat advanced diseases such as solid tumor immunotherapy and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative This project aims to identify early developmental, biomedical, and molecular indicators of risk for severe or profound intellectual disability in young children with Down syndrome (DS). Young children with DS will be assessed at three time points and cognitive outcomes will be analyzed in relation to behavioral, biomedical, and molecular risk factors. Results of this work will promote greater inclusivity in DS research and may facilitate innovations in both biomedical and behavioral intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chagas disease is the result of infection with the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi and is characterized by compromised heart function in humans and in the many other host species that this parasite naturally infects, including dogs in the continental United States. This project will use a setting of high intensity transmission in dogs in south Texas to investigate questions of importance to the management of T. cruzi infection in humans, related in particular to the benefit of early and successful resolution of the infection using drug therapy, to prevention of the development of disease. Completion of this work will provide guidance for the how to best reduce the impact of T. cruzi on human and animal populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Title of Project: “Solving longstanding mysteries in plasma triglyceride metabolism” Genetic variation that impairs the efficiency of intravascular triglyceride hydrolysis by lipoprotein lipase (LPL) increases the risk of coronary heart disease, yet the functions of key regulators of plasma triglyceride metabolism have remained enigmatic. We will use advanced biophysical methods, advanced microscopy, and physiologic studies in mice to elucidate the functions of two apolipoproteins that regulate LPL activity, and we will explore the turnover and trafficking of LPL in capillaries. Our work will provide fresh insights into the molecular physiology of plasma triglyceride metabolism and new strategies for treating cardiometabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it utilizes a mechanistic understanding of the progression of chronic ischemic heart failure in cardiomyocytes to restore function and improve cardiac function. The study will provide critical preclinical data in a large animal model on the therapeutic efficacy of a first-in-class gene therapy for dilated ischemic cardiomyopathy. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission to enhance health, legthen life, and reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our long-term goal is to achieve comprehensive predictive models that can guide precision medicine and synthetic biology. Toward this goal, we will make models understandable, reproducible, credible and reusable by (1) developing tool for reproducibly and credibly building, simulating, and analyzing models; (2) assembling these tools into a user friendly workflow; (3) providing the community services for annotating, simulating, and validating models; (4) promoting the importance of reproducibility; and (5) training researchers to conduct modeling reproducibility. These efforts will enhance the reproducibility of modeling and, in turn, enable comprehensive models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our study focuses on a multi-component switching mechanism that changes the activity of Grp94 from a normal folding chaperone to a disease specific variant that helps cancer cells survive. We introduce a new method of separately studying the individual elements of this switching mechanism, and use this technology to dissect how each component alters the function of the chaperone. Our overarching goals are to discover how this switch changes Grp94 and to use this knowledge to distinguish between the pathologic and normal forms of Grp94 so that the first can be targeted for treatment while second is spared.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE Schizophrenia represents a major public-health problem worldwide. In this proposal, we aim to combine fMRI, neurocognitive, and clinical data across multiple large-scale datasets to provide an explanatory theoretical model for understanding neural ensemble alterations in patients with schizophrenia and their relationship to cognitive deficits. In doing so, we hope to elucidate their biological mechanisms and contribute to the development of novel therapeutics for cognitive deficits and brain-based biomarkers for treatment selection and target engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is a progressive atherosclerotic disorder that impacts >200 million people worldwide. Physical activity is greatly reduced in these patients by exercise-associated pain, thus diminishing functional capacity and quality of life. We seek to elucidate the neuronal mechanisms that produce exercise- associated pain and determine the potential benefits of Nrf2 upregulation in muscle afferent neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Clinician-scientists play an essential role in the application of new technologies and discoveries to clinical practice. We propose that didactic training and a 2-4 immersion in the laboratory of a successful basic scientist, or the application of basic science to precision/personalized medicine, with expertise in molecular biology will provide a sound foundation for a career as a physician-scientist involved in translational research in inflammation biology, relevant to trauma, sepsis, burns and critical care survivors. The successful trainee will develop expertise in functional genomics, molecular genetics and molecular biology to help translate the current genomic revolution to improved clinical practice, and will be prepared to serve as a national leader in surgical/clinical academics.

PROJECT_TITLE: Molecular Biology in Burns and Trauma
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Special Emphasis Panel[ZGM1 TWD-A (PD)]

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because cohesin-mutant MDS is an aggressive disease with poor outcomes, for which there is no targeted therapy available and the mechanisms of which are not well understood. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The purpose of this T35 grant renewal is to provide intensive, short-term (10-week) research training for 20 medical students who will conduct clinical, translational, and basic research projects relevant to the mission of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute. The research will be conducted under the mentorship of faculty members from the Colleges of Medicine and Engineering, who have a proven record of mentoring. The program is designed to attract the most highly qualified University of Florida medical students into careers as physician- scientists in the fields of cardiovascular and pulmonary research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Porphyromonas gingivalis is a periodontal pathogen that colonizes in subgingival plaque and use a specialized secretion system (T9SS) to deliver virulence factors including the gingipain proteases. This project seeks to define the T9SS architecture and mechanistic details of cargo translocation to lay a foundation for development of intervention strategies aimed at blocking T9SS function and disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Breast cancer remains the most common malignancy among women worldwide. Clinical work demonstrates that patients with ‘blunted’ circadian rhythms in circulating glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol) have worse quality of life and succumb to cancer earlier than those with robust rhythms. This work will identify the mechanism(s) driving this deleterious phenomenon and develop therapeutic approaches to target it, likely conferring benefits to patients with breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  The human lung, similar to other internal organs, is encapsulated by a thin squamous epithelium called the mesothelium. Aside from knowledge that mesothelial cells produce lubricating fluid to facilitate smooth organ movement in relationship to each other and the body wall, mesothelium function in lung development and injury repair remains poorly understood. In this study, we will use Myelin Regulatory Factor, a transcription factor that is expressed in the mesothelium as an entry point to address the formation of this fundamental cell layer, its role as a signaling center in lung growth, and its crosstalk with other injured cell types in lung repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance  Immunotherapy in combination with chemotherapy has proven highly effective for TNBC; however, some patients develop severe adverse events, and many may not benefit from treatment. We will investigate auto-antibody response in predicting adverse events and recurrence during and after single agent pembrolizumab therapy. Our split sample discovery and independent validation design using hundreds of samples from an FDA registration trial has the potential to introduce a clinically useful new biomarker that could optimize the use of immune checkpoint therapy in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatment-resistant metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) is the deadliest form of prostate cancer, with a dismal median survival of only ~5.5 months. Unfortunately, by the time this deadly form of disease is diagnosed, patients are already progressing on androgen receptor (AR)- directed drugs and prognosis is very poor. We developed a liquid biopsy biomarker, referred to as EnhanceAR-Seq, to more sensitively detect resistance early with the longer-term goal of advancing personalized treatment strategies to improve patient outcomes and survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal is to determine and validate an objective integrated multimodal electrophysiological index to assess the level of visceral pain in patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). We will establish this objective biomarker through non-invasive surface recordings of the autonomic neural activities and building a mathematical prediction model via machine learning algorithms. This biomarker will lead to accelerated development of preventive and therapeutic schemes, especially non-opioid treatments for effective pain management in IBS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Corneal transplantation, or keratoplasty, is the only known curative treatment for corneal blindness, yet the cadaveric donor tissue required for this sight-restoring procedure is available to less than 2% of patients worldwide. While several different tissue-engineered corneal transplants have been proposed, designing multi- layered constructs with the long-term transparency and regenerative capacity of a human donor cornea remains a formidable challenge. Here we propose leveraging recent advances in 3D bioprinting to fabricate a bilayered, tissue-engineered cornea, with each layer fabricated from a customized biomaterial formulation with optimized print parameters to achieve the desired biofunctionality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Older adults with asthma have diminished perception of airway expiratory obstruction, which may contribute to poor outcomes. We conducted a pilot randomized trial of an intervention that trains older patients with asthma to better perceive airway obstruction and coupled it with motivational interviewing to improve asthma self care and demonstrated improvements in several clinical outcomes. We now propose a fully powered trial to test the intervention’s efficacy for clinical and self-care outcomes and examine potential mediation pathways via increased used of inhaled corticosteroids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative It is a common clinical occurrence that neuroimaging scans obtained in the course of routine care discover covert cerebrovascular disease, comprising covert brain infarction and white matter disease. These patients are at very high risk of future stroke and dementia, but there are no proven preventive treatments or guidelines for initiating risk factor-modifying therapy, in part because the patients are difficult to identify. We have previously developed a natural language processing (NLP) algorithm that accurately identifies these patients at scale; we now propose to use this large cohort with NLP-labeled scans to develop a deep learning model to identify covert cerebrovascular disease and other radiomic features to predict stroke and dementia from routinely obtained neuroimages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an inflammatory condition in which peripheral nerves are attacked by patient's own immune system and current treatments are ineffective in a substantial proportion of patients, who are left with permanent disability. GBS is mediated by autoantibodies and/or autoreactive T cells directed against axonal or myelin antigens that initiate immune attack against peripheral nerves and macrophage lineage cells play critical role in eventual damage to the nerve fibers. This project proposes to test a treatment stratgey that can reduce macrophage inflammation in the nerves of animal models relevant to GBS. These results may facilitate development of new therapies for patients with GBS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging adult women are at high risk for obesity, proinflammatory behaviors (insufficient sleep, intake of highly processed foods, declines in physical activity), and psychological stressors—all of which perpetuate chronic inflammation and contribute to insufficient weight loss treatment response. The proposed study builds upon promising preliminary data demonstrating that an integrated lifestyle intervention (ILI) addressing all of these risk factors through the lens of inflammation produced clinically meaningful improvements in depression, anxiety, perceived stress, as well as weight loss. We will now examine the potential of ILI to positively influence adiposity and biomarkers of inflammation and cardiometabolic risk over longer-term follow up, compared with a developmentally adapted behavioral weight loss arm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: We discovered a novel antiviral natural product that is produced by enzymes encoded with the human genome. This natural product can inhibit replication of a wide range of viruses, including Zika virus, hepatitis C virus, influenza virus, rhinovirus, respiratory syncytial virus and HIV. The goal of this proposal is to define the underlying mechanisms responsible to this broad antiviral activity and to understand its role in normal physiology. These new insights might lead to new antiviral therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health: This work will directly benefit civilians, caregivers as well as U.S. service mem- bers and veterans by: 1) unveiling potential neural targets of future pain reducing treatments; 2) developing a non-invasive diagnostic and predictive assessment of neuropathic pain, and 3) unmasking the relationship be- tween quantitative connectome measures and psychosocial aspects of the pain experience after SCI. Having an understanding of the mechanism of pain following SCI injury is critical to further provide a referral mecha- nism for intervention and/or modification of ongoing intervention that will aid to ameliorate the debilitating consequences of neuropathic pain in individuals with SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer usually is detected at a late stage when it is uncurable. This proposal focusses on identifying reliable early detection markers that would allow discovering tumors at a time when they are still local. Overall, our project will identify secreted protein markers that are detectable in easily accessible liquid biopsies and distinguish between pancreatic non-cancerous lesions and cancerous lesions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure drugs help improve cardiac performance. This study compares an FDA-approved drug with a promising new drug to answer why one drug might cause irregular heart rhythms as a fatal side effect while another is safe. The understanding of how these drugs work will reveal exciting new cell processes to enable future heart failure drug development towards increased efficacy and minimal side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Monocytes / macrophages play a critical role in antibody therapy for cancer. However, these cells are in a suppressed state within chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). We have found that activation of a particular intracellular receptor can reverse this suppressed state and lead to stronger antitumor responses. Here, we propose to study how a ligand that activates this receptor works, in order to justify clinical testing of this ligand as a potential treatment for CLL.

PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol-associated liver disease is a major clinical problem. This project will evaluate the role of histone lysine methylation enzymes in development, progression and resolution of alcohol induced liver fibrosis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Current neuro-protective and neuro-regenerative strategies to restore vision to the over 64 million people worldwide who are legally blind from diseases that damage the optic nerve are successful at promoting survival of damaged retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) and promoting long distance RGC axon regeneration but are lacking in cues to guide axons towards appropriate targets in the brain. We have shown that exogenously applied electric fields (EFs) not only promote RGC axon growth but appear to also be able to control the direction of axon growth. In this project, we propose to develop EF application into a technology that will synergize that with current strategies for optic nerve regeneration by providing directional cues for regenerating axons, leading to more targeted growth and increased recovery of visual function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Exercise is an extremely efficient lifestyle factor to prevent and reverse metabolic, inflammatory, and neoplastic diseases, but exercise is hard and the regulatory mechanisms driving an individual's ability to exercise remain poorly understood. This proposal explores the impact of the intestinal microbiota on the activity of brain neurons that influence exercise performance. The results of these experiments will enhance our understanding of how exercise performance can be controlled, and possibly enhanced, from the gastrointestinal tract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE - RELEVANCE TO DISEASE Cystic Fibrosis (CF), one of the most common lethal genetic diseases in the United States, is characterized by progressive lung destruction and development of comorbidities as patients age. In 2010, Emory University established a highly successful CF biospecimen repository, and in 2020 Emory and Augusta University established the Georgia CF Data Warehouse (GACFDW), a cloud-based high-quality computational infrastructure that would support access to integrated clinical and research data focusing on non-pulmonary complications in a small cohort of CF patients. The goal of the present proposal is to extend the GACFDW to all 900 CF patients followed at Emory and Augusta CF clinics, to focus on pulmonary complications of CF, and to develop the GACFDW into a unique Data Resource that will strengthen CF researchers’ ability to integrate multiple research data streams with patient clinical status, providing new opportunities to understand factors contributing to disease progression and response to therapy. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative People with cystic fibrosis (CF) are living longer with new treatments, but symptoms like pain, cough, and tiredness continue to affect their quality of life. This study will look at symptoms that occur together, and relationships between symptoms and individuals’ biological processes, social environment, and the care they receive. The goal is to identify new opportunities to reduce symptom burden for people with CF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: A major undesirable outcome of cataract surgery wounding is the development of the lens fibrotic disease, Posterior Capsule Opacification (PCO). The proposed studies take important steps toward elucidating how extracellular cell-surface vimentin functions to promote a fibrotic response to lens injury. Findings from these studies are expected to inform new treatment strategies for PCO, with potential application to understanding how extracellular vimentin mediates fibrotic disease and pathogenesis in other tissue types.

PHR: Project Narrative: Sodium plays a critical role that influences almost every biological process in humans. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to characterize the pathophysiologic response to exercise in chronic severe pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular failure (PH-RVF) and then use this novel physiologic understanding to develop a more durable, wearable mechanical cardiopulmonary support system – pulmonary assist device (PAD) - for patients with chronic severe PH-RVF. Our multidisciplinary team will utilize our high- fidelity sheep model of PH-RVF as a platform to first study changes in exercise tolerance and capacity using a treadmill, after which we will then attach the PAD and study any improvements in exercise tolerance. This project will fill the current gap in our understanding about exercise physiology and cardiopulmonary deficit during PH-RVF and how this deficit can be addressed with a wearable mechanical cardiopulmonary support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH CTR AT TYLER
PHR: Pleural fibrosis is thickening/stiffening of the pleura resulting from pleural infection, asbestos-related pleural disease, and treatments, etc., which leads to severe restrictive lung disease and clinically significant dyspnea associated with fibrothorax. We have identified a gene called Dedicator of Cytokinesis 2 (DOCK2) that plays a key role in mesothelial to mesenchymal transition and pleural fibrosis. The proposed studies will shed new lights on the pathogenesis of pleural fibrosis and may ultimately lead to the identification of novel targets for therapeutic intervention of this detrimental disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This R01 project will address the synergy between Hippo/Yap and Wnt/b-catenin signaling in cardiomyocyte proliferation in adult mice and in human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes. Myocardial infarction (MI) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality world-wide, and patients with MI often progress to chronic heart failure, requiring heart transplantation or mechanical support devices to maintain survival. By leveraging the synergy between Yap and Wnt signaling to induce MI border zone-specific proliferation of cardiomyocytes, this project seeks to understand the mechanistic basis of cardiomyocyte proliferation in the setting of myocardial injury to enable the development of future MI therapies.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Biological age reflects not only chronological age but also the impact of genetics and the environment on the aging process of the brain and body; dietary habits have been shown to have significant effects in studies of general health. In this proposal we will evaluate relationships between diet, biological aging, and neurodegeneration and disease progression in multiple sclerosis (MS). This study will further our understanding of mechanisms of neurodegeneration and neuroprotection in MS, and will help us learn about how diet and other lifestyle factors can impact MS prognosis over time.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arkansas and Louisiana have among the highest rates of adult obesity in the United States at 38.7% and 38.6%, respectively. Prevention and intervention efforts are needed to reduce the number of children who will become obese adults and suffer the host of negative health consequences that accompany it. This proposal will develop and test strategies to stop the use of detrimental feeding practices by early childhood educators which promote unhealthy weight trajectories, inappropriate eating behaviors and poor dietary outcomes for children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Relevance to public health The project will advance and clinically test an automated intraoperative fluorescence imaging technology to help cancer surgeons remove 100% of primary tumors when possible, reducing the need for follow up treatments like call-back surgery, radiation therapy, and/or chemoradiotherapy. Moreover, successful primary surgery can decrease patient morbidity and yield higher survival rates. The proposed fluorescence imaging technology will be evaluated for head and neck squamous cell carcinoma surgery against state-of-the-art surgical guidance methods in an 80-patient clinical study, as a precursor to a future phase II clinical trial where the technology is expected to have positive impact on patient survival and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE While chimeric antigen receptor T cell (CAR T) therapy represents a major advancement in the cancer immunotherapy field, these ‘living drugs’ face several barriers to their widespread success, including the inability to discern their fate after infusion. Here we propose a new in vivo approach to monitor CAR T cells with high specificity using immuno-positron emission tomography (immunoPET), a rapidly expanding area of molecular imaging. Specifically, we will develop and characterize the first human-specific immunoPET probes for OX40 and ICOS, two cell-surface antigens that are upregulated on activated T cells (including CAR Ts) with the long- term goal of clinical translation to improve patient outcomes by enabling non-invasive monitoring of responses to CAR T and other immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will establish a novel epigenetic ‘priming’ strategy designed to enhance PSMA expression and in turn augment clinical activity of PSMA-directed therapies such as 177Lutetium-PSMA-617. In addition to testing the effect of vorinostat (HDAC inhibitor) in a clinical trial, we will also conduct preclinical studies evaluating other epigenetic therapies alone and in combination, which will inform iterative clinical trials. Finally, we will evaluate imaging, tissue and blood-based predictive biomarkers, which will lead to new molecular diagnostics that will improve the lives and outcomes for patients with prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The genetic code in heart and skeletal muscle are decoded by a unique molecular machine that is different from the rest of the body, mutations of which causes fatal heart failure in infants. Completion of this project will shed lights how heart works at the molecular level and lay the foundation for the development of new therapies for heart diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Sulfation is the most common modification of carbohydrates yet is often overlooked. Effective and innovative methods will be developed and related enzymes will be expressed for facile synthesis of complex N- glycans and O-glycans with defined sulfation patterns. The resulting compounds are important standards for glycomics analysis and probes to understand the functions of sulfated glycans as well as many biological processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Biallelic mutations in the tubulin folding cofactor D (TBCD) gene result in a severe early-onset developmental and epileptic encephalopathy for which there is no treatment. Herein we will determine the neuropathological mechanisms of TBCD variants using patient derived cerebral organoids and investigate the molecular and clinical phenotypes in a corresponding allelic series of TBCD knock-in mouse models. We will then evaluate the efficacy of a targeted adeno-associated virus gene replacement therapy in our established models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The brain neurons that control movement and executive function in mammals are born at the same time from the same parent cells, but they develop to give rise to completely different connections and functions. How genes are regulated to control these fate choices is not well understood: we propose to study the intersecting roles of gene accessibility and gene repression in the normal development of uniquely mammalian brain connections serving movement and executive function. Completion of our Aims could lead to novel treatments for conditions like autism, cerebral palsy, and paralysis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Maternal obesity with hyperphagia is a risk factor for preeclampsia, pregnancy hypertension, and offspring cardiometabolic disease. In utero programming of female offspring during preeclampsia contributes to the lifecycle of disease in women as a sex and gender. Investigating the maternal obesogenic environment is warranted to halt the transgenerational programming of cardiometabolic disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adults with Down syndrome (DS) have a 75-90% lifetime risk of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), making this a significant issue for the DS community and broader public health concern. Currently, research studies and AD clinical trials rely on in-person testing options for adults with DS and development of remote testing options will benefit study design, reduce participant burden, and increase the probability of diverse participant inclusion in DS research. This study will transition promising measures for tracking early AD from in-person to remote administration, providing an innovative and novel data collection approach for monitoring participant performance in research studies and clinical trials in adults with DS that will directly benefit projects funded through NIH INCLUDE (INvestigation of Co-occurring conditions across the Lifespan to Understand Down syndromE).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Biomarker signatures might represent a more realistic personalized medicine approach to match rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients with the most appropriate therapeutic option to optimally control immune driven inflammation and thereby minimize joint destruction in this disease. Prior studies have highlighted strong associations between body weight and RA disease outcomes suggesting an important relationship between inflammation, metabolism, and RA outcomes. We will characterize obesity-induced mediators to address the question of whether adipokines and inflammatory lipid profiling in plasma effectively predict patient response to therapy prior to administration.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement While up to 50% of patients with GDM require the addition of a medication during pregnancy, the long-term effects of medication treatment of GDM are largely unknown. Using state-of-the-art statistical methods, we will compare GDM medications (metformin, glyburide, insulin) on long term risk of maternal diabetes and childhood obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Inherited heart diseases are a significant cause of death and morbidity with limited options of treatment largely due to the poor understanding of the underlying mechanisms of impaired heart muscle contractility. The goal of this project is to understand how contractility is regulated in healthy pig heart muscle and how contractility is dysregulated in diseased heart muscle. Such understanding can provide important guidance towards mitigating the root causes of these diseases via more targetted approaches than with current therapies that mainly focus on alleviating symptoms.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This study seeks to evaluate an innovative multilevel intervention to increase contraceptive use in rural Uganda, which has among the highest unmet needs for family planning and fertility rates in the world. By addressing multilevel barriers to family planning, this intervention can help couples to better space and time their pregnancies, reduce the incidence of unintended pregnancy, and ultimately reduce rates of maternal and infant morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: We discovered that each of the cardinal interneuron classes of the spinal cord can be divided into two subtypes - one with local connections and one with long range connections, based on a conserved set of genetic signatures. These findings reveal a previously unappreciated organizational principle of the spinal cord, but lead to the question why did nature duplicate the cardinal cell groups creating these subsets? This grant will examine whether these newly identified long/short range connectivity divisions of the cardinal classes represent distinct neural units for motor behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This project aims to quantify the effects of sustained volunteering on multiple modifiable cardiovascular disease (CVD) biomarkers while considering the selection into volunteering, genetic susceptibility for clinically high CVD biomarkers, and the effect heterogeneity in multiple population subgroups. Findings from this ten-year longitudinal study of older adults will inform the optimal level of volunteering among older adults, identify which population subgroups should be targeted for volunteering interventions, and show how genetic information informs research on volunteering and health. This study will also provide insight for future research to examine the complex trajectory of volunteering and cardiovascular health in middle-aged and older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a chronic, inflammatory, debilitating skin disease that is treated symptomatically, but only a subset of its symptoms can be identified clinically by visual inspection and palpation, which is the current standard of care in the United States. This project proposes development of an advanced photoacoustic and ultrasound imaging system with an easy-to-use hand-held probe that will generate a 3D map of likely HS involvement throughout the epidermis, dermis, and hypodermis. The proposed photoacoustic/ultrasound imaging system and associated HS-detection algorithm not only hold promise for reducing HS morbidity in direct clinical use by enabling more accurate surgeries and better-targeted pharmacological treatments but will also assist future HS investigators to develop more effective drugs and individualized therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most prevalent joint disease in middle-aged and older populations. The objective of this proposal is to investigate the therapeutic role of NFAT1 treatment in joint tissue aging and OA development using OA mouse models and human joint-tissues with primary OA. Positive results of this preclinical project will promote the development of a personalized OA therapy in patients with significantly reduced NFAT1 expression or biological activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Niemann-Pick C is an invariably fatal lysosomal disease affecting both the liver and brain. The relevance of the proposed studies to public health is that they will define the mechanisms which trigger liver dysfunction in Niemann-Pick C disease. This work is expected to identify novel pathways that significantly contribute to manifestations of Niemann-Pick C, thereby setting the stage for future discovery efforts to identify and test new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is a major public health problem because of its high prevalence and causal relationship with serious medical diseases, and particularly challenging in its treatment is lost weight maintenance—lost weight is often regained. Here, we will investigate how obesity alters the function of brain areas that govern appetite and body weight regulation. This work will be critical for understanding how obesity changes the brain, and for informing therapeutic approaches for improving the ability of people with obesity to lose weight and keep it off.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Sphingosine phosphate lyase insufficiency syndrome (SPLIS) is a rare metabolic disorder that affects the kidneys, brain, hormone-producing glands, skin and immune system. This study will characterize the features of the disease and quality of life of SPLIS patients and how they change over time. We also aim to develop laboratory tests that can help us monitor the health of SPLIS patients and detect the disease in dried blood spots as a newborn screening test.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to develop a soft magnetoelastic microneedle patch that enables the study of in vivo, rapid, and non-invasive characterization of skin mechanical properties on human subjects and establish its clinical significance for the pre-screening and early diagnosis of skin cancer. Moreover, the wireless transmitting features can provide extra information on time-dependent changes of tissue, facilitating further understanding of skin cancer progression. Such platform technology includes not just monitoring the stiffness of the tumor, but also stiffness changes during aging, wound healing, or other treatment processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative Cell fate during human development requires the tight regulation of global gene expression programs that are controlled by pioneer transcription factors (PTFs). These PTFs must recognize specific DNA sequences within very large regions of the chromatin on multiple chromosomes, by yet poorly understood mechanisms. The goal of this research is to understand the rules of PTF-DNA recognition within large regulatory regions and how these mechanisms translate to the cellular transcriptional decisions that ultimately lead to global gene regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a major public health problem for which current treatments are inadequate. Accumulating preclinical and clinical evidence indicates that acute inflammatory activity impairs fear extinction, which in turn could prevent recovery from PTSD. The proposed research takes a vital first step towards translating this evidence into novel interventions to improve public health by determining the effects of acute inflammatory activity on fear extinction processes in men and women with and without chronic PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Synaptic transmission in continuously modulated by short-term plasticity, a ubiquitous property of nerve terminals that rapidly changes the functions of neural circuits without physically restructuring connections. Altered short-term plasticity is implicated in multiple neurological disorders, but this link has been difficult to establish due to a lack of identified molecular mechanisms for plasticity. Building on our recent discovery of two key mechanisms for short-term plasticity, we will use knockout mice to define the molecular interactions and functional consequences of short-term plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Guided by experience and leadership in the NCI-sponsored clinical trial networks (NCI-CTNs) throughout my career, this R50 Research Specialist award offers critical support that would enable me to fully engage in high- yield activities across a spectrum of educational, leadership, and clinical trials-related research activities of the NCI-CTNs. Fundamental to each proposed activity is a consistent focus on reducing health disparities by promoting diverse enrollment in modern clinical trials. Exciting new programs are proposed, including an educational series directed at increasing the diversity of potential future NCI-CTN investigators, protected time to develop minority recruitment interventions that can be deployed across the NCI-CTNs, and establishing my home institution (UC Irvine Chao Family Comprehensive Cancer Center) as an active Affiliate Organization within the NCI-DCP Cancer Prevention Clinical Trials Network.
